Smoked aroma. Sparkling dark brown-red color. Huge light brown creamy head. Medium sweet, strong smoked taste. Very creamy texture. Light bitter, dry finish. Maybe too heavy beer, but very good.
Bottle from the local. Dark brown pour with thick off white head. Nice smoke pit malt aroma. Thin to medium body. Clean and crisp. Smoke is excellent. Reminds me of a pig roast, mmmmm
A great smoked beer,with wonderfull pinces of bacon and ham...Smells terifficly,and has a great taste and so malted...
Bottle pours a deep red beer with a tan head, nice lacing . Scent is Roasted malts and smoked wood. Taste is very smokey. Great stuff!

1pint 9oz btl. Pours a cola bodied cola color with a thi white head. Has the obvious aroma of smoked malt. Didnt enjot this one as much as the urbock or the helles. Intense smokey malt taste (just as in the aroma). I dont get a whole lot of dimenisions to this one. Still nice with the burger I ate, but Ill take the helles next time.

50 cl bottle from Systembolaget. Poured in 1-liter dimpled mug. Dark brown colour with off-white, foamy, medium sized head that takes some time to settle. Aroma is smoked malts, bacon and some more smoke. Taste is also peaty and somewhat sweet. Special but nice. Full bodied and quite dry.

Bottle that heavy got at Vrutak in Zagreb and shared. Poured a red-bronze body with a thick white head that went away slowly. Smoked cheese nose, some pancetta. Lovely. Sweet heavily smoked taste of pancetta, yet soft. Lovely, some bitterness, tasty. Exactly what I expected. Another great smoked from this brewery!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2011 Bottle courtesy of Bierkrug - many thanks! Initial taste is intense smoke, but quickly smooths out into a smooth balance between roast, grains and smoke. Nice lingering aftertaste. Very nice overall, very unique.

Aroma similar to the aroma in a sheep farm (where they keep the sheep).
Smokey, heavy.

Appearance is dark, but still you can note some deep copper colour when held up to light. Heavy, thick, three finger foam. Heavy lacing in the glass.

First impression of taste is, smoked meat. Like smoked lamb. Heavy smoke, and malt. Finishes dry on the tongue.

Palate is full, but finishes a bit dry like mentioned earlier.

Overall: A heavy beer probably best suited with a heavy meal.
Smeels like bacon. Very smokey, very maple and oak notes. Malty and bready not my style

[500ml bottle, Peckhams Edinburgh] One of the true tests of beer drinking (other than lambics and imperials) are the rauchbiers  one of my friends described this one as like drinking hotdogs in a blender. That pretty sums it up  the pour is thin but deep dark brown with a thin head, and fairly high carbonation. Aromas of beechwood, smoke, malt and bacon  the flavours really strengthen on the palate with that smoky bacon crisp taste really evident  it also lasts with a very stubborn aftertaste. An acquired taste not for everybody, but still pretty drinkable [16062007]

500 ml bottle. Rated @ 18.9.2009.
Dark brown colour with a off-white head. Aroma and flavour are pretty much the same; smoked malts, caramel and some ham. Weaker than Urbock on the palate also. Thin mouthfeel. A light  version of Urbock.
16.9 ounce bottle purchased at Total wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $3.79 Very good.
(bottle) dark brown with small tan head; aroma of smoke, smoked fruit, smoked meat; balanced and clean flavour, no finish
Bottle from Alko. Cola brown colour and beige head. Very smoky and malty aroma and taste. Really nice. Nice strong body and great balance. Only Urbock version tops this.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2011 Dark brown.Big nice beige head.Taste and smell smoke everywhere but finish with some nice sweetness.Also some roasted malt and chocolate.Good palate.I enjoy a lot of drinking this beer with barbeque.

From the bottle, pours a clear dark amber with a nice off-white head.  Dirty musty earthy smokey aroma.  Taste is similar, like drinking from a cup that sat by the campfire all last night.  Relatively clean finish, the smoke does dominate any other flavors.

Pours dark brown with a slowly fading off-white head.
Nose shows smoked almonds, charcoal and smoked pork. Hard to pick up much underneath, unlike the urbock which had lots of malt. Still, quite nice.
Flavours are less smoky at first, with some soft caramel malt and mild bitterness, before that smoked almonds/ham note come back in force for a lingering finish.
Creamy carbonation could be upped a little.

Had this from a bottle, both warm and cold> I prefer it cold the smoke is too over powering. When you drink it cold if gives of a much smoother taste and quite enjoyable. Give a try because it is very different

Bottle. Impressive smoked aroma, reminds me of old farmhouses and the way clothes smell after hours of sitting by the campfire. The flavor has that smokiness too, along with some decent malts and woodiness. Makes me want to have some smoked eel.

Big meaty salty smokey nose. Pours copper/brown with a thin white head. The flavor is full and smokey, lots of salty meat, barbecue, and some light underlying caramel sweetness. Really nice smoke initially followed by a light and refreshing crisp finish. A very enjoyable beer.

Pours a light brown with a tan fluffy head.

Malt and strong smoke hit the nose and holds on. The smoke is like a campfire cooked bacon that is just a bit over done.

The medium mouthfeel was held by light carbonation. Smooth over the tongue.

Taste is balanced with beef and malt balancing the smoke. There is even a hint of sweetness at the very end. Interesting and well prepared.

I had this as part of a beer dinner and was paired with a sausage and nice a aspic. It really matched nicely and balanced any additional smoke.
From the wood at the brewery. Soft smoke and caramel nose. Lovely smoke and malt flavors with bacon and smoked salmon. Light carbonation. Wonderful, as always.

My first smoked beer and what appears to be a very well crafted one. Pours a clear light brown with medium head that subsides fast leaving good lace. Strong smokey aroma with hints of wood, leather, charred malts, and bacon also a distinct lager smell.  Flavor follows par with the aroma being slightly sweet fading into darker malt character and medium light bitterness balancing it out.  Slightly dry smokey finish medium bodied with a creamy texture. good stuff!
Bottle 1 pint strong smoked flavor spices  complex flavor with strong finish goes well with steak and grilled meats.  Also had an undertone of nuts.

This one really knocked me off my chair, literally.  I took one good whiff and thought that  I had just stepped into a smoke house. It was really woody, like bourbon barrel woody. The taste was exactly like the aroma. For a smoked beer this one is damn impressive.

50 cL bottle from the LCBO, served in a snifter. Pours clear chestnut with a frothy tan head. The head slowly fades but leaves a small amount of lace behind. On the nose, the aroma is distinctly smokey, like a campfire with notes of smoked bacon, charred malts and hints of nuts and wood. The flavour begins slightly sweet but this dissipates to a dry finish. Malts are well balanced with earthy hops. The finish is moderate-long and malty with a dry, somewhat hoppy edge. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, milky texture and average carbonation. On the whole, this is a reasonably interesting beer, but a bit too smokey for my taste. Something more subtle would probably work a bit better. 2010-08-26
First smoked beer for me. Aroma of smoked cheese and meat, meaty taste through the beer. An experience, and not necessarily a bad one.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Amber, with a moderate tan head, with a decent amount of lacing through the session. This Beer first smells, to me, like a smoked beef jerky. Some in my party were appalled, but I forced them to soldier on! Flavors were at first dominated by the smoked malt but I have to say that this dissipated greatly through the session, leaving behind flavors of jerky, oak, malt, and a feeling of campfire. I have to say I was impressed.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 1 pint 0.9oz bottle into a pint glass. The label has no freshness date but it does have the abv (5.1%) and a description of the beer on the back. 

Appearance: The body has a deep copper body with clear reddish highlights. On top it has a tall, light tan head that makes spotty and slick lacing on the glass. 

Smell: Its aroma is very smoky, like hardwood BBQ smoke, roasted malt and those imitation bacon bits that go on salads. 

Taste/Palate: There is a deep smoky wood character with grainy malt with hints of bacon. It has some mild sweetness underneath that is balanced buy some light mineral (salty metallic) notes and leafy hop bitterness. The palate has a slightly slick smooth feel with a medium body and carbonation. It finishes with a slow deep smoky fade off the tongue. 

Notes: Overall its an interesting beer but its not one that I could see myself drinking much of.

Big thanks to Jeremy for sharing this...it heals all...F U La Folie 05!

A-pours a transparent dark reddish brown, fluffy creamy yellowish head with a huge lace left behind.

S-the nose has a ton of smoke and campfire to it, smoked ham is quite strong in the nose, caramel malts there to balance that malt profile and a faint grassy hop aroma in the back.

T-tons of smokey campfire in the taste, again smoked meats, lots of smokey glazed ham, sturdy malt base and notes of malt sweetness with caramel and toffee, a light earthy and grassy hop presence in the finish.

M-smooth and creamy feel to it with a medium to light body and clean soft finish, low carbonation but enough to balance.

D-very interesting beer, quite smoked and meaty but enough balance to it that is seems to work very well together and be enjoyable.  Plus, after the onslought of acidity and vinegar of La Folie 05 there was a need for malt!
Brown pour with a good sized off white head. Malt driven smoke aroma. Flavor is meaty with plenty of caramel and smoked malt. Chewey finish with good carbonation.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2010 500mL bottle, pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of intense smoke and tobacco. Flavour follows accordingly, with potent smoke and tobacco - very peaty. Reminds me too much of an ashtray.

I am sure that this is an excellent example of what it is but I just dont think I am a fan of smoked beer.  If you like smoked beer, this is good.  Once I got past the smoke it is a very nice Marzen. Nice color as well. Serving: Tap

My first true smoke beer (But I have had BrewDog Paradox before). Didnt expect something so crazy. Looks dark brown, opaque with a nice fluffy white head. Smell is smoked ribs, barbecue, chicken.... crazy. Taste oh so smokey, similar to the smell. Its like drinking a meal. Some earthy maltiness but the smoke is overpowering. Still nice, probably better with some actual barbecue stuff, its just not really my thing.... yet.

Pours clear deep red amber with huge tanned head leaving nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of smoked salmon, chocolate, tar and roasted malts. Acidy smokey malts and hoppy flavor with floral tones. Acidy crisp and smokey on palate. Finishes tart hoppy with a great smokey aftertaste.
In bottle; very different beer (My first smoked beer). Aroma of meat/beef jerky and molasses. taste very similar; it was good but just not what I expected
aromas of smoke, cooked bacon.  dark - almost black in appearance.  bacon, smoked meat and some molasses.  more light bodied than I expected.  still wouldnt want more than one at a sitting

500ml bottle from SAQ.
Appearance : Deep mahogany with a creamy head.

Aroma : Strong smoky ham. Some notes of caramel. A bit mineral with light hints of raisins. Very rich and smooth. A bit woody also. Some fruity notes as well.

Taste : Smoked ham. A bit earthy. Notes of caramel especially on the finish. Light notes of raisins. Finish rather dry with smoke notes that stays forever.

Overall : Pretty straight forward beer but very well made. Mouthfeel is very smooth. Very unique texture. Carbonation is a bit fizzy in mouth but gets very smooth when you swallow making this a highly quaffable beer. I get more complexity as I drink it. Gets a bit flat if you take too much time to drink it.
It smells like smoked pork and malts.  Its a dark brown with a thin white head.  Its got a smoky kind of chocolate oak flavor.  Definitely a distinct flavor.

10.07.21 brown med carb white rim nice lacing. A:Smoky, campfire / smoked ham style powerful. F:Med body finish is sweet and short. O:Nicess smoked beer I had to date. Next time Im gonna try it with some nice bbq should complement well.

From a 500 ml bottle this poured a murky brown with a light brown head and glue like lacing rings.  The nose is roasted malts and smoke. Solid body and smooth mouthfeel. Lots to like here. Flavor is roasted malts and smoke again. Remarkably good tasting.
Bottle at Schmidts in German Village. Pours a clear reddish brown with a thick tan head. Hammy nose with caramel and sweet malt. Malty flavor with sweet caramel and a hammy finish.

Pours very dark with a thin white creamy head.  Smells of sweet fruity malts and a wonderful smoked wood.  The smoke is very strong and is wonderfully present.  Very wonderful smoke flavors in this beer with sweet malts coming and going.  Some sweet fruits like dates are noticeable behind the smokey malts.
sweet smoke on the nose, semilight-bodied with a small head, the carb is weak and the taste is smoke at first and after a couple more sips theres some malt as well.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a nice white head. Rich aroma with hints of burned malts, smokey notes, ham. Taste is like above with a big smoked start and finished. Just lovely.

500mL bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy dark brownish amber with a thin white head.  Aroma smells like smoke, oak and bacon.  Finish is very smoky, with malt and a bit of oak.  Flavor is intensely smoky upfront, fading a touch to let cereal, bacon, and malt through.  Moderately sweet beer, but the smoke completely dominates the whole way through.  Finish has mildly bitter malt and smoke.

Purchased at the LCBO on King Edwards in Ottawa. Poured a brown colour with some red highlights. The medium lasting head left thin bubbly lacing. Smoked hickory nose with hints of molasses. Tasted exactly what it should... smoky ! Mildly carbonated medium mouthfeel. To be enjoyed very slowly.

drank from dimpled glass mug; aroma was of wood, wet charcoal, and with hint of coffee; appearance was a soot black with milk chocolate brown head; taste was strictly smoked bacon and nothing else; medium- full mouthfeel, best part of this beer; overall gave it a 0.5 on my list, ok if you like eating your bacon from the bottom of your grill; not recommended

Rating #372, bottle from Fish and Beer  

What a dissapointment! I had really looked forward to this beer, but there was no reason to that... Its a very dark brown, but clear beer, with a tiny head.  The aroma was promising as in very smoky! Smokehouse and notes of sweet malts... Then comes the flavor - a flat märzen with two tons of smoke. Leather and careful sweetness. Too thin, airy and light. Where are the hops? Dissapointing...

Aroma: strong smokey smell
Appearance: almost opaque black with offwhite head that quickly settles to about half a finger:
Taste: not as smokey as I wouldve anticipated from the smell, but the smoke definitely is the overwhelming taste. nice light sweetness. 
Palate: carbonation is average. somewhat watery initial aftertaste and then the smoke really lingers. 

Overall good for the smoked beer style. Definitely enough smoke to know its there, but not to the point where thats all you taste.

Bière brune.  La mousse est blanche et sestompe rapidement.  Au nez, parfums de copeaux de bois sur le BBQ et notes de viande style hickory.  En bouche, même impression de fumée avec une base de malt grillé.  Le liquide est de densité moyenne et sa texture plutôt mince.  Finale longue et fortement boucanée.

This pours a dark mahogany with some ruby highlights.  The head is loose and big, but lows quickly, leaving some lacing.   Aroma is unsurprisingly smokey - smoked ham, smoked cheese.  But there is also a hint of hot wet asphalt, or railway sleepers.  There are some red fruits too, but mostly everything is overwhelmed by the smokiness.  Taste is as the aroma, but for a bittering and a malt presence.  Mouth feel is just too thin for this kind of flavour.  More alcohol would fill this out.  The finish is very one dimensional.  For a beer toted as a love it or hate it, I actually found this rather middle of the road.
The aroma is full of smoke, very plesant. The flavor is also full of smoke, but it could actually take a bit more in my opinion.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2010 Rating number 1,000. The beer pours a hazy reddish brown color with a tan head. The aroma is very smokey with some meaty notes. I also get a little dark fruit in the aroma. The flavor is smoke, roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit and ash. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. This beer was similar to the Urbock, but I feel this one was a little less smoky, but also more complex in the flavor department.

Poured a deep amber/reddish hue with a prominent slightly tan tinted head.  Left some decent lacing around the glass.  Aroma is quite pronounced; strong bacon/meaty notes intermingled with damp, charred wood.  Nice smoky flavor carries through all the way to the finish, leaving behind plenty of aromatic character in the nose with just a hint of dryness on the tongue.  Very drinkable, a pleasant experience!

Aroma is a strong smokey peat reminiscent of an Islay malt whiskey like laphroig. Taste is an in your face smokey sausage flavour that is tempered by a malty nutty roasted backbone. I also get cheese flavours from this beer. Not something that i would have all the time, but very interesting and complex beer.

50cl bottle. Easy drinkable beer despite the smokeyness and the dark brown color. Body is thin and mauthfeel is dry. Lightly hoppy and smoky nose. Palate is pleasant with a strong smoked finish. Great beer for a summer BBQ!
coffee, toast, caramel, grass, soy sauce, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, thin feel, lively, brown, clear, rocky head, minimal head,

Pours a beautiful, beautiful dark amber/maple syrup color.  Aromas of smoke and damp peat and malt.  Initial attack of slightly bitter which fades to a coffee smoky finish.  A wonderfully unique brew.

16.9 oz bottle into Sam Adams glass. I wanted to try two smoked beers back to back tonight. First was Haandbryggeriet Norwegian Wood. Now we have this, an authentic rauchbier. Well, it smells like a campfire. Pours a deep deep beautiful amber hue with a medium head that dissipates fairly quick, leaving a collar of foam and some lace. Taste is just a little sweet with no bitterness. Tastes like a smoky hefeweizen rather than a marzen. Actually, as Im reranking this after its warmed a bit, it tastes like a smoked ham. Awesome. Gotta upgrade my scores. Carbonation is medium. Texture is creamy. Has a nice spicy aftertaste. This is my first rauchbier. I like it. Ive never been a big fan of the marzen style. If they were all smoked, I would definitely drink more of them! Its not as good as the Norwegian Wood, however.

OK I was so looking forward to this but it was a bit of a letdown. Brown colour with very little head. Was quite watery. Smoky flavour was good but there was very few other flavours. A little caramel perhaps. Ill get this again as Im very much hoping this was just a bad bottle.
roasty, toast, nuts, herbs, leaves, earthy, smoke, brown, black, clear, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, thick feel, soft carbonation,
La rauchbier per eccellenza in tipico stile Bamberga. Buona e particolare, ma dopo un pò è stucchevole. A piccole dosi è ottima
Probably my favorite smoked beer.  Served from a bottle and paired with BBQ pork riblets. Yummy.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2014 Moins parfumée que la Rauch Blonde, la belle couleur nous donne une petite idée du gout.  En effet un très bon gout de malt braisé mais aussi très bien houblonnée. Le top des Rauchbier

rerate 15/11/14 belle couleur sombre et cuivrée, légère mousse blanche. Nez de malt fumé, une buche de bois fumée bien longtemps, voir arome jambon foret noir un peu gras et bien fumé. Gout de de malt fumé, boisé fumé, corps cremeux. Super savoureux

Great beer. Aroma was a ham or bacon. Very distinctive at first. Once you got through that you could pick up some beautiful malt notes.
Taste was roasting, smoked even a little chocolate. 
Enjoyable beer and quite an interesting one.

500 mL bottle.  Pours copper brown with a large, bubbly off-white head that dissolves rapidly.  Aroma is smoke!  Smoky bacon and smoke, leather, and smoke.  Flavor is also smoke.  Hints of other underlying malt flavors like caramel, but smoke mostly drowns them out.  This is just really hard for me to drink.  Seems like a well-made beer, but on the hedonistic scale, this unfortunately gets a low, low rating.

this is a beer that I can tell is made well and hits the mark of the style.  But, just not something I can drink more than a sample of.   BBQ and bacon notes abound.  wish I can give score that compensates for my palate

Merci aux gens concernés de la SAQ.  Encore un excellent choix, malgré les quelques erreurs que vous faites.  Pour celle-ci, cest un coup de maître!  Amazing beer, with a wonderful balance between an obvious but not overpowered smokyness (so special and recherché, its unbelievable!), an apt leafy hoppiness and some sweet and fruity notes.  The aroma is exquisite: its almost like serving a delicious Forêt Noire ham in a flower shop!  I love that one, even if it is a little thin and slightly watery...

bottle at Smiths - downtown Springfield MA -  I could smell the smoke as Jim poured this bottle for me.  The aroma was all campfire and a little bit of sweet brown sugar battling the smoke.  The first sip was like biting into BBQ smoked ribs with a little carbonation and sweet BBQ sauce in the finish.  I thought that this was a one trick pony until it warmed up a little bit and became a tad more sweet.  I cant wait to pair this with some BBQ or smoked salmon.  This was a very unique and memorable beer.

Aroma is pure smoke, bbq, and cigar. Pours a dark brown/black with a small tan head. Taste is exactly what i expected, rich malts combine perfectly with the smoke. I just found a new favorite camping beer. Wow, thats intense. Overall, I really enjoyed this beer, just dont drink it if you like light fruity beers.
Nice dark pour. Nose is mesquite barbecue ribs. Taste is much the same. Very smoked. Closest thing to drinking meat. Good with barbecue. Rated 1/3/2000

Bottle at home. My first smoked beer that really tastes like its smoked, and almost nothing else. Dark brown, little red substance, good head that holds ok, could have been some longer. What a weird smell, hard to place it. Smoked meat-stuff, not my kind of smell, its not bad, its just Im not used to a smell like this for a beer, some medicines inside?. First taste a bit weird refreshing, taste smoked all the way, aftertaste weird refreshing comming back, but the smoke stays.. Not my kind of beer at all. Maybe it tastes good with a barbeque or something like that. At least with some real meat-meal. The aftertaste holds and holds and holds...  I can understand people likes or even loves this beer, but I like to eat smoked meat with a knife and fork, not just swallow.

Dark brown w a small white head, way darker than expected... probably the smokiest beer Ive ever smelled, overpowers everything... smoke dominates, malts on the back end, some drying, very good if one note... medium body... very very good...

Pours a dark brown, almost black color.  Aroma is of bacon, malts, and smoke.  Flavor is also of bacon and liquid smoke.  Leaves a bacon fat finish.  As different and special as this is, theres just some things that dont go that well together.  Good try though.

Bottle. Deep copper with a light tan head. Lovely beech smoke aroma thats initially almost overwhelming with some caramel. Taste without food is simple sweetness with smoke and the illusion of pork before slightly inadequate bitterness kicks in at the end. With food - a fatty Moldovan smoked sausage specifically - the complexity of the malt becomes apparent and the beer transforms from something that wears after 200ml to something pretty special.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Rich copper color with a thick tan head. Aroma is rich and smoky with meaty hints along with some wood and campfire hints. Flavor doesnt lack these. Smoky and rich with light bacon and wood notes. Very rich and slightly dry with a light bitter aftertaste and hints of the smoke and wood. Mild carbonation and very tasty.

500ml bottle. Pours dark brown with moderate light tan head. Smoky + smoked swine aromas dominate the nose. Medium-high carbonation, medium-light mouthfeel. Not too much complexity in the flavours of this beer, however its obvious what the intentional standout characteristic is. Quite a refreshing finish. Classic Beer. Im sure it goes great with a smoked ham!

Poured deep dark ruby color with a small, tan, lacing head. Delivered as promised, a strong smoked meat aroma, with sweet hickory, roasted and bacon hints. Light body with medium carbonation. Sweet taste with a smokey aftertaste. A smooth, unique tasting special brew, almost like a meal. Enjoyed it a lot!

500ml at Toad in the Hole.  Brown and bright with medium off-white head.  Resplendent with sausage aroma.  Flavors are sweetness, gentle char, and a tiny squidge of medicine.  Lager profile pays off in the palate, where the sweet and savory can play off each other without spurious flavors.  A tad sticky when it gets down to it.
smoke,brown, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Bottle. My first Smokebeer/Rauchbier. I was told to check out this beer if i wanted something different, and that i should expect an orgy of smoke reminding one of meat. Pours a nice ruby red/ brown color, with a tan head that looks fairly creamy, but slowly fades away and becomes more of a lacing. The aroma is very smokey and reminds me alot of smoked sausage, the smoke also reminds me of the smoke you would get from a camp fire whilst grilling marshmellows. There is also a sweet malty note in the aroma. The flavour is very smokey and reminds me a whole lot of bacon and again smoked sausage, there is also some caramely, sweet malty and woody notes aswell. The body is light to medium yet creamy in the mouth, with a medium carbonation level. Overall a quite uniqe and different beer that i like alot, especially that it reminds one/ tastes so much of meat. I imagine this would be great for a BBQ. I think will check out some more Smokebeers/Rauchbier!

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2010 Nice looking beer, but as with all rauschbier, must be enjoyed with something.  The flavor gets monotonous, even after the marzen woody character shows up.  Well crafted, ages well, but its only an occasional interest to me.

500ml. Pour is dark amber with thin head. Yep, its smoked. The hubs said,  "it smells like meat". Nose is campfire all the way. Front follows the nose but palate is where it really develops. Roasted malt and some sweet, maple maybe. Really bright palate. Finish is sweet then dry, then smoky again and lingering.

Bottle from Seattle. Lite-bodied smoke beer. Nose is rich, smoked salmon or smoke cheddar cheese. Pretty, deep ruby-brown pour with lasting small bubble head. Smoke is balanced by a light, slightly refreshing body. Would be good to try next to the Urbock, which I remember as much more concentrated.

500 ml. bottle.  Pours a very dark red brown, but not black, with small bubbly gray head, nice lacing.  Aroma of brunswick stew (combination of smoked pork, corn, peas), smoked apple, wood smoke, water.  Taste is of the same aforementioned smokiness, but underlying it is a foundation of roasted malt, peat, dark chocolate, and coffee tones on the finish.  This beer is medium bodied, and its surprising how much flavor and complexity it retains given its relative thinness - yet still with a full creamy feel.  Overall really impressed, though i cant remember much difference in taste than the urbock.  I recommend with cheese and sausage.

Bottle 50 cl from Bier-Bienne (CH). Dark brown with red highlights, beige foam rather elusive and fizzing low. Nose of smoked very clear, smoked malt. Taste dry and net of smoked, less than the flavor, recollection of fires in forest, bitterness and notes of herbs and almond. The finish is long and dry with hints of recooked toffy and bitter dark chocolate.

Bottled. Clear brown and red with thin white and tan head. Aroma is smoky as hell and reminiscent of smoked salty pork and mozzarella cheese. Also, liquid smoke, hickory, camp fire. Flavor is burnt malt dry and crisp but a touch of sweetness underneath ending dry biting long. I mean real long.
The grandfather of all Rauchbiers. Not as savoury as more contemporary beers with smoked barley, but still one of the best Old Germany has to offer.

Holy smoke! Salty smoked meat aroma, has some bacon quality to it but really reminds me of a smoker minus the heavy wood presence. Not as smokey when it comes to flavour, but there is more of a dry wood quality in the flavour. Some sweet malt in there also. Pretty decent but not terribly drinkable, I do not think the 500mL size is appropriate.

Bottle 500ml. Beautiful beer. Aroma of bacon comes first, but also caramel, toffee, and butter. Flavour is sweet, with light bitterness, and good length. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Dark amber, with a thin frothy head.

Bottle.  Pours dark and foamy with a head resembling that of a root beer float.  Smells like bacon in a glass, tastes much better.  Smooth texture with a bit of bitterness and the right amount of smoke.  Very enjoyable.

Bouteille de 500 ml. Arômes de charcuteries fumées et de fruits mûrs. Robe brune aux reflets rouges, belle mousse qui tient bien et effervescence fine. Très veloutée en bouche, la texture crémeuse et douce de cette bière est vraiment intéressante. Le malt fumé est présent, mais moins que dans larôme, et est accompagné de touches de chocolat et de caramel foncé. Finale très sèche. Une bière très bien exécutée et facile à boire.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a beautiful dark amber with nice off white lace.  Wonderful and amazing wood smoke aroma.  Smells really just like apple wood bacon or a smoke house, which to me is a very good thing.  The flavor is a little more mild but still delicious, a little bit sweet with some stewed apple notes.  One of my favorites from Schlenkerla, one of my favorite breweries.
Amber of color with an off white head. An aroma of smoke, malt, weak dark fruits and weak coal. A flavor of smoke, dry, sweets, dark fruits and weak bitterness.

500ml Bottle  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Smokey from the start to the finish this was a great style rendition of the Rauch.   Dark malts with thick flavors this was chewy and rich with smoke.  This is not for the every day throw down beer you will think you ate a campfire after you drink this.
Bottled.  The marzen is my favorite of the Schlenkerla line.  Well balanced etc.

Bottle.

A - Dark copper and ruby. Pretty full, cream colored head.

S - Reminds me of smoked bacon or pork of some kind.

T - Follows the scent, smoked meat (specifically bacon or pork) is dominating flavor. There is a touch of woodiness that comes from the smoky flavor. The background/base of this is caramel/toffee and some roasted malt. This gives a slight sweetness that goes pretty well with the smokiness.

M - Medium body. Fairly creamy, with medium to low carbonation.

D - I had trouble with this. I think that the smokiness would get to be a bit much if I drank more than one or two in a sitting. However, one a day to day basis this would be drinkable.

Notes: I really liked the smoked meat aspect of this beer, but it seems like that would be a bit more subject on the person. I could see this going well in the summer with a barbecue or just some meat in general.

Appearance: Dark translucent red with a creamy cap of head.

Aroma: Ham, smokey malt, and burnt toast.

Taste: Smokey malt, burnt toast and ham.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied and modestly carbonated.

Overall:  This bottle seemed a little old. I remember this being far more smokey, to the point of thinking of it as a smoked ham soda.

Bottle.  Pours deep dark brown, almost black colour with minimal head.  Aromas of smoked fish and salty bacon.  Taste of smoke, slightly sweet malt and smoke.  Smokey flavouring continues well after the inital sip.  Tastes like Im drinking smoked herring.  Way too much smoke to enjoy the actual complexities of the beer itself.

Bottle from LCBO. Perhaps I just dont understand this style of beer. Dark amber/ brown color, with a nice and quite lasting brownish head. Aroma is smoke, smoke and smoke. It feels like there has been a big fire in the glass. The smoke comes back in the flavour, and reminds me of smoked fish. A little thin, and not my kind of beer.
Bottiglia, 50cl. Un capolavoro assoluto. Per chi ama il profumo di affumicato, è assolutamente imperdibile. Gusto persistentissimo. Eccezionale.

If youve never tried a rauchbier, just buy this one.  Buy it.  This is so tasty and such a big nose that Im betting most folks have never tried anything like it.  I dont know if this is typical of the style, but I found it amazing.

On tap at Papago.  I was waiting until I got back to Bamberg to rate this one, as this was the beer I cut my teeth on while living in Germany, but Im happy to have this on tap stateside.  Pours a leathery shade of brown with a creamy beige head that hangs around for the party. Smells of roasted pork, smoke, and caramel.  Tastes harmoniously of each with added notes of anise, wood, and malt in the flavor.  I love this beer.

50cl bottle.
deep red, smooth thick light brown head.
predominantly smoked aroma (charchoal, meat) also some malty sweetness and caramel.
Palate is fantastically soft and smooth. that smoothness somehow matches the malty sweetness really well.
flavor is malty sweet, caramel,  smoke, faint meat. ends smoked and a little sweet. Smoke really does a good job as being part of the entire flavor, not just an add-on. Very tasty smoked.

500 mL bottle pours dark brown with a two finger off white head.  The head retains quite well.  Smoky aroma with... bacon.  Yeah, bacon, and it smells great.  Taste is much of the same, go bacon beer!  However, there is a complimentary sweetness that makes it more akin to a ham steak.  Light to medium bodied with a frothy mouthfeel and a low-medium level of carbonation.  Interesting stuff and the first smoked Ive thoroughly enjoyed.  Went great with an egg sandwich!

500ml, drank in a pint glass. Forms a nice, consistent white head, which has a medium lenght. Awesome aroma, falling somewhere between smoked herring and beef jerky. Somewhat roasty as well.

Slightly creamier than expected. Pours red-to-brown. Has a slightly salty taste, predominant taste is otherwise sweet, brown-sugarish style.

Judging by the lips, it is very, very sweet beer. Otherwise, notes of smoked fish (herring, again!) are still predominant. Maybe some chocolate, not spicy at all. Smoke basically takes all the room there is - everything else is extremely subtile. 

While it is not the best smoked beer I drank -- that title belongs to the Corps Mort, from À labri de la Tempête -- it is probably the smokiest one than I ever drank. I havent drank it with any kind of food, so its not like I can suggest anything in that department. There are better smoked beers, but if you feel like drinking a smoked beer, that one is for you. (yeah, not sure that really makes any sense!)

Bottle.  Pours a dark amber brown color with a drak tan head.  Intense smoked meat aroma that reminds me of a rich summer sausage.  Flavor is also smoky but a little more subdued than the aroma.  Tastes also include a mesquite woodiness and bitter chocolate.  Very nice.

Bottle. Pours dark amber/brown with a big frothy off-white head. Aroma of smoked bacon and weak malt. Taste is weaker than the aroma suggest, the smoke is more like a thin layer above a good malty base and just make this beer better in my opinion, aftertaste lingers, first smokey character, before the hops finishes off. Great beer.
In Bamberg a while back. Great beef jerky like aroma. Awesome dark color. Definitely can taste the smoke. Loved it. Brought back a few bottles with me.

Bottle from Winking Lizard, poured into dimpled mug. Definitely a new experience for me. The appearance is gorgeous: deep ruby colored with a quickly dissipating finger and a half of beige head. The intensely smoky but still noticeably sweet aroma was a little daunting at first, but grew on me towards the end of my glass. The taste is similar to the aroma; it tastes a bit like a smoked meat with a glaze on it, though it still manages to finish with a slightly bitter woodiness. The palate was thin and a little watery with potent carbonation. Ill have to explore this type of beer more.

Dark red colored, with medium white head. The aroma is strong smoked, roasty and malty. Some hops but difficult to perceive because smoke is dominating. Taste doesnt go too much far from aroma, with a nice balanced sweetness and bitterness. Medium body, dry in the end. I really enjoy smoked beers, and this one is one of my favourite. Strong char.

500 ml bottle. Pours chestnut with a big, fluffy, off-white, long lasting head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is rich smoked (lox) malt with hints of piny hops. Medium, smooth body. The flavor is initially a sweet smoky  malt, brown sugar balanced by earthy, piny hops. Long lasting, balanced finish. Great beer.

Dark brown with a big fluffy white head, lacing.
Aroma is full of smoked meat and some sweet malts. Honey?
F: Smoky! Citric notes and malts.
M: Average. 
T: I like this one, but then I am also partial to really smoky whiskies.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2010 Bottle.  Dark brown with a big fluffy white head.  Aroma is rich bacony smokiness.  The flavor is initially a big hit of rich meaty smoke, with a bitter, woody finish.  Theres a lot of subtlety to this stuff considering how dominated it is by the smoke.

Pours a amber brown. Nice fluffy beige head that goes to a nice lacing. Aroma is of raw bacon with hints of citrus and sweet. Smooth smoke flavor with a bit of hop. Medium carbonation. A hint of pepper and dryness on the finish.Overall the flavor is like bacon, ham, or smoked fish. Maybe jerky. It doesnt really taste  beer. It was a very nice experience.

Bevuta a Bamberga, dove mi ero recato, forse, solo per questa birra.
Dal colore bruno, con la schiuma color biscotto, abbondante, allaspetto davvero intrigante, lolfatto e fortemente affumicato, così come il gusto, va saputa apprezzare, di non facile beva, se non accompagnata dal giusto cibo, per i miei gusti mai da bere sola. Il corpo è robusto, quasi liscio. Note più delicate solo nel finale.

Bottle. A clear, effervescent ruby beer with a large, creamy beige head leaving a loose, soapy lacing. Smokey, latakia tobacco, lapsang souchong tea aromas. Meaty, bacon flavours combine with more notes of lapsang souchong and a bit of roasted malt bitterness on the tongue. Quite a light body. Dry through medium to full - though non-aggressive - carbonation and the smokey character. Finishes with even more of the lapsang souchong as an aftertaste.

A classic smoke beer from Bamberg in Germany. Poured from bottle into a Budvar stein glass. No German stein glass so best equivilant I guess. Poured slowly at a 35degree angle. Very little head. Simmers out to the end of the glass. On aroma the smoke instantly hits you - ddint expect that one! The roasted malts are superb and the hop factor is strong. I enjoy the balance even if there is a slight off edge to the carbonation feel. 

I can sense smoke; oak, caramel, leather, coffee and a dash of licorish. I enjoy this and will partner it with my duck.

16.9 oz bottle from Spirits RB. Poured a super dark Ruby brown with an average sized bubbly light beige head. Aroma of mesquite smoke, earthy fire pit, sweet malts. The body is on the thin side with bubbly carbonation and a lingering Smokey sweet aftertaste. Flavor has lots of sweet malts, caramel, earth, tree bark and lots of smoked wood. Really nice stuff, I love the smokey sweet combo.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 Not everyone likes rauchbiers, but they are just fine by me.  I am glad that this brew is available at many good bottle shops at a reasonable price, so thank you for that, Aecht Schlenkerla.  I like the old gothic script on the label, altho I can do without the bogus wax seal.  Malty, sweet aroma.with plenty of burning wood chips.  Flavor of smoked pork sausage and trim hops.  This is a very nice mix of malty sweetness and wood smoke.  This does not make me think that someone had dumped an ashtray into the beer, as one friend once said, but of a crackling fire in an old stone fireplace, and this is the perfect German brew to imbibe while seated nearby.

15.01.2010, 0,5l Bottle from vinmonopolet.no. Dark brown colour with off-white head. Aromaisdominated by smoked flavours. The beer smells like a campfire. After a while the maltyness stepsforward and there is more to thisbeer than the smoke. Nice flavours with a very special mixture og malt, bitterness and a lot of smoke!

Aromas are very smoky! I like it a lot. Nice and dark malts compliment the fireplace scent. Some hops in there plus esters add fruitiness. 
Lovely flavours also, malt comes out a bit more. Chocolate spiciness and some hoppy finish.

On draught at De Paas, Den Haag. Pours a clear amber red color. Aroma is quite extreme, immediately made me think of bacon. Smoke and spices. Flavor is more of the same, wood, smoke, spices and still that bacon aroma lingering around. I think you either like it or hate it. I definitely like this one. Has a bitter spicy finish.

Dark brown color, medium tan head; aroma mainly of smoke with some sweet maltiness in the background; medium body, low carbonation; flavor of smoke based on a sweet maltiness with slightly some hops in the finish. If Urbock was an full-fledged smoked-ham-in-a-bottle type of beer this is more like a dunkel with a smokey twist - not as extreme, but nearly as good.

This is a cult classic of a beer if Ive ever heard one. Ive heard everything now from oh my god this beer is the shit to oh my god this tastes like a stanky dump! I guess I love the taste of dump as much as the next guy- so here we go.  Pour: automatic 5. Gorgeous dark hued brown poured into a weizen glass with a magnanimous beige head. The aroma immediately fills the room with its rude smoky nature- I like it so far.  As I go in for the first actual sniff, the smoke gets ruder and ruder: its like charred meat, smoked salmon, and massively toasty smoked dark-roast barley malts. Nothing Ive sniffed is quite like this. The flavor is simply orgasmic- anyone who cant throw massive amounts of this glorious liquid back is kidding themselves (or is a bitch). Massive smoked peaty barley grains, hickory, oak, and tons of smoked salmon. Malt sweetness is powerful while the smoky nature adds an amazing dimension of complexity. It tricks my brain into thinking its a meal. The palate is rich, thick, full, and delightful with perfect effervescence and a dry, smokey finish.  Another cult follower I suppose

Bottle 0.5l. Very thin head. Dark hazelnutbrown color. Smells like smoked cheese or ham (luckily doesnt taste like it). Medium to strong carbonation. Taste changes very quickly from sweet to bitter and it has a slowly fading smoky bitter aftertaste. Not really my favorite, but one has to try it once at least.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2014 Bottle 50 cl. Very special beer for the one who does not know much about this style ... The smell is very intensive as the smoked taste is less present. Good beer anyway, hops and yeast can not be detected.

Rerated : on of my favorit beer to drink usually : pures smoked beer, very clean, long smoked aftertaste, very Bamberg like.
Huge smoky aroma and taste. Cured meats is all I could think of. Like liquid ham. Very unique beer, second time tasting it and I find the second time more enjoyable as I believe it is fresher.
Brownish in appearance.  Smokey goodness in the aroma.  Smokey-bacon flavour.  Very smooth on the palate.  Lovely.

Bottle thanks to matt7215. Thanks Matt! Pours an odd almost transparent dark brown. The head is small and tan. The aroma has smoke, but not a ton. The malt profile shows through in the aroma nicely. The flavor is very nicely balanced. Earth, sausage, hay, and chocolate. Very very nice. Thanks again Matt!

Bottle. Thanks to hobbersr! Pours pale brown, almost cola brown, but thinner, lighter. Nose is mild but rich smoke, no hops, no fruit, no grain, just smoke. Not as hung-meat-like as other smoked beers Ive had. Palate is balanced, between sweet and savory. Plenty of bacon and ham hock, plus campfire, dark fruit, and sweet malt. A very well-balanced Rauchbier, but maybe a touch watery.
Bottle, 500ml. Pours almost pure black with a decent light brown head. Smells of bacon, tastes like bacon. Great combination, period.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a creamy beige head.   Huge gorgeous campfire smoke.  Cleanest most pure smoke Ive smelled on a beer.  Smooth, creamy, and malty with a nice smoke coming through over light caramel.  Finishes up with even more gorgeous smoke that lingers around.  The smoke in here is amazing.  Doesnt overpower, but its always present and infuses all aspects of the beer.

Bottle from Mr Lawrences wine merchants. Pours brown with an off-white head. Aromas of smoked bacon, roasted malts, dark fruits, some chocolate.
 Flavours of wood, smoked salmon, raisins, quite fruity. Very well balanced.
  Good smokey/malty finish.
Pours medium hazy brown with medium head. Aroma is smoked ham with some tar. Flavor is very smoky with some malts. Very nice when the moment is right.

Pours an amber brown with a decent sized, quickly fading head. The aroma is dominated by smoked ham bone with sweet undertones. The mouth is sweet, biscuity malt with intense smokiness throughout. Not bad.
This was one of my first experiences with a smoke beer, and I have to say it complimented my steak really well...

Bottle from LCBO.  Pours deep brown in colour, large off white head, which leaves tonnes of lacing.  Aroma of smoked salmon, one of the most unique beers Ive ever had.  Flavour is similar, a little more muted that the aroma, but still, like drinking smoked salmon.

Wow, this is such an interesting beer, not just for the smoked taste but because almost immediately you know whether you will enjoy smoked beers or not, just from the first sip of this one. I dunno, can see this going well with german food, especially sausages, bratwurst, knockwurst, etc. I still dont think i could have more than one at a time, but its good, sort of smoked porter taste, just a little heavier.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2010 lct-mhgy, lasting creamy head, ^lace, creamy medium body, medium carbonation.

beechwood smoke chclt-malt yeasty aroma.

smoky fresh-hop T1, ^marzen smoked-malt T2, §ashy tobacco-hop T3, bitter-noble-hops Tf.

Pours a deep chestnut brown into the glass, with a generous eggshell-tan head that reduces to a thin cap, leaving medium-soapy lace.  The nose is very much of smoked peat, jerk spices, Slim-Jims and bacon.  The flavors are reminiscent of their Urbock, with bacon, peat, smoked processed beef sticks, malt, dry-spice pork rub, with lots of smoke to go around.  Very nice.  The mouthfeel is perfectly medium-round, with well-integrated subtle carbonation, and a nice body with exquisite effervescence (i.e. aftereffects, residual aftertaste, etc.).  This is almost as nice as the Urbock, lacking slightly in complexities of the big brother.  I just love this take on the Märzen, Urbock and Weizen styles by Brauerel Heller brewers.  They are a class act, and produce superb smokebiers.  Prost!

50cl bottle. Pours dark brown with a minimal tan head. The aroma was very smokey. The taste was like drinking the gravey from a sausage fry up. The palate was full bodied with a very long smokey/meaty finish. Over all not my kind of beer. I will not be trying this style again, but I supose looked at for the style this must be near the top.
Rich dark beer that smells and tastes of smoked bacon...there is no greater combination of flavors on this planet than bacon and a fine beer.  This is the absolute pinnacle of human achievement.

Poured an orangish color - white head and decent lacing.  Aroma is smoke - on first whiff this smelled like my clothes the morning after a good campfire.  I also got quite a scent of meat (smoked bacon).  The taste is exactly what I expected - smoked bacon.  I actually really liked this Smoked Brew... Id pick this up again to share with friends.

Draft on tap at the Bavarian Lodge (Lisle, IL). Pours a very dark brown, a bit reddish around the edges, but quite translucent, a decent offwhite head that is cakey, laces light. Aromas are good smoked malts, meaty bacon and ham, a touch of ash and brown sugar, caramel. Very smoked dominant. Initial is fairly light bodied, giving good smoked malts, meaty ham, caramel and a touch of brown sugar. Sticks a light sweetness, smoked sticks moderately to the palate. Not too cloying overall, goes down quite nicely. As a fan of smoked beers, I like this and it is quite drinkable. Light bitterness on the backend, a touch of florals, run over with campfire, ham, and a touch of ash with some light caramel, toffee, and toast, largely bready with a touch of spiciness. I liked this.

I tried to base my rating on the quality of the beer when regarded as a smoke beer.  But this really isnt my thing.  It was my first and might be my last.  Aroma is like a burning log in a fireplace with malt.  It pours a rather viscous blackish liquor.  Taste is intense smoke flavour with malt.  This really isnt my bag but as a "smoked" beer this pretty much fills the bill.
a dark brown. odd head, thinnish. a lot of smoke on the nose, bacon and some sweet lime. taste is light and malty, gently balanced with some bitter smoke. a light body with a full taste. very nice.
Pours dark brown color with tan head. Aroma of smoked meat. Mildly sweet flavor with a good amount of smokiness but not overpowering. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

A really nice smoke beer.  Definitely old world style quality.  The nose is just superb.  The flavor is rich yet not overdone.   Very smooth finish.  Nice lingering smokiness accompanies you as you imbibe this beauty.  Wonderful.

Extravagant, german old-style label on the 0.5 l bottle.
Meanwhile pouring, a nice,  stiff, beige-coloured, head grows, which remains long.
Colours deep brown/mahogany, bubbleing is low-key.
The smell is smoky, mixed with some malty sweetness.
Taste is mild, the flavour is smoky, special, its body is pretty good, too.
Finish is light hoppy, dry and remains long.
A real special one, liked it!

[bottle]
Potent smoked bacon aroma with some detectable noble hops. Clear dark garnet under a thin, bubbly off-white. Meaty smoke flavour is strong and in your face at first. Once the palate recalibrates itself there is plenty of sweet base malt flavour as well as a smidgen of noble hops. Moderately salty smoke transcends, though. Medium body, moderate carbonation, moderate bitterness balances the sweetness well.

Bottle. Thanks to Miver. Dark brown body with medium tan head.  Light smokey/bacon aroma.  Flavor is well balanced between malts and smokiness, hints of bacon... medium body... great Rauchbier as you can taste the complexity, not an overwhelming smoke flavor like some are

21-NOV-2009, bottle @Morten.
Amber, beige lasting head.
Smokey nose. Not too much like the Weizen.
Creamy, medium carbonation. Somewhat like belgian dubbel with smoke. OK beer.

The true bacon of beer. This has cured pork all around. There is also a bit of sardine or smoked herring going on in all the right ways. Really makes you want to fire up the grill and char some proteins. Color is slightly darker than most Marzens. the taste is heavy on the smoke, but the body is relatively light. Kind of throws you. Dont drink it super cold. Definitely improves as it warms a bit. The aftertaste is everything you love about a campfire and goes on forever. Really quite amazing.

Amazing smoky, slow-roasted meat aroma (pulled pork, smoked sausage). Mild, dark lager malt, but totally overshadowed. Appetizing, incredible aroma. Char-grilled fireplace.

Glassy red-brown. Thick, bu tlight does pass through. Head disappears fast. Not bud but not amazing.

Initially, its a dark lager on the front of the tongue, but the smoky flavor sits on the tongue long into the aftertaste. That aftertaste is intense and improves with warmth.

Feels smooth and milky; appropriate for style. More of a smoky black lager than a true Märzen to my taste. Tastes good, smells amazing.
Pours deep ruby brown with a two finger dense head. Big smoky aroma with a lovely depth. Earthy and warm, with briny smokiness that just is a perfect autumn accompaniment.

Bottle. Poured brown in color with a reddish hue. Huge fluffy tan head  that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is very meaty, bacon, with some campfire smoke. Tastes is of pretty vibrant with smoke, bacon, wood.  No other brewery for me has taken the rauchbier to quite this level. This is possibly my new favorite style.  Very drinkable and fantastic.

Appearance was very dark maroon with a thin white head and great lacing.
Smell was modern ashtray and oak.
Taste was subtle smoke, much more subtle than the bottled version (which is difficult to finish).
Much more drinkable than the bottled version, this one is fairly complex and definitely unique.  If youre going to try a rauchbier, it has to be one from Bamberg.

Who could ever imagine a beer that smells like a bon fire and raw bacon, yet tastes smooth like a well smoked pork chop?
The aroma is strong but the beer is very easy to drink. If I couldnt smell it, I would place it as a rich, malty schwartz. 
Interesting beer to say the least.

like those little christmas hormel sausage gift packs, body is there, but the smell is so overpowering that it is hard to determine any flavor outside of the smokiness. As compared to the other Aecht smoked rauchbier Ive had (that being a dunkel), this is lighter and less heavy. Bottle from Total Wine and More, Naples, florida.
Pours a dark rubyish brown with small tan head.  Big smoky aroma, almost baconish.  Taste is even smokier.  Not a session beer but pretty nice.

Bottle.  Pours a deep ruby-brown color with an inch and a half thick, rock off-white head that receded to a thin layer and left some spotty lacing.  Aroma of sweet brown sugar, honey ham, charred wood, peat, and some earthy leather.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry with some hints of honey ham leads into a smoky charred wood flavor with some hints of sweet brown sugar and undertones of leather that linger into a moderately dry, smoky finish.  Light carbonation and smooth, slick mouth feel.  Overall, a rather simple, yet enjoyable smoked beer that gives you everything it advertises.  Good stuff.

Bottle. It was indeed thinner than expected, but not in a bad way. Aroma was barbeque-ish, like bacon cooked over an open flame, with a slightly sweet undertone. Full smokey taste on front and back of mouth. This was my first rauchbier and I look forward to the next.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bottle. Nice very dark reddish pour with a pillowy white head. All meaty, salty,  bacon smoke aromas. Taste is nice smokey especially in the return after the first swallow. The mouthfeel is light, crisp, super drinkable. Delicious.

2009-02-12, bottle, Göteborg
Not soo good!
Smokey without a body!
Have a caracter- so there is the rating!

Reddish brown beer with a small head that leaves some lace. Lots of smoked ham and some hops in the scent. The smoked ham dominates the taste aswell, but its also got some slightly sweet malts, and a little coffee.

A good beer. It pours very dark with almost no head. The aroma is heavy with woodsmoke and reminds me of bacon. The palate and mouthfeel of the beer were thinner than I had expected, but not unpleasant.

Bottle from Village Beer Merchant. Pours a deep dark nut brown with a reddish tint. Large fluffy off-white head. Aroma is campfire, wood, with some burnt malt and hops. Flavor isnt as smokey as the aroma but definately there. Caramel malts, medium bodied. Smooth, very easy drinking. Good Smoked.
Smoked pork and campfire aroma. Garnet brown, clear pour with a thin head. Tastes of smoke and charred wood, with a cola finish. Much better than the weizen rauchbier.

Draft at Churchkey. Pours a very dark brown. No head, minimal lacing. Oily surface. Smell is pure smoke. Smells like charcoal plus good pork bbq. Front is puuure smoked bacon. Back doesnt taste much different than the front. Very nice mouthfeel, not thick, but substantial. Overall really good if you can get it and love pork.

bottle- a beer that reminded me immediately of Scout Camp....lovely campire mornings. Dark brown tea color, 1/2 finger head, the aroma was of smokehouse and charred leather with a sweet hickory smoke texture that wasnt as bitter or acrid as Id expected. My first rauchbier but I think it may grow on me....

Dark Brown pour, Aroma is smokey but not acrid or unpleasant like some.  Malt and brown sugar also comes through.  Flavor is caramel malt, some wood, smoke, peat.  Nicely balanced, not a favorite style of mine but this is really nice.  The most drinkable one Ive come across that still manages to impart that nice peaty smokiness.

Tasted this one at the Bottle Shop in Idar-Oberstein. Nice clear amber color with a cream head. Medium carbonation. Smell and taste were HUGE on smoke which took over the beer but not offensively. Also got notes of malt and brown sugar but the smoke was all you can think of. For this style of beer this is exactly what youd want. Would I drink more than half this beer in one sitting? No. But its true to style therefore I had to rate it high.

500 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear dark amber color with a medium large creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of strong smoke and peat as well as earthy notes and caramel. Taste is dry smoked wood and peat, caramel and a lightly hoppy finish. Smooth, medium bodied.

0.5 L bottle. Relatively transparent despite its very dark coppery colour. Thick light beige head reminiscent of shaving foam (a compliment). Strong smoked peat scent with a dash of hops behind. Complex taste with a strong malty basis, the smoked note and nice fruitiness. Uncompromising smokey/spicy aftertaste. Velvety body.

Sample @ Coles German Tasting 2009. Smoked meats, cedar chips over power some malts in the the aroma. Taste is initially smoked meats, caramel maliness that cuts into the smoke factor & leave a nice pleasnt lighter smoke flavor on your palate. Nice beer

Lucky enough to have drunk this in the Schlenkerla Tavern in Bamberg.  Awesome heavyweight of a beer with smoky bacon crisps coming at you before the beer reaches the table.  Takes a couple of mouthfulls before the smoke clears and lets what is quiet and light and refreshing beer shine through.  One of the worlds great beers

Bottled.. Pours a chestnut brown with a thin white head that fades away... Aroma is beef jerky and doggie treats... Flavor I guess is well, smokey. Not overpowering in any way and very pleasant. Medium carbonation and thin to medium body.  This beer would go great with some bacon and eggs.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2012 Re-rate. My son Luke (age 5) says "it smells like hot dogs." Great. Much more smoky than I remember; moderate-high campfire and savory meats, like bratwurst.  Appearance is mostly clear cola brown with bubbly tan head. The flavor matches the nose. This beer has a real softness and ease, even with its strong flavors. Glad to have this available regularly; always a real treat with breakfast or in autumn.

First off, I should say that I really dig this bottle. Nifty old-school medicine bottle look that I imagine in a doctors cabinet 100 years ago. Heavy too, even after emptied (but what do  the Germans make thats not meant to last a lifetime?). Pours a deep brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is indeed of smoke; it dominates, like too much artificial smoke meat seasoning. Flavor is again with the liquid smoke meat marinade, and it tricks the mind into perceiving it as meat flavor. Gets a little less offensive after a few sips. Thick, chewy mouthfeel, bubbly finish. One things for sure: There is no lack of flavor here. Its just not my kind of flavor. I love meat, and I love big ass beers, but when you combine the two it just doesnt work for me for some reason. This is one rare instance when Id actually prefer less flavor - the woodchip/smoke/beef jerky flavor specifically. I wish I could like this more but I just cant. Ill still finish the bottle though; its better than no beer at all, so no-harm no-foul. Overall, fair. My apologies to the other RBian who recommended this for me :(

This is how to make a smoked. Not too over the top, with nice woody and ham tones on the nose and palate. Easy drinking and very enjoyable. Pours a beautiful dark amber red too with good head retention. All in all very goo.
50cl bottle.  Dark amber brown pour with a thin brown head.  Aroma of scotch and smoke.  Thin taste of bacon and campfire with a dry finish.  Appreciate it, but not for me.
50cl bottle. Lots of smoke and a little smoked meat aroma, pours with a thick head. Very enjoyable, one of my favourites beers.
Pours brown with a large light brown head, Aroma is smoke, and light caramel. Flavour is smoke, caramel and bacon notes.

Lots of smoke on the nose, and a lot of wood.  Some bacon/meaty aroma in there as well.  Slight caramel sweetness follows.  The appearance is a very attractive ruby red/brown, clear, carbonation bubbles, thick off white head.  The flavor is smoke, wood, smoked meats, tobacco, thinner than expected.  The mouthfeel has an unexpectedly thin quality.  The finish is campfire smoke, slight resiny hops.  Enjoyable overall.
Poured dark reddish brown, CO2,  roasted malts, wood, little tobacco, but the well done bacon flavors prevail.  Nice, but strange.
The best beer i have ever taste. My favorite beer of all time.500 ml bottle. Taste is of dark malts smoked flavors, and ends again with bacon.

Pours a reddish brown with thick white head. Not very frothy. The aroma is of smoke and tar. Some hops coming through. The taste is wonderful and strong. A start of smokiness finished off by a slight coffee-malt flavor. The body is medium-full. What a terrific beer!

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2015 (bottled many times . draught @ Man of Kent, Rochester recently)  the nose is a mind-fuck its smoked deli meat intertwined with burnt fall leaves ..Chunks of smoky woodiness in a protuberant attack on your nose ..but its excellent as I like smoked texture ; A burnt ruby colour with sandy khaki head .  Insane smoke notes . woody , apple-wood cheese ,smoked pork in liquid format and a salty dry long finish .  A bad ass smoked beer that takes no backwood steps in intensity  .

A fantastic cherry red hue with a nice pearl head. Slightly frothy and lacy. Smokey & caramel malts. Hard to place though reminds me of the tonic I used to have as a kid. The smokey flavoring hits you right up front, followed nicely with a mild sweetness that trails behind. I taste a nice maple flavor and balanced with the hops that give it zip. The more I drink this beer the more I like it. Not something for everyday but still bloddy good.

has a smokey finish. not too thick for such a dark beer. pretty malty but not really that sweet. has a large frothy head. unique for a marzen but tastes really great. couldnt drink too much of it though. i dont think the maltiness quite matches the carbonation. it should be a little thicker.

Bottle from BevMo in Mountain View.  Pours a dark brown color with a small but lasting creamy off-white head and good lacing.  Aroma is lots of smoke, hickory-smoked bacon, ham, and roast.  Reminds me of a BBQ in a good way.  Flavor is smoked ham on rye, roasted malt, caramel, some plum and fig, tobacco.  Just like a ham sandwich.  They really call this a marzen?  Palate is smooth with medium body and lingering smoke.  A novelty for sure, but overall I like it.

Not just fer plain guzzlin, this is uptown all the way! .. . pours a dark barrel brown .. . fantastic head! and lacing is like a doily factory parade.. . refined with such a punch of sweet delicious smoke! god, fuck me, its good... i love smoked beers and this s, h, a , r, p!! i gotta visit that bamburg! ..

500 ml bottle.Pours brown/red with a small dissipating off white head.Aroma of smoked ham ,burnt wood.Flavor is the same burnt wood ,smoky ham with some nice sweet malt.Medium body.Really interesting and very nice.

Bottle thanks to mike for sharing. Brown ale with tan head. Smells like bacon,. Taste is of dark malts smoked flavors, and ends again with bacon would love to see a bbq with as part of the main marinade. Definitely a different than normal beer.

My new love for Islay Single Malts should influence my love for this beer. Well, the smoke her is nothing like the peat bombs that I crave - a different beast all together. Deep chestnut brown, light tan head is thin, nice ropy lacing. The aroma is a lot of smoke. Soooo much smoke.. but this time, unlike years ago, I can go beyond and see what else this beer has to offer. Burning logs that have had a bucket of water tossed on them, lots of salt.. in fact this beer is very beef jerky. Damn! That is it! There is also an underlying fruit that may be plum? So much salt - that is really making this beer awesome for me. The flavour is immediately NOT smoke. Serious. Plums I think hit first or something similar... have I just killed my taste buds? The smoke is much more mellow on the taste. My breath, however, will tell a different story. A story that includes 3 packs of cigarettes. Notable hops hit early on as well. A milder version of liquid smoke makes an appearance finally, solid bitterness... very solid - more than I expected. Lots of malts now, almost a dull chocolate but Im drunk so who really knows what Im tasting. More fruit that is a bit different now, ash, tobacco, tons of roasted malts.. what else? kitchen sink. Light medium bodied, a bit thin on a couple of sips but other than that its smooth and soft with some lingering bitterness shadow and what Im assuming is a months worth of going to a Blues bar of smoke in my mouth. My dump tomorrow will be of epic proportion. Maybe Ill just shit out a pack of Players. Very good beer. So much beyond that overwhelming smoke aroma. A real beer exists under that blanket. I could drink a ton of this in one sitting but Id be divorced by mid morning at the latest. I love this beer.
Bottle. Smoked wood and tar in aroma. Unclear lightbrown colour with beige head. Smoked malt and nuts in flavour with nice bitterness. This must be a sailor beer.
poured brown with a small tan head aroma was nice and smokey flavor was smoke but the aftertaste was like i had a ashtray in my mouth and it wouldnt go away. definetly not my kinda smoked beer...
bevuta brewpub.buona persistenza della schiuma, buono olfatto pieno di sentori di affumicatura e malto.al gusto belle note di tabacco e carammello ben bilanciate con lalcol.spezie varie.

Bottle. Poured a dark coppery brown with a fluffy tan head and lotsa lacing. Nose is smoky and malty and has a distinctive smell of smoked bacon. This is the first rauchbier I have tried so I wasnt too sure what to expect and while I was surprised by the aroma it was a pleasant surprise. Flavour is still smoky but not so meaty, malt blends harmoniously with notes of caramel, tobacco and spice. The smokiness is just about perfect, present but not overpowering. A really good beer, I have just been converted.

Aaaah rating 500.. Here goes...
~Pours a dark brown with creamy tan head. Nice lacing 
~Scent of smoked ham and malts, and woodsy tobacco.
~Smoked malty wood flavor. Malts are toasty. Malts and smoke compliment each other. Neither is very aggressive. Light hops.
~Light bodied, very smooth. Smokey sweet malt finish.
~This is a damn good brew. Wasnt real sure what to expect. It could stand to be a bit thicker. I bet this is excellent straight from the cask. I love the smoked malt and wood flavor. I wish it had a bit more ooompf, but then it might be overkill. Excellent brew. Glad It is easy to find around here. Right on the mark for its style. This is a mans brew that should be eaten with red meat!

1pt 0.9oz bottle.  Pours nice brown color with a very soft foamy head that lasts forever.  Smells of camfired cooked bacon.  Tastes of smoked pork, corn malt, hardwood, and hops.  Nice lacing.  Nice long aftertaste.  Excellent brew.
Deep brown with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of smoked meat, wood, malt and earth. Taste is of firewood, smoke and ash.
Pours red-brown with nice head, which disappears quickly. Marked smell of campfire. Smokey flavor, meaty, malty. I like it.
Dark reddish brown with a foamy white head. Aroma is very smoked. Flavor is dominated of smoke, roasted malt and hops. Good balance of the malt and smoke in the finish.

A must try. As for the age-old saying "smells like a campfire and tastes like bacon," this is pretty dead on. The marzen aspect gives it a nice sweet malty quality too and overall it kind of reminds me of smoked ribs/pork. Yummy!

This is the second Rauchbier Ive tasted, and the first one was NOTHING compared to this one! At first, when opening the bottle, even my wife standing a few feet from me, could sense the smell of SMOKE, SMOKE, and SMOKED bacon, meat, and wood... The aroma is just OUT of this WORLD! Im close to the end of this pint, and I am still completely LYRICAL about the aroma... The Appearance is nice, (my bottle had too much of a head) In the glass it looks really nice, a dark copper... The flavor is smokey smokey smokey... Very nice! If you like pepperoni sausage, or smoked salami... As others have stated, VERY MEATY - nearly leaves a taste of smoked sausage in your mouth!  Palate is surprisingly thin for a beer with such an amazing amount of flavor, but nice, this palate proves the beers origin as a "smoked lager" - not necessarily a bad thing! My overall impression is: WOW! If you like smoked sausages, or cigars... Taste this!

Brewed in Germany...... Pours a dark ruby color with a small dissipating white head. Aroma of smoke, bacon strips, wood and bologna. Taste is much of the same !! The mouthfeel is thin, balanced with some mild carbonation and very easy to drink. Once again i am not a huge fan of this style, but i must confess this is better then i thought. Its by far my second favorite smoke beer !!!!
Way too smokey for my taste. Near overpowering.  If you wonder what fire tastes like, this is it.  The only other flavour there is nuts, but its very subtle.

500ml bottle. black in colour with a nice even crisp off white head. Wonderful aroma of smoked almonds that fills the nose  - very nice. First smoked beer and it tastes as good as it smells with a strong smoky burnt flavoured bitterness that lingers in the mouth. Not a beer that you would drink every day.

oh hell yes.  dark ruby in the light, black in the glass with a tall creamy white head.  campfire aroma, instantly nostalgic with happy thoughts.  Heavy smoked alder charcoal, singular but awesome.  smoky tasty lingering and spot on.
Dark brown in color decent beige colored head.  The smell is heavy smoke, wood, bbq, malts, smells like a meal.  Taste cannot quite compete, malts, wood, smokey, ash tray.

Bottle. This is the only smoked beer I have tasted so I cant really compare it to any others. Very interesting though I cant decide if I like it or not. I am overwhelmed by the smoke flavor. I was really impressed at first but by the end I found it tough to finish the bottle. It is definitely worth trying once though.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a thin beige head, over a clear reddish brown black body (SRM 35).....nose is primarily smoke, with a bit of grilled meat, and sweet malts.....taste initially is toffee, then balanced by smoke and then mild hop bitterness....mouth feel is relatively light, carbonation low. Smoked beers are interestingly different from each other. This one is a campfire in a glass.

500cl. First Rauchbier, the smoky smell is phenomenal, Id rate the aroma an 11 if I could. Aroma is smoked meat, slightly woody, and a bit of alcohol. EXTREMELY aromatic. Pours out dark, orangy red when held up to light. Moderate to large head which disappears quickly. Very smooth, the smoky flavour is thick and builds with each sip, dont be fooled if the smokiness doesnt blow you away in the first mouthful. Interesting beer, I am drinking it slightly too warm and wish I let it cool down a little longer. Overall, quite good.
Pours clear brown with a small off white head. Aroma is smoky. Flavor is smoke and smoked meat. If you like smoked beer this is for you.

Pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  Beautiful sweet, smoky aroma.  Reminiscent of smoked almonds.  Fairly light mouthfeel with heavy, meaty notes mid palate and definite smoke.  A little like drinking a smokehouse and I mean that in a good way.  Makes me think of real good bacon.  Great Rauchbier but you better like smoke.

From Skjold Burne, Aarhus, DK.
Bottled.
Brown with small head. Aroma of smoke and some malt. Flavor is sausage and tar.
Dark amber and obviously smokey in scent and flavor.  The smoke is in fact a bit overwhelming, masking the rest of the beer which is very thin and unassertive (other than the smoke).

Pours with a nice, dark amber/reddish colour and a decent head.  Right away both the aroma and taste exude the smokiness, and the taste might be almost too smoky.  I liked this one, perhaps only for the novelty value but Im not sure if Id drink many more of these.

Poured from a 1 pint, 0.9 oz bottle into a lager glass. Even before I finished poured I was in love with the aroma of smoky bacon which just dominated. The appearance was a reddish brown with a fluffy head after a vigourous pour. Taste followed just as the smell, plenty of smoke and bacon. Great beer for the style. However, if you dont like smoky beers, this one will turn you off.
Nice dark brown color  with light brown foam. Interesting strong taste and great smoke aroma too. One of the best choices when you wanna have a smoked beer.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2012 500 ml bottle. From Bamberg, Germany. Thanks Tom!
Dark copper colour with small light tan head.
Smoke, tar and malt in aroma. Balanced. Smoke, smoked ham, tar and malt in balanced and enjoyable flavour. Nice Rauchbier.

Pours dark brown with large light beige mostly lasting head. Smoked meat in nose, not in a direct bad way though, it rather makes it a bit interesting to take a sip. Clean smokiness dominates flavor. Nice bitter aftertaste. The beer is interesting at first but after a while all I think of is bacon beer.

0.5L bottle, small stable off white head, clear deep brown colour which looks like it is a little opque. aroma of smoked dried meat (bilantong?) and charred wood with hints of vanila and vinous aroma. Flavours of bacon and caramel with charred wood like bitterness, lingering smokey and fruity aftertaste.
Intrguing beer.

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Pours dark brown with a disapeing tan head.
Smells and tastes of smoke and sausage
Much like its big brother Urbock, but lighter in every way, and with a very slight metallic flavor. Nicely balanced, but not quite there.
UPDATED: JUN 7, 2009 Very good beer.  Will have to update my description some time as my laptop died mid-rating last night so I lost my comments.

0,5 litre bottle at the Pembury Tavern, on 5th June 2009. Pours deep brown with a thick,off white head. The charcoaly smokiness is intense and instantaneous both of aroma and flavour. As the previous reviewer states, there is a hint of smoked meat (I get sausage) which I absolutely adore in a rauchbier. Also an underlying bitterness adds depth of flavour. Sip and savour slowly and enjoy the long, smoky/grassy finish. Absolutely exquisite.
my first smoked beer! i really didnt know what to make of it when i first tried it but the word bacon came to mind. i really warmed up to it since and i like it a lot! a bit expensive but worth it.

Extremely smoky aroma... Like smoked sausage... Deep mahogany red to brown in color... Flavor is like the aroma, very smoky in character but more subtle than you would expect from the aroma... Very tasty beer..

The New Bacon of Beer!!!! This beer pours an impressive dark copper with a massive tan head. The smell almost brought to my knees with the over powering scent of smoke, kinda the way your clothes smell after a weekend of camping, it stabs you like a knife to the nose. The sharp smoky taste hits you the second you pour this brew into your mouth, this definitely is not a smooth beer you can slam back or drink more then one in a evening. Its definitely a full bodied taste thats not watered down. I guess for its style its good, but I dont think Im a fan of the style. My serving suggestion for this would be have it at breakfast with two eggs, hash browns and a side of toast ketchup is optional.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2010 Has the same smokiness as the urbock that you either love or hate, but the rest of the beer is a little tamer. the appearance is stunning, khaki head on top of reddish light brown. easier to swallow down, the actual marzen backing is very good.  nice and crisp, moderate bitter finish.  smokey and woody, very thick mouthfeel makes it surprisingly the abv is so low.  after having it again im not sure if the urbock is better or worse. gotta try that one again now

Bottle. Brown/reddish colour with an off-white head. Aroma: Smoke, smoked ham, wood. Taste: Smokiness, malty background, smoked ham, woodfire, tar, light caramel sweetness, light bitterness. Medium bodied.

It poured a dark liquid with some brown and reddish tones and a big foam that left a nice lacing on the side of the glass. The first sniff was heavy with smoke, burned wood, smoked ham and oil. The flavor was similar but weaker, although it lasted longer then the aroma. It tasted if smoke, smoked ham, meat broth and wood. If you want a smoked beer this is something to go for, but I felt it tasted a bit like a very old hunting cabin, dank and impregnated with smoke after years of use.

From bottle, dark-red with medium beige head, aroma of smoked ham, chocolate, and caramel sweetness, flavor of smoked wood, smoked cheese, hash, caramel, chocolate and bitter pleasant finish with hash and some spices. great beer.

This poured a dark dark brown with a small light tan head. Aroma was basically nothing but smoke and dark roasted malts. Flavor was a little bit less overwhelming than aroma, but still mainly just deep dark smoke, and some maltyness in the after thought as well.
