I grew up making country hams in my familys smoke house.  Ive cooked a slab of ribs over hickory for ten hours.  But with those, the smoke doesnt overwhelm as it does in this beer.  Perhaps Im not man enough for this beer, but then,  maybe some people are too manly for their own good.
Best beer Ive had in a long time. Pours brown with a small tan head. Aroma and taste are overwhelming of smoke. Truly a classic.

500 ml botte. Best before date 2004-05. I’ve had this one lying around for while. Dark brown colour with a deep reddish hue. Medium sized mixed off-white head. Grainy and wort-like aroma at first then strong pungent bacon aroma. Well-rounded texture. Seemingly little carbonation. Feels quite bready, much like pumpernickel. Not really sweet, but not particularly dry either. Flavourwise there isn’t much smoke (or bacon if you will) to be detected, but rye instead. Burping makes the room smell of pumpernickel. This is something very special. An acquired taste for sure. I didn’t like it the first time, but this time it wasn’t that bad. I have a fresh bottle in the fridge as well, so I’ll try that one soon to compare. There’s nothing wrong with this vintage, rather the opposite as it is quite rounded and mellow.

After hearing about smoked biers, I had to give it a try, and, well, maybe Im not a true beer aficionado, but I did not care for this taste in the least.  First, the scent of smoke upon opening the bottle was overwhelming, and not particularly pleasant either.  The pour is deep mahogany color, with little head.  The flavor and scent throughout the entire glass was that of a smoldering campfire.  To be perfectly honest, I would have rated this beer lower, due to my personal preferences, but do not want to do damage to the rating that currently stands, as I am one of many opinions, though I find it hard to believe that nobody else strongly dislikes this beer

Like nothing I have ever tasted before. Brown with a fading white head, although the second pour was vigorous and puffed up quite a bit. Aroma is quite assertive, with smoked pork, charred wood, liquid smoke, some smoked chile peppers - really the essence of a campfire, with a bit of brown sugar or sweet caramel malt in there for some balance and good measure.  The taste is not overpowering, with smoke predominant but balanced well by a subtle but clean hop bitterness and an overlying caramel malt presence.  Finishes with a slightly metallic touch. Becomes much more mild as it warms, developing a greater bitterness and an easy drinkability. On the tongue, nothing special but nothing to critique.  Not exactly my favorite - I just cant ever see turning to this one another time, but it was definitely worth a try to see just what this smoke beer thing is all about.

Dark brown/amber pour topped with a foamy, creamy off-white head.  Great lace.  Wonderful smoke and coffee aroma.  Smooth mouthfeel with a pleasing smoky aftertaste.  The perfect complement to my "Bubba Burger"!

Pours a deep dark brown, with frothy one finger head that recedes slowly to a spotty cap and thick ring, leaving behind a nice webbing of lace.

Smell; this smells strongly of smoked pork. I also get some caramel malts, with a little sweetness in there.

Taste; interesting smokey flavors that I associate with homemade smoked pork. Theres those sweet caramel, and toffee malts that mingles very nicely with the smoked flavors, with just some hints of hop bitterness in the finish.

Mouthfeel is a bit on the thin side, but the drinkability is higher than I was expecting. This is only the second true Rauchbier that Ive had, and I cant believe how good it is. I have a couple more different ones to sample, and now i cant wait to try them.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Pours a clear dark maple with a thick head and large slow moving bubbles.  Aroma and flavor is very smokey, almost too smokey for my palate.  You can taste the sweet carmel notes if you hunt for it.  Goes down smooth, overall not a bad beer.

Pours a clear brownish ruby color, with about half an inch of light tan head. The foam dies back in about a minute to a thick ring and a thin top layer. Surprisingly effervesent. No lacing. Strong smoky scent even before I start to pour the contents into my glass. 

First sip is medium heavy on that liquid smoke, but after a couple sips, I notice the malty character beneath the smoke. The maltiness is mildly sweet and a little bready. Hops are in there too, though only a fleeting taste right at the end. The smokiness lingers for several minutes in the aftertaste.

Light bodied and softly carbonated (nowhere near as effervesent as when first poured).

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2009 Dark brown pour with a minimal off-white head. Smokey malt aroma, smokey sour malt flavor. The finish? Smokey. I hate to call this a one-note beer, because it was obviously made with skill and talent, but the smoke overpowers everything to me. Thats okay, though. It is what it is and its tasty ... if you like smoke. Nice for the novelty, but definitely not my style. Tastes like a house fire smells.

Wooooow!!! HELP, HELP - where is the fire extinguisher???? - smoke comes out of my bottle!! Well OK, if I have to be honest, its only smoke aroma or should I rather call it smell... The color of the beer is mahogany red/brown, almost black and the head is OK. My previous experience with smoked beer was at this point only Highlander, and it seems like an infant compared to this one, that is a senior citizen... When my nose reaches the glass I feel like Im in a smokehouse, but I also sense notes of wharf and tar. The flavour is not salt, but otherwise it is smoked foods I taste. There is a lot of smoked meat, Danish salami and smoked eel skin in the above order. I cannot find any other notes, and I briefly get the idea that this might be the ideal way to loose weight for lovers of smoke - stop eating and start drinking, but then again LOL. No, honestly, it was a great experience to taste this beer, and I actually drank all of it myself. I also tried it with my dinner, but that wasnt a pleasure. This has to be a beer that you either love or hate, and right now (medio July 05) Im not sure where I belong, Ill have to taste it again some day to know for sure...

Pours a mahogany color with a medium sized cream colored head. Smokey malty aroma and taste. A slight bitter aftertaste. A more subtle version of thier urbock but without the bitterness of the weizen. I still prefer the urbock

Dark mahogany with quickly dissappearing head. The same smoky malt aroma as the other Schlenkerla offerings, somewhat milder than the Urbock and a bit more twangy/spicy than the Weizen. Really enjoyable. Overall it was more balanced than the others, also in the taste which was lighter than the Urbock but heavier & more dry than the Weizen. Good mouthfeel, fits the rest of the brew very well. A nice alternative to the heavier & rougher Urbock, it just lacked a bit of intensity. Nonetheless a great rauchbier.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2007 Page 13 of MJs Great Beer Guide. I have had three beers from this brewery. My first thoughts when I had this beer was it would be a truly great marzen if they kept the smoked Salmon out of it. 199 of his Classic Brews to go.

Interesting.  I have put this one off for years as friends and pros would put me off with the smoked ham hock reference.  Well the bark is worse than the bite, at least the bottle, as the tap version is very aromatic.  Dark amber color, small head.  Yes a noticable smoke aroma, country ham hocks spot on.  Taste is mildly smokey, not nearly as bad as the liquid smoke I was lead to believe.  As a positive I can see the potential with food pairings with this beer.

500 mL bottle.  Deep auburn brown with a film of head.  Smells like my Mas baked ham!  Or like the woodstove at my cottage.  Theres a little something else there too.  Salt?  Bread?  Salty bread?  Taste is, well, smoky.  Other interesting stuff going on here too.  I think.  Its hard to tell.  Good balance of sweetness and bitterness.  Nicely carbonated.  Smoke is not a flavour I look for in a beer, and Im not sure Id go out of my way to find it again.

Aroma of a forest fire right out of the bottle.  Beautiful, translucent dark color with brown hue and decent tan head of one finger.  The flavor is tres complex...  Once you get past the smoke layer a variety of cedar or pine, malt and even vanilla flavors surface.  The palate is rich and easy to distinguish that it is cask conditionned beer.  This is a beer meant to be savoured to truly be enjoyed, make no mistake.

(Bottle BB 04/07) Aroma of smoked and tar (mild). Red brown colour, clear and average size, light brown, very slightly lasting head with fair lacing. Sweet, tar, smoked and slightly bitter flavour. Softly carbonated, medium-bodied and smooth palate. 10/11/06

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2006 Help!  Help!  Theres a fire in my mouth!  Thats what you may well say, whence you sample this little concoction.  It has a very smokey chorizo/smoked paprika taste, which is truly interesting and different, if not particularly nice!  Smoking!

(Bottle) Dark red with white head. Smoked, wood, meat, fish, cheese you name it aroma with some sour hints. Smoke flavour with some peppery notes. Small to medium malty backbone. Clean mouthfeel. Lingering aftertaste. One dimentional and very good.

50 cl bottle, Shelburne. Dark amber brown, thin head. Thick malty aroma. Bitter initial hit, fades to a smokey finish, not unlike a smoked cheese. As others have mentioned it is lighter bodied than expected, but the smokey aftertaste fills the gap.

Big sweet smoke nose. Pours very dark copper with a small white head. Flavor has a nice smoothness to it, sweet smoke flavors develop with a light caramelized malt character. Finish has a light bitterness that cleans the palate. This beer has a lighter body, but enough character that this never feels thin or watery. Very enjoyable.
This is my first rating and I give all points since this is the beer that achieves great attention. It takes one to get into it, but than you will never forget it.

bottle. Dark golden brown with light brown almost vanishing head. Aroma offers plenty of smoked malt and some earl grey tea. Flavor is really well balanced between malt, smoke, sweetness and hops. Finish lingers on for more than a minute with smoke, malt and hops. Really well balanced and tasty beer.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2007 500 ml bottle, shared with StompBrockmore - pours deep auburn, with a pretty big beige head.  Huge wood-smoke aroma, smells like burning hickory.  Nice aroma that reminds me of a crisp fall day.  I didnt pick it up at first, but after Sir Brockmore shoved a bottle of Laphroaig under my nasal passage, I did certainly detect a similar peatiness to the scotch.  Nice.  Flavour is good, smokey again, but with a subtle  sweetness in there as well.  Smokey (Im noticing a pattern here) finish.  I really enjoy this one, after having come to appreciate the style.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 500ml bottle, shared with VeloVampire - pours a very dark brown, with a relatively thick off-white head on top. Smokey, peaty malt in the aroma which reminded me quite specifically of Laphroaig scotch. Flavour is again quite smoky, but not overwhelmingly so, with a good amount of sweet malt in the background for balance. The aroma is actually stronger than the flavour, at least as far as the intensity of the smoke is concerned. Not really a beer for the uninitiated to the style, but interesting nonetheless, and the best of the style (of which Im not really a fan) that Ive had to date. Drinkable, though not something I would regularly seek out despite its availability.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2010 Bottle. Dark brown with a reddish glow and a dense off white head. Smoke and malt in aroma. Sweet flavour of malt and smoke. Soft. I like this very much... Re-rate from draught (former rating: 7-3-8-4-15): red brownish with a beige head. Smoke in abundance along with sausage and wood. Sweet malt flavour with a little tartness, harsh in a good way and a huge amount of smoke.

500. Pours a nearly opaque dirty brownish black. Thin off-white head dozing around on top. Humongous smoky peppery bacon nose. Humongous smoky peppery bacon palate. The bodys medium, low-ish carb, no alcoholo bite, fairly clean finish. A little peppery smoke sticks to the back of your throat. Overall, this is a very clean, drinkable, pleasurable, complex, satisfying beer. But first and foremost ya gotta be in the mood for smoky pepper bacon. If youre not, keep walking.
Looks great in the glass with a medium head. Aroma is rich and smokey. This beer has some character.

This is a tour de force of smoke! It might best be described as a liquid, smoked salami with alcohol. I adore it and could drink mas after mas of it. Its sad that its not more widely available in Denmark. It should be a stable in most bars...

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 Dark brown, maybe a bit greenish or bluish? Nice carb. Packs nice hoppy bitterness underneath the rauch. Re-rate: This has slowly grown to be one of my favourites. I keep finding new twists from it. Its much more than just rauch..

Sampled from the brewery in Bamberg, straight from the wooden barrel. A really wonderful beer that pairs well with typical food from the area. Its a little smokier than the others but enjoyable nonetheless.

Got this one bottled at the Binnys Oktoberfest in St. Charles, Illinois.  What can I say, this is one of the most interesting beers Ive ever tried.  Smells like sticking your head into a barbeque, looks as black as coal, and tastes like grilling.  This would be great to spice up some baked beans or as a nice marinade, but its a bit much to drink a lot of them, actually.

My first smoked. And boy, was it ever. Dark brown clear color, medium tan head. Strong burnt wood aroma. So strong, I was kind of afraid to taste it. But the smoky taste wasnt nearly as oppressive as the smoky smell. You can really taste the malty marzen qualities, along with the smoke. Not too bad.
I dont think Ill be drinking this regularly, but I bet Ill be drinking it again. Leave it to the Germans.

Lovely aroma of smoked bacon and sweet malt.  pours a dark brown amber color with head the quickly dissapates into a film.  flavors are smokey, rich, with lots of malt.  could use a bit more body.  definitely a down grade from the Urbok, but still very pleasant and interesting.  cheers for rauchbier

16 oz bottle via Liquid Solutions. Pours a celar dark brown with an average size beige head. Aroma is smoke and hickory, and a bit of toffee. Tastes like it smells, is VERY smokey and some nuttiness as well, and perhaps even a little hoppiness in the finish? Or maybe it is just roastiness..it is hard to tell but there is something very bitter under the smokiness. There is also some coffee and a little bit of chocolate in the finish. pretty complex beer. Medium bodied.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown, ruby against the light with a thick light brown head.  This is the best smelling beer Ive encountered in its own very unique way.  Rich, almost like slow roasted barbeque, an amazingly rich smoky scent.  Tastes like it smells, a smoky flavor that makes me feel like Im drinking beef brisket.  A carmelized sweetness hides in the smoke.  Very interesting and enjoyable, with a smooth rich finish to top it off.
UPDATED: NOV 16, 2006 Very interesting style I was pleased to try. Made me think I was eating something off a bon-fire. Smoky, bitter taste. Different, and very good.

Certainly different, certainly an aquired taste. a coke-brown marzen with an overwhelming taste of a decent european smoked sausage that dominates all other flavours. liquidized salami isnt quite my thing at this stage in my beer-tasting evolution.

Sampled today (from bottle) at Mecklenburg Gardens in Cincinnati...

This is a superb rauchbier.  Color is dark brown (cola) and is surprisingly clear.  Aroma and flavor are both an amazing smoke with a hint of meatiness behind it.  The smokiness is rich and completely permiates this brew, but its a bit hard to describe.  It isnt like burned or charred wood, it isnt artificial in taste or smell, and it isnt overpowering.  It is meatly, rich, and satisfying.  The finish is dry, slight char, and some bittering hops come through.  Medium body, but full on the tongue.  Overall, this beer has a rich and complex malt base and deep smokiness to it.  It is a wonderful sipping beer and would probably be well acoompanied by fine cigar and would also go great with many types of food.  I thoroughly enjoyed this beer and look forward to trying it again, the other rauchbier offerings from this brewery (they also make a wheat and ur-bock version), and other smoked beers in gerneral.

500 mL bottle.

Dark copper approaching cola color. Moderate, tight-bubbled off-white head. Huge nose of smoked bacon, tobacco, leather, earth. Notes of sweetness, reminiscent of baked brown sugar, behind the smoke. The flavor is full of smoke and bitter tobacco but with a delicate sugary sweetness, too. Moderate carbonation, clean, but with the lingering aftertaste of smoke and bitter hops. Dry in the end. I was quite impressed at the start with the rich complexity of aromas and flavors, but a little of this beer went a long way for me. Once I passed 12 ounces, I was thinking enough already. Still, the first 12 ounces were outstanding.

I really appreciate this unique brew.  A friend said it reminded them of beef jerkey.  I can agree.  Very heavy with the smoke flavor to the point where it really does become a bit too overpowering to anything else in the beer. Yet, somehow it works well.
Pours a nice dark browish red color. Great smokey aroma.Great smoke flavor weith a nice malt bakcing to it.Nice lasting flavor too.Wonderful!
Very creamy texture, but thin head. beautiful smoky aroma and smoky finished that reminds me bacon. But not as smoked as the Weizen from the same brewery.

Bottle, brought back from the brewery this summer. Beautiful deep smoky aroma, dark clear appearance and great smoked meat taste. Surpisingly light feel and texture but a lingering sticky aftertaste. Its not as good as draught, but I cant move to Bamberg just yet!
Malty smokey aroma, not too much smoke though. Dark red colour. Not much foam. Taste is quite bitter and oaky. Long finish!

First smoked brew.  Poured from 16.9 oz.  Nice rich amber color.  Overwhelming bacon smell and taste.  Cant feel the maerzen, except slightly on intake.  Lighter body gives to heavier body.  Definately different.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2012 Bottle. A clear dark broen beer, with a large, frothy, lacing,  mostly lasting beige head. The aroma is moderately malty (toasted/roasted grain/bread), with very strong notes of smoked meat, cheese and wood. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, very long finish with medium bitterness. Fantastic, but its not for the complexity of the malt character (its all about smoke), rather for the intensity, the uniqueness and the plesantness of what you smell and taste. Also very drinkable once you get used to its peculiarity.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2008 Gravity in Bamberg - Beautiful dark chestnut body, lasting thick beige head leaving thick patches of lacing; Beautiful clear freshly burnt wood smoked nose with warmer caramel malt aromas and even way back a spicy hop touch; Super fresh body, young fresh carbonation, very beautiful small bitting bubbles, soft texture, super balanced with a small malt bitter show off; Medium long finish that actually is a little short compared to what is expected, lots of burnt wood aroma, malt and clear hop bitterness. This beer is in a class of its own!!!!!! From bottle - 7-4-6-3-15=3.5 - Brown clear body, creamy beige head; Deep and quite complex nose with lots of different smoked aromas, most powerful is smoked bacon, barbecue beef jerky, burnt wood, there is also sweet sugary malt with some metallic white sugar undertones; Soft to velvety textured body, very little carbonation, balanced with some bitter freshness; Quite bitter finish that is strangely combined, the bitter and sweet parts doesnt  fit perfectly together, the texture is thinner and aromas are more basic then the nose: again some smoked bacon, but also raw meat.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Pours very dark, but clear.  Actually kind of an ugly color. Aroma is smoky and reminds me of smoked pork.  Flavor is smoky as well and has a nice sweetness to it without being overbearing. A bitterness follows the sweetness and makes for a well balanced beer.  This is far better than I was expecting.

On tap at HDG. Deep dark brown in color with a nice fluffy tan head that left a nice lacing on the glass. Malty smokey bacon aroma. Malty smokey molasses flavor. The smokeyness lingers throughout the whole beer. Smooth mouthfeel. Creamy. Finish is smokey.  Full bodied. Very enjoyable. Delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2006 Draught at the brewery, dark brown with a large pillowy slightly beige head. Unbelieveable aroma - so smoky ham. That smokiness carries through to the flavour and a smooth mouthfeel. Wow, so unique and strangely delicious.

Sample at Sleepy Bear tasting 09/30/06 - Aroma is smoke, beef jerky, roasted carmel and burnt toffee.  Pours dark brown with a medium head and good lacing.  Flavor matches aroma, kind of like licking hickory chips from the BBQ.  Palate is sticky.  A tasty brew that was a great compliment to the slow cooked pork.
brownish head... smokiness at its best...mesquite... cask wood... dark brown poor. just the right carbonation and strong finish.  Tastes what you smell... just not as strong ;-)...
UPDATED: OCT 20, 2006 Bottle. Dark and creamy like in colour. Nice brown head. This beer is very smoky and coffee like in flavour and aroma.

Clear brown with a thin head. Smoked wet dog aroma with a hint of vanilla. Lightly sweet caramel flavor compliments a deep but not over powering smokiness. Very clean and well balanced but also nuanced and satisfying. Perhaps a little light in body for my tastes though. I would be interested to know what is used as the smoking fuel for the malt.

For some reason I was expecting this to pour very dark but was surprised to see it pour a deep golden with a thick, creamy head.  Pork butts in the smoker - boy oh boy this smells fantastic!  Salted meats, charred woods, pipe tobaccos, the list goes on.  I could smell this all day.  Medium body slows the pace slightly - noting bready malts, spicy bacon and fresh  woods.  Although I really enjoy the finesse involved with the malt bill - I could use a little more meat - sorry for the pun - in the body.  Overall, a fantastic example of the style and one definitely to be enjoyed with a heavy meat dish.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2007 I gambled on one of these a few years ago and have been enjoying them ever since.  It is definitely something that you either love or will never drink again.  The smoky aroma and flavor throw you off guard at first, and you wonder why you are drinking a beer that tastes like smoke.  After a few sips you begin to enjoy it for what it is, a complex and tasty brew.

500ml. bottle. Dark copper with a small, but long lasting beige head. Aroma of wood smoke with some"meatiness" to it along with caramel malts and a touch of tobacco. Flavor was tons of smoke, but not as much as the Urbock or Weizen. Then again it could just be that I am getting more used to rauchbiers. Hints of bacon, molasses, wood and tobacco. If you told me two years ago I would be enjoying this beer I would have said you were crazy. Now I am becoming crazy for smoked beers.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 DONT BE SCARED OFF BY THE STRONG AROMA.   Pours deep mahogany brown w/ a full semi creamy froth. Aroma of smoked meat is strong. Reminds me of the morning after a campfire. That heavy smoked aroma is in your hair, clothes. Brings back memories. Medium nectar w/ soft residul effers. Flavors are surprisingly mellow w/ a defined smokey character. Mellow fruit w/ softly leathered jerkey and slight creamy vanilla garter. Surprisingly easy to palate after the big smokie nose. Just a pinch of bitterng on the finish. This one improves upon warming. I bought two bottles. I anticipated drinking only one of them. I drank one cold then the other made the hour trek home in a paper sack. It was so delicious I couldnt resist. The temperature of bottle two was perfect. This brew rocks. Its so easy to drink with perfect balance of flavor.Its funny how an aroma will evoke such childhood memories. I highly recommend this brew. DONT BE SCARED OFF BY THE STRONG AROMA.

500ml Bottle: My 101st review, only hours after #100.  This was supposed to be my century mark but it scared me to so I waited until dinner.  Pours ruby red with an off-white head that quickly faded to significant lacing.  Aroma of liquid smoke, if youre familiar with that, much like hickory although were told its beechwood.  As it warms you get touches of sweet malt.  Initial ice cold flavour is just dominated by smoke, this is one you must allow to warm.  Once it was only cool the malts and hops were brought out, but the smoke is still prominent.  Excellent workmanship, and I can respect the effort, but Ill never drink one again.  Take that for what you will.

This is my 100th beer (im finally in the club) and I couldnt have asked for a better beer. Bottle. Nice brownish colour with a off white head. The smokey taste was very unique and reminded me of a bonfire. I will definitely drink this again.

Brown hue.  Smells like smoked salami or gouda to me (smoked of course).  After a few sips the smoky flavor leaves enough room for a faint sweet kick and a tiny bitter hop touch, but just barely. Goes well with the roast beef and havarti Im having.  No way in hell Id have this beer without food.  Excellent for its style, but not my thing at all.

(500 ml bottle from Belfast Co-op) Slightly cloudy tea-ish brown body with a tall tan head that quickly recedes to about 1/2". Aroma dominated by sweet smoked meat, maybe some caramel if you really dig. Mouthfeel smooth, lightly prickly, a bit dry. Sloppy, spotty lacing. Flavor is highly smoke-driven, hard to pick out much underneath. Sweet smoked meat with a malt backbone buried in there is about best I can describe. Finishes somewhat bitter, and aftertaste is more bitter than smokey. Texture and taste-wise, I enjoyed the Urbock and Lagerbier more than this.

Bottle. Nice mahogny colour with a good creamy offwhite head. The smoked meat aroma is also very appetising. Malty sweetness is well balanced by smoked meat flavours. Still ending with a dry mouthfeel. A nice classic.

Pours a deep brown color with offwhite head.  Aroma is of a smoked meat.  Taste is smoke with a bit of malt and barely noticeable hops.  Ive wanted to try this beer for a very long time so I picked up 4 of them.  Potent stuff compared to Rogues Smoke Ale.
Pours mahogany with a patchy and edgy off-white head. Aroma is smoked meat, roasted nutty malt (grain, meal) yeast (earth) and bacon.

Pours deep mahogany into a shaker.  Sharp hickory-smoked meat notes.  Offwhite micro head with good retention leaves slight lacing as it recedes.  Creamy smoked sweetness with a lasting bittered smoke finish.

This beer is for cookimg with only.  You should not put this in your stein and be able to enjoy this as a session.  Very dark for a Marzen.  The smoke aroma overpowers any malt aroma.  The smoke salami flavor overpowers any you try to eat or drink for the next few days!!!  Very unique beverage.

From a 1 pt. 9 oz. euro brown bottle with no freshness date.

Poured a rudy hued dark brown with a foamy off-white/beige head that settled into a thin lacing, small amount of sticking.

Aromas of a quality smoked ham, the kind of smell that makes you drool, an vanilla oak woodiness and a sweet caramelized maltiness in the background.

The right amount of moderate carbonation and a crisp, chewy and smooth medium bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious smokey tasty, a nice meatiness, a caramelized sugary maltiness, a vanilla oak woodiness, the hops provide a soft bitterness in the middle, and a smokey malt with touches of caramel finish, smooth, good drinkability.

This is my second rauchbier from this brewery and I have to say, so far, Im pretty impressed.

500 ml bottle direct from Germany. Wow, blazing ham smoke aroma!  This is what Beechwood aging is really supposed to mean - just kidding this is smoked with beech not fermented in it. Huge smokiness may be off-putting to some but this is a true to style Rauch Marzen. Pours a firey deep amber/brown-orange color that floats a rocky head. Sweet maltiness upfront ending with dark toastiness from Munich malts yieldiing a satisfying dryness to wrap it up. A great drinking beer probably best enjoyed in moderation as it will wipe out the flavor of any lesser beer you might want to be quaffing :-)

500ml bottle, 5.1% a/v
Pours precisely the same colour and carbonation as a glass of coke, with a faint offwhite head. The aroma is of smoke pure and simple, with some malts present. Tastes obviously smokey, like a strange mixture of malt beer and a smoked meat. Gotta admit its a bit too smokey for my tastes. The aftertaste is as if you were chewing on charcoal from a fire.

Personally, i really dont enjoy this beer that much.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2016 Bottle 500ml. @ home on the terrace. [ As Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen ]. [ This rating is to celebrate my 10 years on RB - this beer is absolutely the beer I in the parst had been my favorit beer of all time.. always in the cellar, a good choice to food, BBQ, cheese, as a night cap, as a morning beer, as a beer after a long days work.. for me a winner ;D ].Clear dark brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, smoke, bacon - meat - wood, dark malt malt, sweet malt, roasted - toasted, light hay - wood. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, smoke, wood - bacon - meat, dark malt. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160622]  10-5-10-5-20 
Cask @ Schlenkerla, Bamberg. [ As Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen ]. Dark brown color with small head. Smokey aroma. Very soft and smokey.  8-4-8-4-20 
Bottle 500ml. [ As Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Märzen ]. Dark brown color with large head. Very smokey aroma. Very soft and smokey. Really enjoyable beer.

Dark amber colored brew. Very, very, very smoked aroma. Its aroma smells like a smoked ham. Lots of different tast in this one. Smoked, a bit bitterness, a bit sweet, spices and a bit floral. Thnx to ceasar for bringing this one.

Very, very smoky aroma. There is no other aroma characteristic but smoke. But it is a nice smoke; a nice campfire smoke. Dark, reddish, brown body with an off-white head that is thin. Not much lace. Initially, the flavor is disappointing. Very dry and malty. Smoke is not as strong in the palate as in the aroma. I dont see a world class beer here like Oakes does. No flaws, and a solid beer for a smoke fan.

Cask at GBBF 06: my first rauchbier and what a treat, dark brown-red colour, great aroma of smoked meat, smoked bacon and cold cut salami, mmmm... really mouth watering, the flavor is pretty the same, very rich, very appetite arousing, some woody notes, some light sweetness, very smooth and highly drinkable.

Bottle. This should be interesting, the first time I had this (before I was rating) I hated it so much that I recapped it and walked it over to GregClows house and gave it to him. Ive since then grown to like many Smoked beers so I hope that bodes well for this one. Pours a clear deep ruby-amber with a large mostly lasting foamy off-white head. Aroma is, of course, very smokey and almost ham or bacon-like along with, well, its hard to detect anything else really -- theres some malt and wood and...Ill leave the rest to others with a better sense of smell. Flavour is the part that scares me as I have that lingering memory of hating it so much. Here goes. Ah yes, my tastes have definitely changed: I like it! Along with all the smokyness theres  a nice amount of sweet malt and some light hops in the finish. Light to medium bodied. Im happy I gave it another try and though I still dont love it (I MUCH prefer the Alaskan Smoked Porter) and I wouldnt want more than one, I still liked it.

Pours mahagony with a patchy and edgy off-white head.  Aroma is smoked meat, roasted nutty malt (grain, meal), yeast (earth) and bacon.  Mildly sweet smoked malt and beef, pork, trace yeast, ashy and mild bitter, acidic finish.  Medium bodied, thin and fizzy palate.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2006 Well, where do I even start on this. The aroma is so smokey, i felt like low-crawling out of my house. The flavor is overwhelming smoke, meat, definitely ham, and bacon. This sounds reminiscent of gstephs rating, but what the hell, its right on the money, only i didnt like it to much. Strangest beer ive had yet. I know it says its a "smoke beer", but geez! Worth a try, but thats about it. If I were rating on style, it would be pretty high. Its just not my thing though.

Pours a deep amber with a thin tan head that didnt want to stay around too long.  Great sweet and smoky aroma, ham, bacon, etc.  A tad thin on the body but good smoky, meaty flavor.  A small hops bite on the end.  A great beer if you just want to have one or two.  I would loose interest in any more than that.  Definitely great with grilling and as of right this very minute....pizza.  A great representation of the style.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2006 Clear dark pop color(huh?). Small head that goes away quickly...smokey meat is the aroma and is pretty nice, but a bit sour. Very nice smoke taste, and the beer remains refreshing. Im drinking this while bbqing...perfect. Hops come through at the end, but arent overly bitter. Just a nice balance.

Pouts a clear red black with a healthy white medium density head.  This is not what I expected of a Marzen, though Ive never had a real rauchbier!  The nose is straight up bacon.  Mostly smoke, with a few light fruity notes sneaking out.  Perhaps hops?  The palate is creamy and mouthfilling though not too thick.  The flavor is an amazing deadringer for bacon.  As a vegetarian willing to make exceptions for things like bacon and pastrami, I think I might be able to cross bacon off of the list entirely thanks to the flavors in this beer.  Theres even the salty twang from bacon in this beer.  Theres some slight burnt charcoal flavors that really fill this beer out the balance a significant rich sweetness up front.  Even a touch of spicy floral hops comes through.  An absolute ton of complexity.  I really enjoyed this beer and will certainly buy more!

Wow, this is like liquid bacon.  Heavy smokey aroma and flavor, and its just dominated by bacon.  A deep dark red with a fairly large tan head.  I like it, but you really have to be in the mood for bacon and a super smokey beer to enjoy a full glass of it.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2012 Second rating Dec 20 CBAC. 

Treat shared with Tipsy. Dark copper. Light head of tight bubbles. Beef jerky aroma makes you hungry, Flavour is light jerky. Interesting airy light body. Loses interest the more you have. A novelty beer for me.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2016 0,5lt. bottle .At "1920" restaurant in Athens. My first rauchbier and I was really impressed. Great with the BBQ plate that I ordered.Very dark brown in color. Aromas and taste of smoked bacon , ash, nice saltiness. Great , I will drink it again (and again...)

Nice smokey bacon flavor.  Not too bad.  Huge head light brown fully lasting with lots of lacing.  Black in color.  For being a smoke beer I must say I was impressed.  I would drink this again. Goes great with pizza.

500 ml bottle into a Dimpled Mug glass.  Pours a mixed light tan and brown color with a very thin tan head that quickly slides away into a thin cover on the brew.  The aroma is heavy on the notes of smoked bacon, smoke, saltiness, and smokey barley.  The flavor has much of the same elements of the nose.  It begins with a light malty hint which moves into a very heavily smoked malts and bacon.  The smoked bacon flavor lingers for quiet some time.  A tiny hop bitterness hits near the end, but is very quickly covered in the smoked bacon.  Fairly smooth, not too carbonated.  Not my favorite style, but I had to try one from Aecht.  For what it is, its good, but I wont be back for a while!

Draught at the brewery tap  Creamy, light brown head.  The head diminishes mostly and leave a fair lace.  Heavy aroma of smoke, salt and smoked bacon.  Just like theyve put smoked bacon in it for 2 years.  Its the first time I taste this style, but I dont like this one too much, because its just too much smoke, but I might have to learn to appeciate the style, as I had to to with lambics, which is now my favourite style.  The flavour is lightly sweet in the beginning and moderately bitter in the end, again with a lot of smoked bacon.  It is a very interesting experience though.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2006 500 ml bottle: Ahhh.....reminds of the time that I sat down with a bag of Kingsford Charcoal to enjoy Superbowl XXV.  A taste much like licking campfire embers.....brilliant! However, the hints of marmelade and offensive smell make this a difficult beer to drink. The human body does not like smoke, and I challenge anyone not to cringe after a good whiff of this most unpleasant beer. Save some money...throw some ashes in your favorite beer and shake vigorously....strain and enjoy! Im sorry to be so abusive but there is no way that this beer is 90th percentile. Give me a break. Id drink a domestic trunk beer ahead of this crap.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2006 500 mL Bottle:  What crap! The official beer of Hell, or the prefect brew if you find yourself trapped in a smoker?  Words cannot express how completely UNDRINKABLE this is.  The aroma says it all:  you will be choking back liquid smoke.  On the positives: it is "smoke" beer & I have no doubts somebody burnt the crap out of this.  However, I dont see how anyone could enjoy this:  it is almost the opposite of liquid, no refreshment value whatsoever.  I wouldnt even recommend this as a novelty food product (forget beer for a second).  Overwhelming & unpalatable smoke taste makes all other factors irrelevant.  You cant have 1 flavour completely overwhelming the taste or it is ruined.  It boggles my mind this has any ratings above 1.0.  Youve all gone mad.  Give me an abusive warning page:  people must be warned!

(0.5L Bottle) Pours dark brown. Aroma of smoke. Taste is pretty much the same, with some dough flavoring as well. Its a great beer to eat with food, but I could only drink one or two alone. Its not one of my favorites, but is definitely worth drinking once in a while.

Its been I while since I had this style of smoked beer... and I know why again.  I will try to be objective though.  Dark tawny reddish brown with a very soapy tan head.  Aroma is like barbecue sauce and wood - smell is very thick.  Med / full bodied with very little carbonation.  Taste is over-the-top smokey, woody and barbecue sauce like.  Its been many many years since Ive eaten red meat, but it tasted meaty.  Mouthfeel is smooth.  Okay if you are into it, but I will never need another.

If this beer wasnt labeled "trendy" it wouldnt sell a bottle.  Although the appearance is inviting, dark color - stoutish head, the flavor is WAY too smoked to be palatable.  Imagine if someone made a beer out of lox... and youre drinking it.  Overpowering and far too simple to be anything more than a one beer stand.

500 ml bottle.  Pours clear dark brown with a tan head that diminishes to a ring but continues to lace.  Aroma of barbeque smoke and malts. Flavor is really heavy on the smoke.  Its wonderful.  Lightly sweet malt and intense smoke fading to a light hop bitterness and drying out on the finish.  I have been looking for this beer for ages, and it certainly lives up to the hype.  Complex and interesting, and very enjoyable to drink.  My wife says its gross  but then she drinks strawberry margarita coolers   $3.49 at Total Wine, Jacksonville FL.

Reddish black, foamy beige head. Smells like Canadian bacon. Seriously. Really great aroma. Flavors is smokey, as one might expect, but also nice notes of caramel and molasses to balance it out. Crisp, clean palate. Even some hints of coffee as it warms. Thanks, Santa!
Very, very smoky! A ltittle too much smke in it but looks nice with its compact black colour. Hard to found more tastes in it, maybe some bread? The smoke is too dominant!

Pours an ashen brown that thins a bit in the light. Nose is powerful roast smokiness up front and intense. Palate is a bit lager watery. Flavor is strong all smoke up front that mellows as warms and more is consumed. A malty sweetness increasingly comes through. Definitely well-made, but a style that will not be enjoyed across the board.

Bottle: I still dont know what to make of this, fortunatly Ive got the Urbock and Weizen to try as well. Pours a nice mahogany color. Aroma was smoked bacon. Flavor was very similar, though there was a little sweetness that came through. It was very interesting. And I look foward to the others. Im just not sure if its for me.
Strong smokehouse odours. Bacon, jerky, salmon. Quite unique. Pours a dark ruby red, thin head. Strong smoke flavour, salmon. Youd better like beef jerky to tackle this one.

(05.23.06) One pint, 9 oz brown bottle from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL  Poured deep dark brown with small white head. Soft carbonation.  Intense smoky aroma. Medium bodied ale that starts dry with caramel and burnt malt flavors. Some wisp of malt sweetness. Finished dry with burnt malt flavor and bitterness. Very good smoked beer steeped with burnt wood-like flavors. Not for the meek.

My first rauchbier.  Smells like bacon, tastes like slow cooked ribs.  The smoke isnt so dominating in the flavor, it is a well balanced component of the malty flavor, not the only flavor in the beer.  Quite tasty

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2006 Hard to really contribute too much more to the website with this review. Initial woodfire smoke aroma followed up with smoked hock. Very well balance flavour that makes it quite more-ish and very sessionable. Good, even carbonation but a bit short on the finish. Very solid.

Found at Wine Sampler. Pours a brownish black with a small head. A friend called this "liquid ham" and for the first half, it really was. Other aromas and flavors such as smoke and maltiness arise in the second half. Aroma and taste of unsalted pork. Balanced creamy mouthfeel. Lingering meaty alcohol finish. Interesting beer.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2007 bottle. dark brown color. large head. smokey aroma. very good. very soft and smokey. really enjoyable.
I love this great smokey flsvor. Feels like Im eating and drinking at the same time. If you love BBQ smells and flavors this is the guy for you. Used it to cook ribs and they came out great.

Pours deep red with a mid-sized off-white head. Big smoky aroma. The smoke flavor is more subtle than that of the Schlenkerla Urbock, but the base beer is better. Toasted malts and caramel pave the way for a fairly strong smoke finish. An excellent Marzen with an excellent smoky twist.

500 ml bottle.  Pours a dark ruby with a brilliant glow when held to the light.  Small beige fizzy head with decent retention due to the fairly active carbonation.  Aroma is everything that you could ask for from an unapologetic smoke beer.  Campfire smoke, beef boullion, toasted malt, and bacon.  Summed up in one word- mouthwatering!  I could just smell this beer and be happy for an hour.  Flavor has alot of toasted malt, fairly dry at first taste.  Then the smoked meat bomb that is the beauty of this beer hits you like a train on the finish.  Minimal amount of alcohol on the finish that lingers around forever.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with very active, yet soft, carbonation yielding a fairly creamy texture.  This is the tops as far as Smoked beers go.  Truely amazing, everything you could want from a Smoke beer.

Whad we say?  I had this once with AC and apparently didn;t enter.  Remember something about smoked melted gouda on a leather baseball mitt, grape leaves, and humidors.  It was absolutely delicious and exciting and I remember the high rating.  Will be drinking this again for sure and getting a more detailed comparison of this series.  This should be a standby beer.
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2006 Transparent brown-  nose/taste hickory smoke pit unusual yet wonderful beer

From the Bottle: Pours a deep mahagony color with little head.  Aroma is of ham, maybe some burnt notes of greese.  A little bit of alcohol, smoke from a campfire on the nose, but mainly ham.  A nice amount of carbonation lacing rising to the top.  Taste is also of ham, while I smelled little more than ham I taste nothing BUT ham.  Quite interesting, I agree that it might be great with some yellow cheeses or maybe salami.  Even has a little bit of a gouda taste to it.

16.9oz bottle.  My third of the Schlenkerlas I bought a couple months back.  Pours a clear brown with a red tinge with a medium-large frothy khaki head.  Head stayed throughout, and the lacing was so thick there was just one big lace in my glass.  The first aroma I pick up on is of course smoked malts (think campfire), a little metal, and pepper.  Not quite as smoky in the flavor, though it is dominant.  Some roasty malts in there as well.  A little bit of a slight bitter, chalky finish with some charcoal ash.  Could have a little more carbonation, but a solid beer nonetheless.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
From the bottle.

Ive had this one sitting in my cellar for six months or so; I was inspired by Oakes latest column ( http://www.ratebeer.com/Beer-News/Article-621.htm ) to pull it out and give it a taste.

Pours an elegant clear caramel brown without much head. Smoked malt of course dominates the aroma, with a bit of dry-cleaners shop in there as well.  The flavor is not as powerfully smoky as the aroma, at least on the front side of each sip. This gives the caramel malts a chance come through, rich and slightly sweet, before the smoke intermingles with mild bitter hops to provide the finish.

Im relative newcomer to smoked beers; in some ways the smoked malts remind me of a strongly dry-hopped IPA in the mouth-drying finish. I cant say that Im to the point where I prefer the smoke to the hops, but this is interesting and enjoyable as well.

A very nice rauchbier, this one was great from the pour onward. The poure was dark brown with a great pillowy head that really laced quite nicely. The aroma was of deep smoked hickory wood (the char from a fire) and exceeded my prior single rauchbier experience. Flavor was strong and deep malts. This beer was super rich in both malty character and smokiness. Good stuff.

Pours a deep, dark red with an aroma of sausage, firewood, pine, salt and pepper.  Tastes exactly how it smells, very meaty and spicy with a heavy emphasis on malt.  Drinking this is like drinking in the memories of a campfire cookout from years past, one of the best beers I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2009 a totally amazing and unique experience. The aroma is explosive, very burned and smoked. Great looks, dark with a small white head. Taste is also extremely smoked, a whole lot of meat, spices and malt!! Not exactly a session beer, but so wonderful and unique

I dont really know how to begin to describe this beer. It hits you with the aroma of campfire and pine, with a lot of bacon, sausage, salt, and pepper. Its a great pour, with a foamy head that lasts the glass and a deep red amber color. Its the first smoked Ive had, and its really a lot of fun to drink. Great palate. Everybody should try this, but I dont think I could drink it on a regular basis. Great brew though.

Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark with a white head. Aroma of smoke, and smoked sausages. Flavor is sausage-like, smoke, and slight bitterness, sounds disgusting, but it was unusually pretty good.
Bouteille de 50 cl. Couleur rousse très foncée, pas de collet. Arome fumé, mais pas plus que ça. Goût fumé faible. Elle nest pas mauvaise, mais ordinaire.

I have to go back and have this again.  My impression was smoke and smoke, sweet malt and a little bitterness.  I had too many beers to taste before it, and I had it with strong smoked meats and sauerkraut, and I am sure that my palate was not able to do the beer justice.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2006 Wow, interesting beer. I dont think I can drink more than 4 or 5 oz a day. The smoke flavor just becomes too much. Poured out clear amber in color with a small khaki head. Aroma is pure smoke. Smells like a small fire is smoldering in my glass. There is just a hint of malt hidden behind the smoke aroma and really no hop presence. Taste is smoky and sweet malts. The smoke flavor seems similar to that of an Oak Cask aged Irish whiskey like Jameson Gold. But instead of the bright fresh wood taste and smell this is more charred wood embers in the flavor. I do taste some hops on the tongue and some bitterness does remain in the aftertaste. But the key player here is the smoke infused malts present throughout the taste profile. No mistake about it, its a smoke beer. For me this beer should shine when accompanied with the correct food. It goes OK with sharp cheddar cheese.

Pour is deep amber with a nice long lasting tan head...smell is strongly smokey with bacon, BBQ, and something sweet...taste is sweet with smoke overpowering any of the malt flavor that should be there...

Draught. Clear brown colour with a longlasting tan head. Has a smoked aroma with some hints of sausages. Malty and slightly smokey flavor. Has a long malty slightly smokey aftertaste, with some bitterness.

really darkbrown,with a red gloom(like chestnut-colored hair) head not very high,creamy-coloured)
by opening the bottle,the beer has a really intensive smoke smell ,as if one would sit on the fire-place(like smoke from wood).in the glass too,that smoke smell is there,but when smelling longer,something malty is hidden behind(very hidden)
by drinking the smoke impression is still there,but now,it remembers more smoked pork than wood.but not only smoky, it s a bit hoppy in the mouth, and even a little bit of malt comes trough.Fizzy little bubbles.
tasts more refreshing than one expects by smelling.
Aftertaste smoky,and an interesting bitterness.
I would not drink it for accompagnating smoked meat,that would be a bit too much smoked things the same time.(such a meal wouldlack of contrasts!perhaps one could try it with something other)
for me,thats a beer one can drink with some friends at an evening or so,with friends,to discuss about it.
very uncommon,special,makes a (change!!
By the way,nice bottle,has some "historic" flair,design of the label fits the content very well!!)
Very dark and very smokey. I love to smell this beer, however it doesnt feel as great to acctually drink. Maybe it could be a bit more fizzy?

clear dark brown with a white head. big beef jerky aroma with a hint of hops. big smokey beef jerky flavor that is almost too much to take. this beer almost seems like it is some kind of smoked meat product in liquid form. light body with slightly fizzy carbonation. long lasting dry smokey finish with a hint of european hops. a very interesting beer that everyone should try but make sure you have a few people to share the bottle with.
Dark red brown with a fluffy head, some lacing. Aroma of smoke, tar, smoked meat. The meat seems even more present in the flavour.

My first impression was that it smelled like a roast.  I was close but it wasnt until my friend mentioned the word Bacon, that I realized the true essence of this beverage.  It poured to a little head and a deep copper color.  The aroma was good, interesting, thought-provoking and rancid all in one.  The beer was unexpectedly smooth on the palate but I felt like I was drinking striaght cholesterol and fat.  I kept looking at the glass to see if a layer of fat was going to form.  it did not.  an interesting drink to try but I will never drink this again.  A true hate it or love it.

Reddish brown with a light brown head. WTF is that? is there old ham in the fridge? I had heard this smelled like ham or bacon but I didnt think it would be so prominent. This was pig straight from the smokehouse. Dont get me wrong I will enjoy my smoked meats when I want to, but drinking my smoked meats is a different thing. I was expecting to find a layer of fat in this beer. Other than the shock factor of this beer, it tasted a lot better than it smelled and was very smooth in the mouth. This was good to try, but next time I better be eating a meal when I have one. This was not my style, but I can see why so many people enjoy it.
Interesting.  Its unlike anything Ive had before.  I enjoyed it, but I dont think I would choose to have it again.

Dark red/brown pour with light brown head.  Aroma is smoked meat, malt and something else, slightly sweet.  It has a rich malt flavor, carbonated tingle, and a sweet malt syrup finish which is all capped off by the light smoke ending.

Medium brown, a touch murky.  Well formed thin head. Expressive nose of chocolate and classic smoky beech, a touch sweet. Nice bouquet but not totally convincing.  Not as good on the palate, again nice smokey touches, some malt sweetness but not much else.  A bit simple but it would be unfair to label this a poor beer.  Given there is not much of the genre in this country well worth trying.
Bottle. Pours black with a small off-white head. Aroma of smoked salami. Flavor is smoked salami and slight bitter hops. Good body, not my thing, but good for its style.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 Pours a clear brown with a tanned head. Light sweetness. Strong aromas of tar, leather and salami. Dry, leathery finish. Medium bodied. Reminds me of a classic Swedish mosquito repellant. I´m surpriced I liked it this much. I guess it would be good with fried eggs and bacon.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2006 Rating No. 250.  First had this on tap in Bamberg in 2004 (when I marvelled at the idea of liquid ham), but this review is for the bottled version.  Dark ruby brown pour, full beige head.  Intense, intense woody smokiness, big aroma.  A little burning in my nose and eyes at first, maybe its just the sensory memories of sitting too close to the fire on a chilly night.  Could spend a half hour just smelling this.  Smoked bacon or ham, also in the taste.  Full, thick body.  Balanced.  Dry finish and a lasting, slightly more subtle smoke aftertaste.  Smoke, smoke, smoke; smoke is everywhere, and never did it taste so good.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 Bottle. Pours to a rich dark brown, with a small white head. Mild carbonation. Aroma is very smokey, but is heightened with smokey meat scents like bacon and ham, as well as ash. Compared to the Urbock, the Marzen is cleaner to the palate, not as thick, and not as smokey, but still retains wonderful character and body. Smokey and roasted malt flavor is detectable, but the dominent smoke and bacon, and wood-smoke flavors make for a well rounded and enjoyable Rauchbier. I feel the Urbock has a slight edge, but this is a wonderful example for the style. I do not drink Rauchbier often, but Schlenkerla makes a great product and I am pleased that it is widely available.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2006 Draft.  WOW! Aroma is in every way similar to a smokehouse full of ham! Pretty light orange semi-cloudy color with a decent off-white head.  Drinks easily even with probably a higher carbonation than Id like but I will forgive them! Taste is an essence of smoked whitefish (in my opinion) but definite hops presence is noticeable. The woody BBQ-like flavor never diminshes yet does not overpower. Every bit the conversation piece as well as an enjoyable drink. Im in love.
Re-Rate for BOTTLED sample. Hmmm. Not nearly as delightful as on draft. Less aroma. Obvious metallic taste that I did not get from the draft. Odd.

This is a delicious beer.  Thanks again, so much to Shrubber85 for the bottle.  Very dark brown body, quickly receding tan head.  Definitely a very smokey aroma.  Medium carbonation was nice,  The sweetness of the malt is very well balanced with the smokey taste.  The aftertaste is also very pleasant, perhaps a little spicey, reminiscent of a fine smoked gouda cheese.  At any rate, this is a style Ill need to look at more closely in the future.

Bottle (...also often sampled at the Dominikanerstrasse): Dark amber coloured with reddish sparks, small, lacing off-white head; strong roast-malty nose, also charcoal and wood in the aroma; sweet-bitter (like from ashes...) flavour, quite full bodied, oily texture; long smoky, malty finish with a moderate delicate bitterness. A class of its own ! Hard to drink for beginners, but the next one is always better...............

On draught at Schlenkerla.  Thanks to Helmut, Knut & Herman for welcoming us to Bamberg so graciously at the pub.  And what a pub it is!! (oops, thats for another part of the site).  Beautiful autumn, brown color with slightly tan head.  The aroma is just incredible with bacon and woody smells.  The flavor is also nice and smoky with malt, bacon, & very little bitterness detectable.  It is very smooth and medium-bodied.  It goes down easy!  Especially after a 9.5 hour flight and a 2.5 hour train ride through the snow!  We have had quite a bit of fun homebrewing with Weyermann rauchmalt but this experience will have us experimenting with it much more.  Awesome beer.

Had one of these from a bottle tonight.  The only thing I noticed on the label when I
bought this one was the word Marzen.  Imagine my surprise!  Sharp nose of hot-dogs, and
smoked pork chops.  A little much at first but calmed down somewhat after the brew had
a chance to breath.  Pours a dark garnet.  The average creamy off white head has fair
lacing and retention.  The flavor is primarily sweet.  The caramel malt is underlying an
intense grilled smoke tone.  Complex to be sure.  The medium body is creamy and soft. 
Though I can appreciate a much different style than Im used to, not really my cup of tea.

Bottle. Ridiculous (and delicious) heavy smoky aroma of burnt salami. Low carbonation lets charred wood flavors come through - very smooth mouthfeel lets smoky flavors linger. Flavor is much weaker than the nose, with some meaty malts. Honestly, such a huge aroma inundates all other aspects of the beer. If you like it, you love it.

Smokey bacon/ham scent... seriously.  Near black with red highlighting (I love that look in a beer).  Very strong unique smokey taste.  Hickory like.  Low Carbonation.  The smoked taste really sticks to the tongue and lingers.
Hazy brown color with a thin frothy off-white head. Aroma of sweet smoke. Flavor of smoke with hints of salt.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 Pours to a clean red-hued brown body with a light beige head.  The aroma is smoked black-pepper gouda cheese and burning paper.  The flavor is sorta strange.  Its like its trying to be a smoked cheese but also is pretty light.  Not really strong and smoky like I thought it would be.  Still, pretty unique and definitely drinkable.  The palate is lightly dry, smoky.

dark and clear copper color, tall thick foamy light tan head.  aroma is like smoky clothes after a night by the campfire.  kind of reminds me of waking up after burning man.  charred wood and paper smells.  flavor is malty smokin like Alex Smoke!!  for those not on the "Grime" tip, its smokin like Nightmares on Wax Smokers Delight.      You know, the smoked ham bit is not as strong as I expected, more of a background note. finish is a little bit burned hay.  nice beer for the beginning of spring thats still stuck in winter!
Smells exactly like smoked gouda.  Looks great, but taste is too much for me.  Very complex, yet very nasty... to me atleast.  Prob. wont buy again.

The bottle poured a beautiful clear deep ruby colored beverage with a medium smooth off-white head that was mostly diminishing but left good lacing on the glass. The aroma was WOW, smoked ham and hot dogs around a campfire. The malt producer must smoke hams in the same kiln they produce the malt in ... and good ham at that. The body was medium-full with smooth carbonation and a slightly slick, oily texture. The flavor starts off just like biting into a piece of smoked ham. I wonder if it is kosher. The finish was long and had a slightly smoked and bitter-sweet character.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2013 Bottle at Ship & Mitre, Liverpool.  I was looking through my ratings last night and I couldnt believe that I hadnt added this.  I think because I knew I had a bottle at home which I would rate.  But then I had the one at home and thought, "Oh I dont need to rate this, as I had it in Liverpool."  Fortunately I still have my notes from the Ship & Mitre.  Smokey bacon aroma, dark brown beer with beige head.  This is good, I mean good.  Like a dunkel in mouth with more smokey bacon on end.  Stunning.  And my first ever Rauch.  Re-rate at brewery, fantastic in mouth, just the fullness is amazing, so smooth too, effortless
Well I have to respect this beer even though I do not enjoy it. The amazing amount of smoke in this beer gives the expierence of drinking smoked ham. Not my taste but an interesting beverage.
Hazy brown color with a thin frothy off-white head. Aroma of sweet smoke. Flavor of smoke with hints of salt.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2010 1. Barrel Draught at the GBBF, Kensington Olympia 06/08/2003
Mid brown coloured with an extremely smoked aroma and flavour. Lasting bacon finish.
2. From a 5l Minikeg at Chris Os pre GBBF tasting, Kensal Rise 31/07/2010
Big smoked aroma. Mid brown coloured smooth and a little rich on the palate with a hint of bitterness in a smoky bacon flavoured malt finish.

500 ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with barely any head that amazingly manages to hold on throuhout the glass.  Heavy smoke aroma.  Smoke and more malts.  Heavy smoke on the flavor.  Smoked wood, smoked fish, and more smoke.  That classic Marzen flavor barely comes through in the finish.  Pretty good if you are in the mood for it.

Poured from bottle into shaker glass.  Nice dark brown color, tan head with decent retention. Excellent lacing. Aroma is nice and smoky sweet.  More subtle that some other smoked beers that overdo it.  Overall impression can be summed up in three words: rich, smooth, and smoky.  Not my favorite style but a quality brew.

This is different! The aroma is of kielbasa or smoked bacon. The head is creamy off white, fully diminishing with good lacing. The body is a deep red/brown. The initial flavor is a light bitter and the finish is a light bitter and the duration is long. The body is light to medium and the texture is almost creamy with light carbonation. This would be an excellent bier to have with stuffed grilled jalapenos and habeneros. We stuff them with Italian sausage, gouda cheese and cover with bacon and put on the grill for 45 minutes to an hour - Man would this be good with that!

A leathery smoke aroma and flavor dominate this brew in a good way. My favorite of the three Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbiers, this brew is not so sweet as the bock, but has a bit more girth than the weizen. Its a good middle ground and an excellent pairing with any steak or beef meal.

The smokebeer.  Ive heard so much about them so I had to track one down.  Pours a beautiful bronze colour with a long lasting tan head and decent lacing.  Being a smokebeer, theres no surprise the nose smells of smoke.  Wood smoke, like a campfire, and traces of leather, almost cheesy.  I know, it sounds disgusting, but it really does smell pretty nice.  Taking a mouthful, the smoke flavour persists in a malty, even bitterness straight through to the finish.  A very interesting beer like nothing Ive ever had before.  I liked it.  (500ml bottle)

Bottle:  Huge smoked cheese aroma and little if anything resembling a Marzen.  Pours a dark transparent amber with a small off-white head with decent retention.  Okay lacing.  Flavor is pretty much dominated by smoke as well with some notes of bacon.  Light caramel in the far background with some hints of Euro-lager in the finish that lingers slightly into the smokey aftertaste.  As it warms, some Marzen characteristics become noticeable, but still very subtle.
Smokey... Beer that tastes like ham.  how can you go wrong with that?  Nice dark color.  Nice malty flavor with smoke all throughout..  Not an every day beer but certainly enjoyable.

Bottle 500ml - Dark red colour with a thin white head that disapear quickly. This is all about smoke. The aroma reminds me of the time I was working as a chef and once a month we where receiving fresh smoked meats from a local "fumoir" there was this home made ham and smoked sausages, home made bacon...mmmmm!!! this is real wood smoke. The taste is of smoke, wood, toasted malts and a nice bitterness from hops. Not the most complex beer, but I love the experience. This is excellent with cheese.
Bottle. Nice dark amber colored beer with good head. Taste is smoke and sausage!!! Aroma is smoke and sausage as well. I almost did a rofl when i first tasted it :)
Looks like the Urbock, and tastes like a slightly weaker version. Still a great beer. Smoke smoke and smoke!

A dark, reddish brown beer with a thick, beige-white head. A distinctly smoky nose, an immediate hit of smoky wood, there is a slightly sweet, malty follow up, but this is engulfed by the initial smell. The taste is the same, dry and smoky, almost reminiscent of smoked bacon! The malty sweetness is just about recognisable towards the end. The aftertaste is long, dry, and slightly bitter.
Unlike any beer Ive ever tasted.  Smokey roasted flavor.  Medium body with light bitterness and a slight oily texture.  Worth trying.

Bottle pours a bright, deep-mahogany with a creamy, ecru head that holds and laces. While this beer conjures the same aromas as the <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/aecht-schlenkerl I tried recently ("smoked sausage or ham, charcoal, campfire"), the flavor and palate are more savory and refined. I find no chemical slant but instead I stumble across dark fruit in the flavor. The aftertaste is at once smoke and roasted malt, and a buttery note to the palate makes the meatiness of the beer simply mouthwatering. By far the best Rauchbier Ive tried.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Countryside, IL 60525<font size=-1>
smoky and smooth. would be good with BBQ or with some smoked cheese and crackers. I was hesitant to try this, but its a great beer

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2008 First ratingBottle at Bishops Arms in Sundsvall, Sweden. February 17, 2006.Dark red color and a white head.Very smokey, petey scent, lots of tar, smoked reindeer meat.Taste is very similar to the scent, lots of smoke.Perfect for rounding off an evening or with grilled food.7/5/7/3/15=3.7Had this so many times, but at last a rerate(Bottle from Systembolaget)On August 9, 2008Dark red color, white head. Smoke, sausage, reindeer meat scent. Taste goes around the same way, even more smoked sausage. Medium mouthfeel, medium to low bitterness. An aquired taste most likely, but sign me up for aquired then!8/4/8/3/16=3.9

Bottle. Creamy offwhite mostly lasting he
ad. Brown colour. Powerfull arona, you can feel the smoke. Also in the flavor. I fancy this beer.

Nice red apperance witha medium light brown head.  Heavy smoked aromas, similar to smoked ham or bacon, very nice.  Meat and malt flavors, again a smoked ham type quality, which combine very well with the hops.  Good smooth ending.

I just think its phenomenal what they can do with malts and whatever else went into this beer.  Its insane.  Like chewing on a meat lovers pizza (minus the cheese and crust).  Very very smoked.. like summer sausage actually.

I love this liquid smoky link...and thats coming from a vegetarian.   Intense smoke/bacon/smoky link/roasted malt/wood barrel/caramel/and on and on.  Pairs wonderfully with spicy foods like Cajun or BBQ or smoked cheeses.   Brilliant effort.

Bottle from the LCBO. Wow, now this aint exactly your ordinary, run of the mill beer. Just imagine soda water, bacon, and pipe tobacco poured into a blender! Haha ok, thats an exaggeration, but you get the drift. I was bracing myself to be fully disgusted by this based on the account of a fellow beer snob friend of mine, but much to my shock I didnt recoil in horror with my face distorting into all sorts of unpleasant expressions upon the first sip. If anything, I wound up finding this an interesting, surprisingly drinkable take on the concept of beer, if not exactly delicious. This experimental beer strikes me as something typically German, and my timing couldnt have been better as I drank it along to a meal of sauerkraut, dumplings, and pork hock! Needless to say, it fit in beautifully given the context and I actually enjoyed it. Still, its more of a novelty beer that I wouldnt drink with any real regularity. Id save it for moods when Im craving something different.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 Very smokey, hickory bacon aroma. Like huffing a charcoal grill. Works well for the aroma but a little too much in the taste. Certainly unique but really you taste nothing more than the intense smokiness.

This beer is bottled bacon.  Everything about it is smokey.  Pours dark mahogany with a decent tan head.  Aroma is...smoked bacon.  The taste is...smoked bacon.  There is some decent malt flavor and it does drink very smoothly.  I might have this again if Im having meat and cheese for dinner.  It is pretty good, but I cant really see drinking this on a regular basis.
Bottled. smells like an accident with a fire place. Golden dark brown colour. smoked flavour. smoked bitter aftertaste.
smells like beef fuckin jerkey, hardcore beef jerkey.  kind of smooth up front with a huge meaty vibe to it, just like beef jerkey. very smoked jerkey at that. weird. dogs should drink this shit.

50cl bottle. Clear mahogany colour with a fair lasting creamy head. An overwhelming smoked aroma makes it difficult to smell anything else. Reminds my a bit of smoked meat or sauces. Quite light, a bit oily and easy drinkable beer actually, but the smell is almost to much. A loooong smoked finish. Definitively a very nice experience.

Pours a deep reddish brown with thin bubbly off-white head that fades down to swirls. Nose is very smokey almost like a camp fire kind of smell. Flavor is at first a little sweet, then comes the same smokiness from the nose, all in all the smoke aroma and flavor is pleasing, just hangs around a little too long. Give me this beer and some fresh grilled meat and Id be in heaven.

So similar to the weizen.  Cant pretend to claim like most that I actually enjoy them.  Just too smokey and burnt up in your face.  You should definitely partake & sample  these as oft remarked they are interesting & unique.

Schlenkerla Rauchbier pours to a beautiful, bright, deep mahogany color with a thick tan head and a good bit of carbonation. The nose is pungent with waves of salty, and smoky malt aromas. The palate is firm with lots of big flavors of smoke, salt, and bacon. Schlenkerla finishes with more of those intense salty and smoky flavors, then ends with a dry and sooty finish that lingers on the tongue. 

A phenomenal rauchbier, and a classic example of the style. As with the Spezial, the aromas and flavors are just so much fresher and brighter than the bottled and exported draught versions we get in the US. You cant go wrong with any version of this beer, but to enjoy half liter after half liter of this beer in the Altstadt, and in Bamberg, is really something special for a beer lover. As much as I love this one, it is not for everyone. Some beer drinkers just cant get past the smoke in this beer, and find the aromas and flavors just too much. But for those who love this style, Schlenkerla is as world class, as a beer can get. This one works extremely well with hearty German fare, and is a wonderful beer to just drink and enjoy.

I think I know why most users like this one. But I cant really say I like it. I felt it was drinking a german sausage cocktail. Not exactly tasty. More smoke than that, and the house is on fire. But very smooth to drink.

Thanks to BierBauch for this one.  1pt 0.9oz bottle.  Lots of smoke in the aroma, reminds me of smoked fish or cheese.  Pours a dark brown with a medium white head.  Drinking this is similar to drinking pure liquid smoke with some malty caramel tastes.  I liked it though the smoke, I thought ,was a little over the top.

bottle at BierStube in Moline.  definitely a smoked beer.  aroma was all about the smoke.  looked like a marzen, but the flavor was like the smell in your clothes after sitting on the wrong side of a campfire.  still a nice change of pace from what I usually drink.

first "smoked" beer for me!!! it had a one deminentional smokey aroma reminiscant of smoked mozzorella.  color was aa murky brown and head was white.  it seemed to be a very thin beer pouring it and drinking it. flavor was mostly smokey and yet at times it tasted salty almost. some caramel malt nots were present but not effective.   real smooth and easy to drink.

(500 ml bottle: $3.50 at Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA) With the powerful aroma of smoked meats, especially ham, you know exactly what this beer is going to be about just on one quick sniff.  I cant pick up anything else in the nose, but then again, I dont have the most sensitive sense of smell.  While the flavor is most certainly very smoky, the lightly sweet and caramely malt is there initially, but tends to get lost very quickly because the smoke really picks up and finishes very strongly.  So the only chance to really taste the malt is immediately after sipping the beer, and only when the beer warms up.  Otherwise, its lightly roasty, somewhat bitter, and the smokiness makes for a slight harshness in the finish (but in a good way).  Body is medium, but just seems thin for how much flavor this beer is packing.  Carbonation is about average for beer, but keeps the smokiness from weighing down the palate.  Deep amber in color with excellent clarity.  Over an inch of light tan head forms on the pour, gradually settling to a thin but complete layer, leaving patchy lacing behind in the process.  All in all, very enjoyable, especially the lingering smokiness on the palate.  Although I think I enjoyed the flavor of the Märzen a bit more than the Weizen, the Weizen had more complexity.  The smoke and caramely malts of the Märzen seem to go hand in hand, but the wheat offered more of a counterpoint to the smoke.
Smokey malt bacon aroma. Clear dark brown colour with fair head and lacing. Burnt smokey flavour. Fizzy palate.

Pours black, little ring of foam on the outskirt. Smoky smell reminding of a Hygrade smoked sausage; in the mouth, the first contact is a lot smoother than the nose was leading to believe, almost disapoointing in it smoothness, oh, in  the aftertase, the smoke finally appears, followed by some mild bitterness and then by some more smoke. Overall, smoother to the mouth than the nose led to believe.

22 Nov 05 - Big smokey bacon aroma.  Dark brown-red colour, suds lacing and a good head.  Big smokey bacon malt flavour.  Bitter medium mouthfeel with lingering smokiness.  Great smoke beer but not to my taste.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2007 Pours a deep amber.  Very good sized off white head develops.  Aroma is HUGE of woody, smokey cheese and summer sausage.  Unlike any brew Ive ever smelled before.  Flavor is not quite as smokey, though it is still very smokey.  There is some faint roastiness in there, but then the smokey cheese and sausage takes over.  I gotta say, this is one strange beer.  Interesting though, and I like it simply because it has shown me something extremely and unexpectedly unique.  Good in small amounts, I wouldnt want another full bottle to myself.
Bottle. Ultra smoky. Thinnish body, nice finish. Dont know if I like this or the Urbock version better, but this is a good beer.

Thanks for the prompt hl. This was one of the beers I tasted in Europe lat year and overlooked in my ratings. I had this with the Urbock and so it was a mini smokefest of a tasting. Great deep amber appearance and good firm head. The nose? Well what else? It smells like my barbie when there is a beer can chicken on the go and hickory chips smouldering on the side. Great smoky flavour with little else being able to come through. I reckon this is one of those beers that should sponsor Blokesworld. I think the ladies would love this as much as the shows pole dancing competition and the customised car section.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: I half-suspect that if you shat in a glass, these blokes could add smokemalt, ferment it and come back with something tasty. Damn, theyre good. This one doesnt quite match the Urbock IMO, but its still a superb beer. Teak colour with a fat layer of foam that painted the glass beige on the way down. Theres a depth and intensity to their smokemalt that no other rauchbier (that Ive sampled) matches. This has a rich aroma of hickory, oak cask, smoky bacon crisps and a meaty Christmas ham note. Doesnt quite live up to the promise of the aroma. There was a hint of acetone and lemonade in the first sip before the smokemalt took over. Then it developed typical rauch burnt wood flavours, long and dry in the finish. For a rauch, this is ridiculously sessionable. Medium bodied and very rounded. Has anyone here done a tasting of all the Aecht Schlenkerla range side by side? If so, please beermail me - Id be interested to read the results. (500ml bottle, IBS Perth, bb June 06)

Very surprised Ive never rated this.  Deep ruby amber, crystal clear.   Moderate to strong wood smoked bacon aroma, touch of malt sweetness.  Some bitter hops, medium to full-bodied.  Woody smoky flavor, malty too, theres some heft to this.  A touch of minerally water in the smokey finish.  This is the stuff.  Im likely seriously underrating this.
It has a firm smokiness from its aroma though its palate to its clean, dry, long finish. Its aroma and flavous ara a shock at first but this style marries perfectly with smoket ham or sausages.

Bouteille de 500 obtenue par le service dimportation privée de lInstitut de la Bière. Arôme: Forte odeur de fumée. Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de fumée très présent et de noix. La durée de larrière goût est moyenne. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture minérale. Leffervescence en bouche est moyenne. Présence de fumée en arrière goût. (Rating #396)
First smoked beer Ive ever had.  It actually does make you think of a campfire and bbq.  I wouldnt classify it as wheat but Im no expert.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2005 Nice dark copper color with a big off-white head.  Beautiful big smoky aroma which recalls a campfire.  Taste is a bit malty, fine but not terribly flavorful  Body is a bit thin.  A good, drinkable smoke beer.
