red/dark brown body, thin, light tan head.  SMOKY, satly and sausagey, just like Schwai's venison Jerky!  Dry and sausagey flavor, like a hanging venison sausage more than jerky as far as taste goes

Pours amber with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet smoke.  Like a brown sugar cured ham.  Flavor is similar.  Starts very sweet, caramel and honey.  Strong smoke flavor follows.  It took about a quarter of the bottle to get used to the smoke.  Then I could appreciate the contrasting flavors.  The swwet dominated the start of every taste while the smoke was equally dominate in the finish.  Very strange, but nice.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2005 Nice dark brown in color... 

Like Lapsang Souchong tea? Well I do, and it smells just like it... FANTASTIC smoked scent that I wish they made Yankee Candles of.

Taste... ahh that is Lapsang Souchong. Gorgeous. Smooth, mellow, refreshing, and rich. This is it folks... this is the taste I have been longing for.

Damn good beer.

Bottle.  Chestnut brown with an enveloping aroma of beechwood smoke.  Full and malty, with a pervasive smokiness and earthy dryness that lingers on the palate.  Some people like this beer right away.  It took me several bottles.  Once you get acquainted with its unique character, though, youll say to yourself: Damn this is a good beer.

Bottle from The Offie, Leicester. This is so special it really should be my 200th beer, but hey ho! that's the way it goes. Big charcoal aroma. Dark chestnut colour, with a quickly receding head, which leaves a patchy residue on top, and spidery lacing. Huge initial meat flavour, but with the odd speck of sugar. Malt and watery taste at the end, once the bar-b-q flavour has subsided some. This is like a meal - I wouldn't be able to drink much of it in a single session, but it is a delicious speciality, and still surpisingly crisp, due to it's thinnish mouthfeel. Nice lingering taste too.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2006 October 2005 - Dark brown body with a small beige head. Massive smokey, nitratey, sweet smoked meat like note. Smoke is mildly less prominent than aroma, similar character throughout. I cant really get too far past the smoke to the underlying beer. Dry finish. Average palate. Just really does not do it for me. 4/3/3/3/12 - 2.5

January 2004 - Extremely smokey aroma emminates from the dark burnt amber bodies brew like the campfire smell that invades your clothing after a long camping trip. Flavour is malty with smoke sausage like qualities, with a long lingering aftertaste. Dont like it... Smoked is not for me, four guys couldnt finish this bottle. 4/3/3/3/5 - 1.8

Man I know this beer is highly rated but I just can't get past the whole campfire stompin's in my mouth taste. I swear though I could almost taste an okay beer underneath it all. It did look ok in the glass.
The Mother of all smoked beers, just taste the fine balance between malt flavour

Dark umber with a quickly dissipating, frothy, offwhite head. Aromas of a smouldering campfire accompanied by subdued malt and the faint sting of alcohol. The taste of smoke is surprisingly subtle with malt sweetness coming to the forefront followed closely by a balancing bitterness. Lingering malt sweetness is accentuated by a fine carbonation which makes for a refreshing mouthfeel. Thoroughly enjoyable after playing with the kids in the snow.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2007 2003 bottle.  Good ruddy, red-brown pour with some lighter oranges as well.  Big creamy light-mocha colored head that sticks on top for most of the beer.  Lots of lacing.  Smells of sweet malt, slight smoked woodiness.  No sediment of any sort and mostly clear, or I would have given it a 5 for appearance.  Taste starts out with a semi-sweet, ultra balanced marzen flavor; light honey, good nutty hops, caramel malt.  The smokiness comes on in the middle and slowly builds into a wonderful finish of smoke, smoke and more smoke.  Like smoking a nice cuban while eating a bacon, and smoked gouda sandwich on brown bread (ok no one actually does that, but you get the point).  Smoke is not subtle, but I did enjoy the fact that the flavors were layered and the marzen flavor was there at the start.  Medium body, didnt get any thinning. Light carbonation, good stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 Deep maroon under a tan cream.  Smoky, tarry aroma, softly coniferous with thick malts and spicy caraway.  Dark chocolate before the sweetness of oily rye bread; bitter spices fade into a lingering tobacco aftertaste and building smokiness.  Velvetyalmost oilygood attenuation, pinpoint carbonation.

Satisfying and continually refreshing; a quaffable contemplative pint.

50 cl bottle, best before November 2008.

Rerated on 11 January 08.  Much different than my experience many beers ago.  Sure, theres still plenty of smoke -- rich and sultry -- but refined, bready malts can easily be detected behind the glowing, ashy remnants of a previous evenings campfire.  Light mineral presence in the aroma along with barely noticeable earthy hops.  Rich, light brown hue with a medium, frothy, khaki head.  The flavor is smoky and dry throughout with a malty, almost toffee-like, sweetness in the background.  Feels a bit acidic, or perhaps its just the smoke playing tricks on my tongue.  Iodine and Bakelite notes emerge with some warmth.  I still get a little bit of fruitiness from this one, but it seems more like pears this time around.  A bit of smoothness is gained from a little more warmth.  Medium bodied with an oily texture and moderate carbonation.  A little experience has gone a long way in my enjoyment of this beer.  Previous score of 7,4,7,3,14=3.5.

50 cL bottle, goblet.  No real Märzen qualities show themselves in the aroma.  Theres lots of smoke, but nothing nasty like liquid smoke.  Even though its absurdly over the top, its quality.  A thick, creamy, white head is short and sits on a deep maroon body.  Moderately sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly astringent finish.  Theres actually some nice caramel-apple Märzen flavors under the smokiness.  Hard to tell too much about it though.  Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: its good, but do I have to like it?

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2004 RE-RATE: My opinions on the aroma and flavor of this beer have changed quite a lot since I gave it an overall of 6 out of 20 some time ago.  Pours a clear maple syrup brown, with a large but diminishing foamy off white head.  Leaves a good lacing. 

Smells strongly of smoked meats, salt, hints of ripe apples underneath, and a touch of light floral sweetness.  Yummy.    

The flavor to me is reminiscent of a stout, but definately not the same thing.
There is some light honey sweetness, good maltiness, and of course, the smoke, with a nice bitterness in the long finish.

The mouthfeel is of medium thickness, with fine tingling carbonation.

Sometimes I might rate the flavor and palate and overall score a point higher or lower, but today, this is how I re-rate this beer.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2006 This beer definitly smells like meat and I drank it with some meat and they went well together.  Drank brown color with a hint of amber coloring.  Has very little head.  This beer isnt thick but still satisfying to the taste. 8/3/8/8/16 BR>Rerate.  Ahh the youthfull ratings.  but this is a standard in my house and a lovely berr altogether.  The reason i sit to rerate is I got to try this on tap at the Hop Devil Grill.  Well, all the smokiness is exaggerated and the beer really does seem fresher.  Its a very silky smokiness with some sweetness to it.  A beautiful extremely dark brown color with just a bit of brown translucence.  Whats there to say its just freaking a good ass smoke and even better on tap. 9/4/8/3/18
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 14, 2004 This may seem odd but my main comment is a warning to vegetarians, or simply those who don't like the smell of meat: don't try this beer. I tried to rate this beer objectively according to the quality I felt it offers but it is difficult for me to get past the meaty aroma and taste. Aside from my own reaction though I have to say this seems like an incrediblely well-crafted smoked beer. Campfire and smokehouse waft out of the bottleas soon as the cap is off of it and it doesn't relent. You'll feel like you are curing pepperoni or salami as you look into this deep brown beer. An acquired taste I would say....

Tawny red colour with soapy-looking head. The aroma is delicious, oysters and woodsmoke. Starts off almost meaty, but a bit thin on the palate. This is an excellent pairing with a lot of foods, and certainly something a bit different.

Dark auburn color with curling tendrils of head. High carbonation is evident through sporadic firing of bubble salvos up through the liquid. Aroma is a complex smokiness underpinned by cocoa, ovaltine, hickory, and walnuts. Flavor is sweeter than one might expect (although not really given the marzen base), and starts sweet while finishing quite dry. Charred meat, campfire, and burning sugar types of smokiness are all present. Some hop presence, but this is scared off by the bitter, smoky astringency. Interdigitated malt structure (caramel, pecans and molasses) comes through the wall of flavors. Overcarbonation keeps this beer from being all it could be (problem remedied ad hoc by decanting beer and leaving in fridge for 30 minute or so).

The head when poured had a darker toffee colour. Not the best head, disappeared quickly. Heavy hickory scent and taste. Small amount of toffee and roasted coffee. Very slight burnt malt taste on top of the hickory. Hard to find anything past the hickory flavour.

Bottle, imported.

My first rauchbier, so take it for what it's worth.

Dark brown color, almost opaque.

Initial nose is instantly a musty, pungent smoke aroma, like a damp campfire from the night before, followed by a solid maltness like that of a doppelbock.

The cream colored head is cmposed of fine bubbles, but it fades quickly leaving a residual ring at the side of the glass and bits of brussels lace on the sides of the glass.  I had to pour aggressively to get any head at all.

The taste is first and foremost heavy smoke--not bitter and acidic like liquid smoke, but like a smoked brisket--deep, subtle and flavorful.  There's a bit of maltiness to it as well, but not as much as there is in the nose.  The smoke dominates everything, leaving an enduring smoky aftertaste.

A good, solid beer.  I can see why some people like rauchbier so much.

Time to hunt down a steinbier!
A very nice beer.  Goes well with Barbeque.  This is one I wish came in half cases here in the US.  I'd drink a lot of them.

Clear deep orange-red beer with an off tan, thin head. Smokey/malty nose that says German lager. Smooth malty/smokey flavor. Full body lends itself to the smoke. Every time I have a beer made by these guys, I am impressed by how well it is made. Prost!
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: The aroma took me back to camping, and sitting around a dying fire.  The beer had a brownish/dark amber color to it with a whiteish head and a bit of lacing.  The flavor was like that campfire smoke again.  Very intersting taste indeed.  The finish was smooth and left just a hint of smoke in my mouth.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark amber color with a thin white head.  Has a strong smoked sausage aroma and flavor with a dry finish.  Reminds me of a BBQ.  Very unique.

Very smoked. I seldomly taste a beer that i dont like, but this one i couldn't drink. It has a very smoked taste that totally dominate the beer. A lttle smoke is good, but this is to much. For the first time in many years i had to throw out half the beer.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2004 Wow!  I was really surprised by the powerfully intense smokey flavour.  I split a bottle with a friend and I could barely get through it.  Maybe next time I'll pair it with some food.  Really needed something to cut through the lingering smokey taste in my mouth.  Will definitely try this and other smoked beers.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2004 (Bottled) Dark amber color with a small lacy head. A strong, sweetish aroma of smoked ham and hops. Sweetish, strong, smoked-malt flavor. Medium-bodied, somewhat carbonated, but very smooth palate. Oily, smoky finish. Maybe slightly sweeter and easier to drink than the Urbock, but pretty much lighter in body. At its best when only slightly chilled, IMHO. A top-class smoked beer.

Markable better than the more common Weizen Rauchbier. This one is just as intense in the smoke aroma and flavor departments, but perhaps more drinkable. This brew has a pure, sweet-malty backbone. Color is a clear, medium ruby amber. Enjoy!

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2006 You smell the aroma of an old fashoin smoke house as soon as you start pouring this,taste was like smoked summer sausage. It had a smooth mouthfeel, the heavy smoke taste did seem to recede a little. This would be great to eat with jerky or sausage, you appreciate it more with each glass

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2007 this is the smokiest brew Ive ever had.  Pours a burnt brown in color with an off-white head.  Tastes of oak and smoked salmon are prominent. A great beer that is probably good with with food, but a little too much smoke flavor for drinking.

Ok this is going to be a challenge,,this style seems to drivde beer drinkers.
Comes in old fashioned brown pint bottle with parchment style label.
Wow this is one beautiful looking beer ,dark brown with deep ruby accents, toppedby a massive frothy off white head..the head shrinks but persists wonderfully.
MM lovelly smokey aroma like lightly smoked Scottish salmon..or venison..very appetizing.
Wonderful taste..i like the dry smokiness it leaves on the back of my mouth..i can taste some nicely roasted malts beneath..but no hops to speak of, maybe the smokiness covers them..but this is good stuff.
Very smooth for a start on the tongue then the great rough smokieness takes over..great.
WEll I am happy to say I am in the ranks oif those that like Smoked beer..this was a great.will try more of this style.
Most remarkable achievement since the barbecue potato chip. How did they do it? On paper, it sounds absurd, but it works.
Smells and tastes like smoked meat.  I'm not much of a fan of this smoked style of beer but, I think this beer represents its style perfectly.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2005 Bottle. Pours deep mahogany with a medium frothy brown head. Nose is very smoky and meaty. Dark malts, burning wood, smoldering earth, and a smoked sausage hint. The burnt wood seems to stand out more that I recall. Taste is smoky malts, burnt wood, lighter notes of smoked meat, light spices and hints of smoked cheese. The body is medium with moderate carbonation and a lingering smokiness. Finmish is light smoked meats and cheese with dark malts, light sweetness, and smoldering wood. Much better than I recall. Perhaps, originally, I wasnt ready for it.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2010 The beer pours reddish copper in a Don de Dieu glass. Nice foamy head, it diminishes pretty fast though, but holds the glass fairly well. Surprising aroma, definitely a new class for me, meaty with bacon and ham, salty sausages. The flavors developments are quite unrivaled. Let me explain.. first that intense smokiness (long dry smoky/bitter finish)is kind of a guardian over the journey that tasting this beer is. Its also one of the not so typical beers that holds the 4 basic flavors. Mouth entrance is very malty and moderatly sweet with the body being medium to full. Then, those smoked malts develop into a salty (bacon is salty after all) taste. Slightly tart at the same time. The finish is intense and bitter, woody, earthy, peaty. I wouldnt drink this everyday, but I can see this doing wonders paired with multiple meals (pancakes, poultry, pepper beef etc.) I changed my mind and would definitely drink this everyday. An everyday intensely smoked and highly drinkable beer that goes well with most meals just as much as by itself. Blimey, if it aint a 5

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2003 This is certainly a new beer drinking experience. Aroma is smoked ham, bacon. and salami. Appearance is dark brown bordering on black. Flavor is of dark malt and a variety of smoked meat. A cookout or a meat lover's pizza in a bottle. I can see people being weirded out by this experience but I think its an excellent beer even better than Stone's Smoked Porter.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2014 Draught at the brewpub. Hazy amber beer with a nice offwhite head. Smoked fruity aroma, malty, hay, vanilla notes. Smoked flavor, grassy, hay, bready, roasted notes. Smoked floral finish with grassy notes, hay, vanilla, roasted notes and some cream.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2005 Very heavy smoke aroma. A true bacon-beer. Very dark but clear reddish-brown with a finger of fully-diminishing large-bubbled white head. Some lacing. Initial smoky flavour gives way to a wonderful supporting maltiness in this medium/light bodied marzen. Aftertaste is all smoke. A very enjoyable beer although I think the smoke may be a bit over the top for some. Not your everyday lawnmower beer. Bottle.

Deep amber. Nice head. Smoky smell as soon as I openend the bottle. Initial taste like smoky bacon. Then I was able to taste the full-bodied, malty Märzen underneath the smoke.  Smoky and slightly hoppy finish. I love this beer. Since it lacks any bitterness and sourness, it goes down so easily that you have to ration the beer in your stein. Or you just get another one from the fridge.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2003 A tad smokier than their Urbock, and much smokier than the Weizen. Color is a very dark red, nearly black. The aroma is bacon. Seriously, it just smells like bacon, and little else. Hints of ham or other meats maybe, but not much of the usual malt/hop aromas of non-smoked beers. The flavor is also very meaty. I enjoyed the flavor, but the problem is that there isn't much of a hop presence, or even maltiness, to balance the smoke... so it really just tastes like smoke in a bottle. If you're in the mood for a beer like this it's great, but if you're not it's a bit too intense. I prefer the Urbock.

Dark amber colored with a tan head. Aroma of smoky bacon and sausage as soon as you pop the top. Smoky flavor as well along with malt and a hoppy aftertaste. Medium bodied. Very enjoyable, but you can only have it once in a while.

Pours a deep brown with small white head. Sharp aroma of smoke.  Hrm, flavor of smoked fish. Yeah, this is the first smoked I've had, and I'm not too impressed. I guess if you don't like smoked food, stay away from smoked beers.

A very nice dark amber coloring with a little lite head, that is very think but manages to stick around.  Aroma is very smoked and salty.  The flavor is nicely smoked and not over the top and slightly peppery.  This one would go really well with food, sausages, bangers and mash, etc...Nicely malty with hops in the aftertaste.  Very enjoyable.

dark ruby red with an orange tint appearance when held to the light...thin head, some nice lacing. i just dont detect any smoke to this one. riiiiiight! this bastard is loaded and loaded with smoke. surprisingly i can get some maltiness through the smoke, but not a lot. flavor is full of smoke and i can detect a bit of the hops in finish..but ultimately, this is a big bottle of smoke..too much i think.

#200. Deep brown colour with lots of mostly diminishing, lively, frothy, off-white head. Hickory, smoky, gouda, and bacon aroma. Hickory and smoked bacon remains in the flavour, with a touch of coffee, a lingering smokiness, and a background sweetness. Dry mouthfeel, with a sort of chewiness different than what you would find in a stout. Very good, balanced flavours, and a smoky touch that's not overpowering. Thanks Josh.

Pours a clear deep auburn red, no lacing but a nice sized head. Aroma is deliciously smokey like a really nice sausage or salami, maybe even salmon. Flavor has the perfect amount of smoke in it with some nice complexities of crystal malt. I don't know about a 5 Oakes, but this beer is pretty damn good. If you really like smoked meat or jerky, you'll like this beer. If not, well, you make your own conclusions. I could drink this for hours on end, it is relaxing and smooth once you really get into this bottle.

OK so now what, I think I have finally found a style I do not like.  The kids said it smelled like a camp fire, I think it tasted like burnt shishcabobs--you know so burnt that you could taste whether it is beef or vegetable.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Medium, short lasting light brown head. Dark red-brown colour. Powerful aroma of smoked ham, bacon etc., also malt. Flavor likewise but less powerful, nice balance and good mouthfeel. Very nice.

Dark amber colored and a moderate head. Smoky aroma, smelled like meat, beef. The flavor was smoky with a mildly sweet maltiness, a touch of bakers chocolate, and it seemed oily. Finished dryish and slightly bitter. The upfront smoky nature put me off at first, but it is quite good when you get used to it.
very well done.  Love the malt flaver with the smokey flavor.  Very tasty on the palate.

Pours a clear brown with a thick off-white head. Beautiful aroma of smoked German sausage. Initial taste is also like very smokey german sausage but after a few sips the flavour doesn't seem as strong. Definately one of those beers that you can only drink 1 a day. An interesting beer that would probably be poured down the drain by your typical macro beer drinker.

This beer pours a brown color with minimal head and lacing.  The aroma is the weirdest that I've noticed - smells like honey hickory smoke barbecue sauce - wonderful aroma.  The taste wasn't very good though.  It tasted just like it smelled, but for some reason the taste wasn't good at all.  Can't say much more, but the taste was terrible.

Very, very dark brown and ruby. Pale  and large bubbly, nice lacing. Beautiful aroma of smoke, bratwurst, tar and burnt wood. Taste of smoked sausage and tar-pastilles in malty body. Long smokey finish. Delicate beer but one bootle per eve is just enough.

Huge head, dense and irregular.  Beautiful sausage aroma, gentle and so enjoyable.  Good head retention with deep amber color.  Fun to sip, to get that chewy smokiness that makes you want to eat it or dinner. (gravity pour at GBBF 2003)

My first thought when I tried this beer was of smoked cheese.Love lts dark appearance and the lingering smokey taste that hits your mouth like an exploding cannon ball.Very dark for a Marzen and a beer that you either love or hate athough I personally think its really weird to hate it! Give it a try.

This is really a strange beer: it's not the first smoked beer I've drunk, but I'v never found a beer that has a so strong smoked aroma and taste. The flavour is a little bit salty and spicy and reminded me smokd ham. Really particular, but good, very good!
Dark brown and a big lacing dark head. Lots of smoke in aroma. Taste with salt and a hint of sour feets. Try it!

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004 i love this beer.  when i first had it, i was shocked at the aroma and flavor(s), but once you overcome them, it is a truly unique and delicious experience.   one of my favorites and highly recommended.
great as it warms up

The aroma is the smokiest I've ever smelled.  Like a steak.  Fairly dark color, tan thin head.  As jskendzel described it to me," like drinking a steak."  However, I prefer to eat my steaks.  Smoked beers I think need a little sweetness to be good, but this bottle does not.
Normally, I eat beef jerky after a few beers and it tastes great.  However, when the beer tastes like beef jerky, it undermines the whole experience.

The intense woody smoke flavor and aroma is great.  This is a truly interesting beer not for the novice.  The malty smoke flavor and aroma are not something I could drink much of, but when I do I really enjoy it.  This beer would accompany cheese and anything spicy well.

Never let it be said that one could get hammered on a Schlenkerla. Smokiness is deep, but makes for one of the most flavorful beers of a lifetime. Excellent as a meal, but I would never try more than one in a row. Almost needs a chaser, but man, what a tasty brew. Marzen had a bit of a bacon aftertaste (sounds odd, but well worth it).

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Sampled on tap at the brewery-pub
A very dark beer for a Marzen, a dark amber in color.  This one is quite dry tasting, with a very pronounced smokiness to it.  The dryness seems to accentuate and focus your tastebuds upon the smoke flavor.  This beer has quite a good amount of Body, a certain fullness that comes through even though it is quite dry tasting.  There is not much in the way of hop flavor, which is good, as it allows the subdued malt and smoke to come through.

Mahogany color, small off-white head. Had a very meaty aroma and flavor. kinda smelled like a ham or bacon.  Imparted a distinct woody/smokey flavor similar to that of liquid smoke. A little on the watery side.   This was my first smoked beer. Unique, but enjoyable.
Bottle: Deep smoke in the nose, took me by surprise. Dense, creamy, and lingering head. Smoke and assertive malt up front. Dry. Clean finish. Leaves some smoldering embers well after it's gone.

dark brown colour (mahogany?), short lasting head with some lace. fantastic smoked aroma.
taste is a flavour explosion. super smooth!
Ruby brown. Aroma of bacon or smoked meats. Good balance, dry and smoky but not overpowering in the smokiness, I also detected a slight nutiness
Scent of smoked ham or bacon. Big smoky taste. Reminiscent of a slaughter house I once visited in BC.  Dark ruby colour, little or no head.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2003 Bottled.
A very special beer. Smoky, meatsmelling and tasting.
I wouldn't drink more than half a bottle at a time...

(o,5 ltr bottle) Hmmm... BAMBERG! Quick dissipating white head and a beautiful mahogany-brown body. Scent of beef jerky. Smooth, smoked malt flavour. Medicinal to my sore throat. Hickory flavour. Mmmm. So smooth...
Quite decent, dark rich amber with a good head. Somewhat meaty cold cut but good cold cuts. Lots of smoke. Quite decent.

(bottled) Dark reddish brown & crystal clear.  Strong smoke aroma, underlying malt, and salami??  Malty, medium-bodied and duh, smoky.  Smoke dominates the entire experience but the underlying other qualities of the beer somehow manage to almost balance it.  I'm rating this beer (as all the others) not on my personal preferences, but what the brewers intended. Seems like you love it or don't: I'll need a few more bottles to make up my mind.

Pours a clear reddish/brown, large tan head that slowly recedes to leave thick lacing.  Aroms is strong with smoke, bacon, and some saltiness.  Flavor starts of a bit sweet, middle comes the smoke, end is long and lingering with a smoked bacon flavor.  Body is medium, fairly slick, minimal carbonation present.

RERATE 10 july 03:
Just returned from bamberg this beer is fantastic. Even better from oak casks. Low carbonation but still refreshing and smoked at the same time. Incrediblely intense and complex. 
The smoke is well balanced and not too overwhelming. Very nice. I tried this together with big onions filled with meat in a Rauchbier Marzen sauce. Incredible. It should be compulsory for any school class in Germany to wisit the unique brew pub.

Bottled. My first Rauchbier and its been very nice indeed. This beer leaves no doubt as to whether its been smoked or not. Dark amber colour with slight reddish hue. Strong white head that was almost lacy. Big smoked aroma. Big smoked flavours which were shy to begin with but that came on and swam around in your mouth quite some time. Im sure those Rouchbier devotees could tell what it was smoked with, but here continues the path to wisdom and liver destruction.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2003 Being a vegetarian, it's hard to tell that this has the taste of Bayonne ham but so they say. Color is amber and the head is quite poor. Smokey aroma, smells like bacon or so. Somewhat bitter finish. A funny beer to drink...

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004 I could smell the embers immediately upon opening. Wow! Super smoky and much more than the Weizen I tried recently. Dark and brown reminds me of a glass of coke with the ice melted. Same exact color. Short fluffy head but dissapears quickly. Taste is smoky, malty and sweet. I can't find any hops in this one. Again, aroma is real smoky like a smoked bacon or beef. I like this beer but I also am a fan of smoked foods. You'll most likely have to be in order to appreciate this style.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
Forget Kaiserdom, this is the one!
Big smokey bacon aroma, rich malt backdrop. Not one to drink all night, but certainly one to drink.

My first 'smoked' beer experience. I expected I wouldn't like this style of beer, however I actually liked the taste.
Strong bacon/meat aroma. Dark brown coloured, lasting head. Taste is a bit malty and bacon/meat like. Palate is likewise, moderate bitter.

All the salty aftertaste is crap.  Good beer when eaten with equally strong smoked foods, a touch of marzen sweetness with smokey flavor.  Would be great to use for a sauce for pork.  Not my taste entirely.
Awful stuff...  Reminds me of eating smoked fish, with the aroma and salty aftertaste.

I had the rauchbier weizen and was less than impressed. The smoke seemed stale and overpowered the rest of the beer. Here however, the smoke seemed to complement the beer more. I was reminded of grilled meat (of course not with a gas grill, those wastes of grills) and campfires. I could see this going well with a nice grilled steak or some fat grilled hamburgers, but I'm not so sure I could handle a lot of it.
Nose of campfire, smoked ham, also in the taste. Somewhat bitter finish. Had trouble finishing the bottle.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2004 Deep amber in color with a small frothy head. Excellent lacing. Aroma is that of smoke with grain. Flavor moderately sweet & bitter. Finish is slightly bitter. Im not sure I could drink this all the time, but I did enjoy it. The smokiness was not overpowering. I recommend having it with a meal, I had one with a fat ruben sandwich, excellent

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 This brew poured a small head of fine to medium sized light brown bubbles and a very dark brown, but still somewhat transparent, body. It has a very strong aroma of smoke about it and a very smooth smoky initial flavor that builds to an even stronger smoky finish. I rather liked it. The smoke was not too more for me as it was for some.

This brew poured a quick dissolving head and virtually left no lacing on the sides of my mug. It has a strong smoky aroma. It left an aftertaste. It poured a dark amber color. I just couldn't acquire a taste for this style of brew. The taste was just too smoky for me.

Bottled. If you like smoked beers, I don't mind them, this is the one for you. This was like drinking a campfire smell. Too overpowering for me. The taste was also to smoky. Poured and looked good but that was it.

I love this stuff.  Pours a deep dark brownish ruby colour.  Earthy smoke notes, like a campfire.  Nice sticky head.  Great mouthfeel, earthy smokiness, wood, dirt, campire.  A great brew with smoked foods.  A classic beer that everyone should have to try.

Dark brownish color, decent tan head, medium bodied, very smoked aroma, smelled like someone set the glass on fire, this was my first real rauchbier, the aftertaste tasted almost exactly like a Slim Jim, lots of smokiness in the flavors but especially the aftertaste

Dark amber body with a large and frothy head.  Incredible lacing.  Aroma is smokey all the way in a beef jerky sense.  Full bodied and chewy beer with a great bitter end.  The smokeiness last through the whole experience.

Dark brown and red color, medium size head. Smokey and malt aroma and flavor, light to medium body. Resembles smoked teas like lapsang souchong, and Laphroaig scotch. I enjoyed this more as I drank more and it warmed. First rauchbier, so I can't really compare it to others. Something I'd drink once in a while, but quite good anyways.

Brown to red in color, with a nice head that quickly disappears.  The aroma is quite smoky.  Barbequed pig, baked beans, a light campfire and a salt lick can easily be found in this.  Probably about as smoky as I can handle.  This just doesn't seem to be my style, but this was surprisingly drinkable.  I'm quite glad I made myself drink this, and not just because it's a beer.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2004 Appears brown at first but is actually a deep garnet red when held to a light. Thinnish white head leaves just a few tiny spots of lace. Aromatically, it certainly lives up to its Rauchbier name. Nose is intensely smokey and that's it. Reminds me of barbecue pork. Just a bit more going on in terms of flavor. Some acidic tartness, sweet malts, and of course loads of campfire smoke. Creamy mouthfeel reminiscent of a stout or full bodied porter. Just a touch of bittering hops in the finish. This has been quite a tasty intro into the world of Rauchbier.

This was just way too funky to express in words...basically one weird ass beer!!!! This one pours a deep brown color with a soapy white head. The aroma pretty much turned me off from the getgo...beef jerky, heavy salt, smokey malt, and roasted raisins predominate..its almost like this beer was marinaded overnight...not very inviting. The taste isnt bad if you can get past the beef jerky/salty aspect of the taste. Very thin body, little carbonation, but incredibly salty with little alcohol presence if any. I didnt quite understand the point of this beer...i feel no need to try this again.
Significantly sweeter than their UrBock. The smokiness dominated, but the malty sweetness rounded out things, and the beer left a malty aftertaste. Easier drinking than the UrBock. Nice.

(500 ml bottle). Well, any idiot can recognize that this beer has MORE aroma than (nearly) any other beer, and MORE flavour than a lot of beers. But to make a 100% honest rating, I have to ask myself: Do I actually LIKE the overpowering smell of smoked meat? Sadly, the answer is NO. I'm a beer drinker, not a goddamn sausage maker! The flavour is not quite as overpowering smoky as the aroma - at least you get a notion that you're drinking a beer and not just liquid smoked meat. Still, it tastes like something that has just been saved out of the burnt-out ruins of a brewery. Like any Marzen, it is quite light bodied (when you try to ignore the smokiness, of course). I probably have to admit that Rauchbiers are not my cup of tea - sorry, beer - but would still like to sample the Urbock as I imagine that a heavier beer would carry the smokiness better than a Marzen. Did I mention that this beer at least LOOKS good? - good head, beautiful dark copper colour.

Smokey aroma like baviarian smoked cheese.  Deep copper hue with small head.  Smoked malt taste with a long dry finish.  <y first smoked beer to date so the flavours were slightly shocking at first but this is a good beer.  Would go well with smoked cheese.  It seems a little thin beyond the smokeyness though

Nice malty and bigitme smoked aroma,big creamy head,nice dark amber color.Flavor is big and well smoked lightly malty,medium sweet,kind of watery in the texture the after taste is smokey ,malty.i mean what more can you say about a rauchbier it smoked and delicious as hell.A good accompaniment for samon or shellfish ,but not a brew that you would drink in large quantity ,the flavor would get to you i believe.

This stuff is a phenom.  The first taste is a bit of a shock.  Every one afterwards is a fix.  Have it with some nice salty crackers.  Beechwood reek and malt swirl together in perfect crisp harmony.  More!

I cant believe that i liked this beer this much.  normally i am not a fan of smoked beers but this one is done soo well.  the nose was at first overpoweringly smoky but then i started to enjoy the intricacies of it.  smoked gouda, salmon and beef jerky were all there.  the flavor was mild and plain except for the smoke which just as it did in the aroma became more interesting as i relaxed and enjoyed it.  it was a little watery but that worked well for this beer.  i would really enjoy this one at a bbq.

Pours a clear dark brown color with a big, off-white head that lingers. Wow! What an aroma, I can smell the campfire two feet from the glass. The aroma is strongly smokey, but attractive just the same. Medium body with low carbonation, the flavor is all malt with tones of smoke. The finish is long and smoke filled. Drinking this reminds me of roasting pigs on a barbecue or cooking bacon in the microwave. Excellent brew!
This is THE beer: unbelievable aroma of smoked meat, malty and smoky taste, incredibly long aftertaste.

- brown with a red hue and a creamy head that quickly dissipates, strong smokey aroma  bacon-like, very light hints of malt; smokey flavor with definite taste of bacon, lightly textured and dry, a tiny bit watery, smooth

wonderful smoky aroma, reminding me of a bbq pit.  dark reddish brown color with virtually no head. smoky tasting but not overwhelmingly so, as the underlying malt and hop character complement it well. Was a bit apprehensive to try this beer, as I didn't think it would be my thing. How wrong I was, a wonderful beer, that I will be revisting soon.

Very smokey aroma, almost overpowering, pours with a dark brownish hue with a small head, the taste has hints of Bavarian smoked cheese and smoked ham and there is an underlying maltiness, medium to full bodied and pretty good as well.

Non-existant head.  A very 'hammy' taste.  Color and aroma conjure up campfires, the flavor of the 'smoke' is a bit intense.  Very smooth, but the aftertaste is a bit on the sour side.  The smokey flavor is really overpowering when you happen to 'taste' it later.

Clear ruby amber with a moderate head. What an aroma. Visions of a toasty fire and beef jerkey dance through my head! Delightful smoky flavor with tasty malts and a faint bitterness. Medium mouthfeel with some wateriness and a dry finish. Excellent!

Thin small head.  Smoky bacon aroma (breakfast beer?).
Tastes like smoked ham.  Smooth.  Little hop aroma/flavor
--but that is not really part of style.  Dark amber colored.  
I like it.  Will drink again.
A good overall beer.  This is like the everyday version of smoked beers.  It has a good peat character and tastes like liquid pork at times.

This beer, while still retaining its smoked character, is much milder than other smoked beers I've had. Very well rounded smoked malt here...great mouthfeel. I was kind of expecting a blinding liquid smoke flavor I've seen before, but this is much mellower and more drinkable...I can still taste my dinner - instead of just the smoke.
A deep red beer with a good head. The aroma is tar and smoke dominated. And the flavor is very powerful and dominated by tar and smoke. Really a great beer.
Smoke and chocolate, dark roast coffee and some dirty stale water in a not so bad combination. To drink slowly, and not too much.

Medium brown, clear, super lacey head.  Lots of smoke (mmm...bacon) and malt in the nose.  Sweet, malty, delcious rounded smoke taste, very multilayered, stays with you for a minute or two, developing ...  I can smell the fire!  Absolutely to die for.

Superbly smoked nose; like rind of cured ham.Deep black-brown beer with fiery, reddish shine. Smoked taste as from smoked ham again, but also tobacco notes. mouthfeel nor cloying, nor meaty, yet marvellously chewy palate, (ful)filling. Only negative note - hence the lower overall rating - is the drinkability; ones enough!
UPDATED: MAR 18, 2004 Very good and interesting. The smoked flavour stays in your mouth for hours.
Sparkling amber brown. Smoky nose. Massively smoked palate covers up everything else

UGH!
Dark brown body with a tan head.
Overwhelming campfire aroma and taste.
If there was anything else in the aroma or flavor I couldnt find it!
Drain pour.

1/5/03:  bottle.  medium head which diminishes quickly with very little lacing.  nice red- brown leather colour.  overwhelming smoked bacon nose.  this beer tasted like greasy smoked bacon.  unfortunately i was unable to finish this beer because of the overpowering smell.  i guess i would rather eat a slice of bacon than drink an entire glass of it.

While this might be a good representative of the Rauchbier style it was too overwhelming for my palate.  The smokey taste and heavy oak/hickory flavor was too dominant to enjoy this beer.  I suspect it would improve with more aging (although mine was already past the the bottle date.)

Wow.  This is the first "official" smoked beer Ive tried, and its truly an interesting and awesome style.  Big maltiness with a pronounced hickory-ish smokiness.  Smoky in the style of smoked cheese.  Really awesome.

I love bacon. However, a beer that tastes like bacon just didnt appeal to me. The smoky aroma and smoked flavor just became too overwhelming. I also didnt like the chunky debris on the bottom of the glass. I admire the beer for what it is, but its just not my cup of tea.

What a great beer.  I had this in Berlin 4 years ago and saw it at a nearby store.  It wasnt as smokey as I expected.  Maybe thats because Im in the kitchen grilling lamb chops.  The smokiness makes it seem spicy.  It is very well balanced.  An excellent beer

Bam! Blackish with ruddy stains. Overpowering waft of smoke. This is a bastard of beer. 
Smells like buckling or kippers. A real barbeque beer; an Islay Scotch of beers.
This beer has been chared. Dry finish. Other than the overpowering smokiness of this
beer there is little merit, because you see how flat and carbonated it is after swallowing.
Yet in the mouth its full, sugary, oily and worty. A musty beer. Liquid rawhide. Offbeat
and peculiarly attractive.
Smoke titan: after opening a bottle with this beer, you feel the smoke is everywhere in the room: in your nose, in your ears, on your lips. One of the most unusual and wonderful beers in the world.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2009 Dec, 2002 Bottle  Smokey and greasy - bacon then turkey with a touch of kippers. A little Lapsong Souchong (my favourite tea). The progression in the nose is: smoke (wow!) rancid bacon (ugh!) then sweetness like a decaying corpse (interesting!). The body is smoke (now a little chemical) grease (and here you reflect on all the smoked food products youve tried) and then the hops come in with the Lapsong tea taste (mmmm). The body is thin and is at odds with the power of the smoke. At one time all beers would have been smoke flavoured, but that would have been balanced against a very sweet ale malt base. Using the traditional malt smoking with the more recent cold lagering results in a pigs ear of a beer - neither fish nor smoked red herring. Interesting? No doubt about it. Your favourite beer? Quite possibly. World class? Jackson thinks so, and this is the most famous example of a smoked beer, so its certainly a must have beer. [2.9] 
 Aug, 2003  Gravity Cask, GBBF 2003  Smokey bacon aroma. Smooth yet tingly mouthfeel. Soft and delicate flavour. Watery finish initially, but becomes quite smokey. Aroma is way better than the taste. [3.3]
Sept, 2009 Bottle at Greenwich Union. Bottle had been kept in very cold fridge, so this took a long time to warm and find the flavours. The aroma is famous, and deservedly so - all sorts of smoke - wood, bacon, smoked mackerel. Taste (when it came) was chocolate - smooth and almost stout like. No awareness of hop bitterness, the bitterness balance coming from the smoke. There were old trainers and burnt rubber and treacle and malted milk biscuits and caramel. The flavour is decent enough, and I enjoyed the flavour more than on previous occasions. [3.5]
This is a very interesting and unique style.  Smells like smoked bacon and tastes very similar.  I imagine this would go great with BBQ.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2003 PROBABLY THE BEST BREWERY IN THE WORLD!!!!This is what LAGER beer is all about. Acquired taste like Scotch. Not for little boys, Big Cahones only! If you dont like this you should wear a skirt. Do you perfer your meat baked in the oven or smoked on the grille?  SMOKED is Better. Drink it like beer not to be sipped like an ale. This along with Denmark/Norway Spezial and German/Austrian Heller Bock make up some of the best beers offered in this WORLD.
The Germans had it right, lager is the best beer and smoked is the best lager. Drink 4-5 and tell me its not GOOD BEER. Forget all those ALE little dessert flavors and drink a REAL MANS BEER!!! Try it with pancakes, on the crapper, driving to work, skydiving, ridin a porcupine, hell this stuff is gggrrreeaaattt!!! anytime!!!

didnt quite know what to expect of rauchbier but i wasnt disappointed in the flavour department. black bean at the bottom of the wok. reminded me a lot of australias own sheaf stout except for that it was actually enjoyable to drink

More like an ale than I was expecting.  The aroma is like smoked ham but the flavour is fairly hoppy.  The worst bit about the beer is the time it takes to get use to its smokey nature, but this grows on you.  Better overall than I was expecting.

Im a fan of big, smoky single malt whiskies, so this beer is right up my alley. A beautiful smoky aroma from the moment the bottle is opened. Pours into a gorgeous ruby-brown colour with a moderate head. More of that smoky smell - I could just sit and sniff it for hours. Inital crisp taste gives way to the smoke as it slides down your throat, and rolls into a nice, dry finish. I had some alongside a lunch of hearty borscht, smoked gouda and potato bread, and I was in heaven.
I have got to try this with eggs.  Huge bacon character over one of the best Maerzens Ive tasted.  Excellent.
Smoke, smoke, smoke. There is not much more to taste. Causes nausea in me. Headache if you drink more. If you love your health take care!
Has a firm smokiness with hints of beechwood.Has a long, dry finish.Very deep color
this is a nice brew, oak-smoke taste and medium head that backs off fast, dark coloration and nice after taste, this is a fairly good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2013 2013-10-17, parallel tastingbottle bb 2014/04, 8-5-8-4-16=41bottle bb 2012/04, 9-5-8-4-18=44The fresh one is dynamic and more lively, more carbonated, and performs well even when it gets much warmer in the glass; the aged one is rounder, a bit mellower, with more wood aroma, and very light traces of oxidisation; and its better when a bit colder than the other one.2011-09-30, draught at Ølbaren, Copenhagen, 10-5-8-4-17=44In the large mug the color seems very dark; the head is creamy. The nose is full of smoked ham, followed by campfire. Good caramel flavor, but the body has less impact than usual, the mouthfeel is drier, and with more roastiness; usual bitterness. The final is quite dry2011-02-12, at the brauhaus, from fass, 9-5-9-5-19=47And finally, here I am at the mother of all rauchbiersI got two glasses, one was last of the small fass, one was the beginning of a small fass.Dark chestnut color; generous, compact head. The aroma is less strong than from a regular tap, but very harmonious; it mixes the smoke, with the wood campfire, and some roasted nuts; not fat, nor sour (but the new fass shows some butter too). The carbonation is very mild, therefore the flavors can develop better; caramel, chocolate, smoke, roasted nuts Somehow there is some residual sweetness too. The flavor is worth an 8, but it gets at least an additional point because of the harmony and blend. Correct bitterness. The final has a good mix of smooth caramel, smoke and bitterness. Perfect.2010-02-14, bottle, bb 06-2005, about 6 years old, 9-5-9-4-17=44Dark brown color; generous creamy head, reducing to a thin layer and nice lace. Nice smoke aroma, with roasted chestnuts, dust, light pepper and wood. Mellow caramel flavor, smoked, woody; the body is lean; lower bitterness, not sweet but the age has softened the corners; the final shows a good mix of caramel and smoke. No signs of oxidization. Marvelous.2009-10-09, draught at Ølbaren, Copenhagen, 9-5-7-4-16=41Beautiful mahogany color, generous creamy head. All around the glass it spreads its wonderful aroma, smoky, deep, with just a bit reminding smoked sausages. Caramel flavor, less sweet than I would prefer, with medium body strength, and of course the smoked malt. The final has a quite low bitterness, some comes from caramelized sugars. Very well brewed; personally I prefer the Urbock.2007-04-02, draught at Bishops Arms, Malmö, 8-5-8-4-16=41Beautiful dark amber color; generous creamy head. Very nice smokey aroma, harmonious, sweet. The flavor has more roasted malt (and therefore bitterness), than the bottled version, which also hides the smokey character more; some nice hop as well. But its a great beer as usual.2002-11-14, bottle, 8-5-8-4-16=41Misty dark brown color, with a big persistent head. Very nice smoked aroma, hiding some malt. The taste is very well balanced, smoked of course, with some malt and the right blend of bitterness; quite dry.Im just figuring out which food to eat with, the next times

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2007 Bought this recently and got a very different impression from a bottle I brought back from Germany. I enjoyed the one straight from the source (no surprise there). Wonder if this hadnt been well kept or my tastes have changed so quickly. The good impression was one that I wouldnt enjoy all the time, but was akin to BBQ in a bottle. A nice, but strong mix of smoked flavor playing off the malt sweetness. This latter bottle gave an overly smoky flavor with something fishy that I couldnt quite put my finger on .... kept trying to find before I just gave up and headed for the drain.
______________________________
Retooling what seems a really unfair rating as the times I had this brought VERY divergent feelings. - the drain pour above, and one where my nose lingered above the glass and the ultra-smoked flavor was a delight, definitely dominating, but still playing with the malt and sweetness.

Holy crap, this is amazing.  Its almost like I am drinking a campfire.  Man this stuff is smokey.  Smells of smoked meat (pepperoni, salami, bacon), ends with a beautiful long smokey finish.  Absolutly outstanding.

I guess smoked beer just isnt the beer for me.  It smelled and tasted like a spiced smoked meat, which I will eat on occassion, however the flavor just isnt what I want in a beer.  I think Ill be staying away from smoked beers as much as possible.

Dark reddish brown, decent head formation. Lightly smoked bacon aroma covers over a mild sweet maltiness.
Easy drinking, light to medium bodied. Essentially sweet with a light chocolate at first, turning to a subtely well balanced smokiness. Remains refreshing throughout, finishes slightly dry. I was never really sure if I was a smoked beer fan, but this is excellent.

It smells smoked and it tastes smoked. The smoked flavor and scent masks everything in the beer making it hard to find any complexity. It is a nice change of pace if you have some time to invest in enjoying it, certainly not made to chug.
Dark brown tint and smoky aroma.  A crisp full flavor with a heavy smoke taste.  A great beer to go along with a meal.

Smells and tastes, and might very well be smoked gouda. I just didnt know what to make of this brew. I like smoked gouda, but in beer form it is suite strange. At first taste I wasnt too pleased, but it grew on me as the bottle went on. I wont make a repeat purchase however.

Clear reddish-brown, tan head.  Very smokey aroma.  Woody, smokey, malty.  It does have something in common with bacon but I like bacon so its not a problem.  My only complain is that I bought just one bottle.

This reminds me of when my buddy used to smoke beef brisket for 6 hours on a fine barrel style grill, this is a as Smoky as the Mountains in East Tennessee, American Country Ham has nothing on the smokiness of this brew, malty, and a little sweetness among the smoke.Grab the cheddar, beef brisket and this fine beer and come on down. Recommended

Not being a fan of Lapsang Souchong tea, I expected to hate this beer. Deep reddish-brown color, small but dense head, aroma is very smoky, like bacon or beef jerky. Surprisingly, the flavour is more malty than smoky, with enough hops to perfectly balance the smoke and sweetness. Also to my surprise, this is better drunk normally rather than sipped. This beer works on the Reuben principle -- the various strong flavours, some of which may be objectionable on their own, balance each other out to produce a wonderful blend.

Has a dark red, almost black, color and a smokey(bacon anyone?) smell.  Taste is like the smell, smokey with smooth maltiness to it that finished with a refreshing bitterness.  Overall this was a pretty interesting beer, kind of suprising at first, but it settled down to be a pretty good selection.  I bet it would be good with barbaque or smoked fish.

surprised me by being smokey in more of a salmon than an ashtray or whisky kind of way. clean, smooth, rich, and easy to drink. also surprised me by having a nice fresh bitterness. it was pretty funny to see groups of old grandmas walk into pubs in bamberg and order a round of half litres of the stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2009 Bottle... This beer rocks!... The aroma was heavy with malt and hickory-like, bacon smoke. Slightly sweet and lightly floral underneath all other aromas. A beautiful, clear, sparkling dark ruby/copper hue. Frothy, medium-sized khaki head with decent lacing. This Märzen is fairly malty (not overly so), moderately bitter and lightly salty and acidic.  Its full-bodied with lively carbonation and an oily mouthfeel. The long, very dry finish includes a not-unpleasant tangy/bitter palate. A great beer for either sipping or drinking mass quantities.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2004 Original rating: 9th October 2002. Bottled - Some brought me it back from Germany. Dark brown, the large head diminishes quickly. Very smoky aroma. The smoky flavour masks all else - I didnt think Id like it, but I did. (3.5/5)
Rerate: 6th July 2004. I much prefer this than I did before. The smokey flavour isnt sickly, and adds to the entire beer. Oddly refreshing and thirst quenching. (4.3/5). I will put in a total of 4.3 as my tastes have changed, not the beer.

Let me first say that I am enjoying this beer with an October barbecue; chops ang grilled veggies. Dark dark brown. Nice looking carb, which mellows out fairly quickly, but still sticks around. Oh that is so cool. A real malty nose, but with some very restrained smokiness. This is my first rauchbier, and I am not sure I really expected it to be smoky. The taste is great malt, with a very mild smokiness. Smoke is kind of sweet and amazing. Palate is fine, but I think I need to remember that this is not a big porter, no matter how flavourful. Sidenote: my wife loved this, and her fave beer is still Coors Light.

deep reddish brown, quick disappearing  beige head.  smoky and sweet malty aroma.  very full bodied palate with more malt, good bitterness, and smoky finish. this went perfect alongside a blt with aged cheddar.  quite tasty.

Well, I never thought I would EVER even come close to enjoying any kind of rauchbier.  The first time I tried it, 2 years ago (a different beer though I dont remember the name) it tasted absolutely vile.  The only reason my brother in law and I finished what we pourred was that we had paid 9$ for a 1/2L.  I got this same impression again - when i started drinking it (and smelling it).  Its like going over a smokey wet fire and taking a deep breath.  Once your palate gets accustomed (or saturated), you start to notice all kinds of rich malt flavours.  Im new to the style so it is hard to describe, but by the end of the bottle it was quite enjoyable and I could probably have been persuaded to have another. :)

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2004 6/23/2004: The smoke character is still as I remember it, but the body seems drier and less sweet.  Smooth, thick and warming body finishes roasty and woody.  A very nice rauchbier.
9/18/2002: Pours a rich dark brown with tan head.  Upon pouring, smoke fills the room.  This style takes some getting used to, but by the end of the bottle, you only want more.  This beer would be even better if I could enjoy it with some sort of processed meat. Wait, I just remembered I have some Johnsonville Stadium-Style Brats in the fridge.  MMMMmmmm.  I microwaved them, but while drinking this beer I could've sworn they were grilled.  Nice balance of sweet malt with the smoke flavor.  Better mixture of flavors than the Aecht Schlenkerla Weiss.  This is a very respectable brew and a must try.

Deep amber, small head.  The lace was not sheets, it was curtains!  The taste was initially thin, then suddenly full and thick.  Smokey roasty malts, very long lasting smoky finish.  Im still not sure if I really like this, but its easier to handle than the Urbock.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2007 Bottle  500ml 
Classical 500 ml euro bottle. Perfect shape for and size 
Appearance :Good clean lager with medium fine top. 
Nose :Country smoked kielbasa, slightly strong at first but with time rauch blends with body seamlessly.Flavour/Palate: Medium bodied, gently yet assertive warming alcohol. Clean malt work creates perfect blanket for smoky character. Quiet refreshing liquid meal. Very Central European in character. Definitively not for everyone, beginner might be put off by such unusually meaty character. If you are able to put behind this with acquired taste this is true treat!

A bold, challenging beer. Clear, dark amber colour w/ long-lasting creamy head. Assertive smoked ham aroma. Medium bodied. Rich smoked ham flavour w/ an underlying maltiness. Smooth, dry finish w/ a touch of hop bitterness.

Strong smoked sausage  aroma, that might intimidate the first time drinker. Garnet, with a medium toffee head. Smokey, pork hocks flavour, oddly bitter, like burnt almonds. Full bodied, complex. Is there a more unigue beer on the planet?

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2006 Eating prosciutto while walking in a damp, smoked filled tunnel...Wooden torchlight in hand, you finally reach the end of the corridor and find a creamy apple pie waiting for you...Quite an illuminating, heavy fog...

The tap version at the Schlenkerla Ausschank in Bamberg is even a little smokier if you can imagine that, but also very drinkable. The lingering, coating smoke is beautifully blended with quaffability, and the finishing drying effect just makes you want to have more. As good as the bottle, though more quenching.
Phenomenally smoky, but not as much so as the Urbock.  A symphony of flavors pour forth from this beer.  Its in-between Urbock and Weizen in terms of smokiness.

This one had little head to speak of, a rich, clear mahogany color, and an aroma of perfumy hops and smoked malt. Not as sausagey rich as the Urbock, I loved the dry, leathery smokey malt aspects, while maintaining a sweetness and significant hop flavor. The finish was dry and rather bitter, entirely appropriately, I thought. Very good.

pours with a fine-bubbled root beer kind of glass clinging head which covered the product for a moment then went convertible, exposing the beer to the elements above. dark brown like an ancient car body sunken into a river embankment. the first whiff of any schlenky is always a thrill: barbequed beer. yum. an acquired taste id say, generally shocking at first sip but gorgeous by bottles end. sure theres as much smoke as a tire fire, (tho much more attractive), but if you can bend your nose around the christmas ham and smoked salmon, theres caramel and even a little apple or peach. medium palate, pleasantly sweet, not the rush of the urbock, but a grand savory celebration, even for vegetarians.

Slightly less intense version of Schlenkerlas Urbock, quite good and would work well both cold or at room temperature as opposed to the Urbock which I would never drink cold under any circumstances.  Probably a bit better for beginners or those not used to smoked beer.

Deep smoky aroma, like smoked sausage or bologna or other fatty smoked meats. Brown to darkish red in color with small off-white head. Medium carb with medium oily palate. Sweetish start (like a light maerzen) with medium hops character. Sweet smoky fatty finish and after. One of the best smoked beers Ive tried (though I havent tried many yet).
The smokey aroma reminds me too much of smoked meat for me to really enjoy too much.  However, the overall taste isnt too bad, I just dont personally like the smell.
Pretty good.  The smokiness acts a bit like hops, adding pleasant bitterness.  The underlying beer seemed fruity and nice, though too simple.

Man, I love rauchbier.  I have previously had the Ur-Bock and the Weiss, this is the first time I have had the Marzen.  I noticed that it got the lowest rating of the three, and I have to agree with this.  While this rauchbier is  very good, the other two are better.  This one is not as complex as the others.  It is very smoky, with a bitter smoke finish, but the beer itself is not tasted as much as with the other Schlenkerla offerings.  Still, I would take this over almost any beer in the world.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2010 Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is medium to dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted dark bread, roasted grain), with a strong note of savory smoke (meat and wood). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Finally the Maerzen and Urbock are back in fine form after several years of getting poor samples locally...Id almost lost all hope.  The Urbock is assuredly more satisfying, and the Weizen more interesting/unique, but the Maerzen is a perfectly serviceable smoked lager, and more suited to quaffing than the Urbock.  Very high quality smoke character, combo of sweet charred wood and smoked meat...none of the acrid, cigarette ash smoke smell of lesser examples.  Yummy.
This beer is much more smoked sausage tasting than like a normal beer.  It is enjoyable for a depart from normal beer tastes.  Smoky smooth with roasted nutty hints.

Pours a beautiful deep clear garnet, the head is frothy, long lasting, the lace clings to the glass in sheets. The nose is SMOKIN Like Hams from the Hills of Virginia, malt, caramel. Front is sweet, the top medium, the finish is lightly acidic, a tad dry, nicely hopped, and quite pleasant. Thanks Herbjones  - Do me a favor and tell your dad: This Dinky Dau Squid is going snoopin and poopin at zero dark thirty, on Friday once the Eagle Shits, found a place that has ba mui ba and ham and mothers, owned by  a retired gunny cannon cocker, see if he wants any? Ranks #219 on my current 1000 master beer list.

Yep, it smells like smoked meat.  Like really, good, brown sugar cured, smoked pork or something.  It only took me one sip to get beyond the smoky surface and into the remarkable characteristics underneath.  I like the smokiness, and I love the quality of this beer despite its quirks (it seems many people just cant get past the smoke).  Next time I have this it will be with pancakes.

Much more pronounced smoke than in the Weizen, in the aroma but especially the flavor, or maybe its because the underlying style is a bit more subtle than a weizen. Either way, I cant get much from here, except, as Pivo says, it seems to be high quality. The palate is nice and light.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: [re-rate] Whao! Smokey nose, like a smoked ham. Guess what? - it takes like a smoked ham as well*.  Thats about the only thing you can say about this brew. Definitely challenging and hard to get a handle on. Very tough to match with food - best with plain bland things, like a pretzel.  I gave this good points because it is a well made beer: sophisticated for sure…but enjoyable?  Ive had more enjoyable smoked beers. I can see this being a beer you crave after you get used to it.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2003 First rating June 2002: As there is a phrase in Germany 'The little bit I do eat, I can also drink' this is the exact beer to act like this. Smoked ham aroma and tasting with malt intervalls. Long lasting aftertaste. Nice dark amber body, no head. I kind of liked it, but it is not a everyday beer. = 4.0/ Rated again: has also hoppy undertones. Pricks on the tongue - nice long lasting smokey bitter finish.

Perhaps likening beer to gouda cheese doesnt entice folks to try it, but this beer has that lovely gouda aroma but a firm, assertive taste.  Its not for everyone, but its a fun, tasty special beer.

The aroma, how do you explain it. Someone said smoked gouda,I can see that.Beef jerky, I can see that also. The flavor is just as intriguing. Damn I dont know what to make of this. Tastes like liquid smoke. No style is really discernable to me.I like the flavor but as a beer Im not sure.

Beautiful pour into a Pilsner glass, leaving you with a clear copper body with a healthy off-white head.  The aroma is unquestionably smoke -- think back bacon, or maybe heavily smoked gouda.  And the flavor?  Smokey, but not much else.  I want to embrace this beer, but instead I merely chalk it up to experience, thinking its a decent beer, but nothing special.  Maybe its big brother, the urBock, will leave me with greater appreciation of this brewer.

Since this is my first rauchbier,my comments are brief.
Very smokey,beef-jerky aftertaste. Not much flavour beyond this.I dont understand the style.....why do they bother???????

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2005 Brown color. Aroma of bacon, salami. Smoked definitely. Tastes like bacon, but very smooth. Bit dry palate. Nice to have tried one, but ill probably stick to one, thats enough of this kind of beers.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2014 Re-rate: I appreciate the style a lot more now. A very strong smoky aroma with a very gentle smooth flavour. I?m glad i?ve given this one another shot. Original rate: (1.6) This is the first and last rauchbier i have ever tried. It?s just not my kind of beer. Tastes like ashes.
With its lovely red-brown colour and heavy smoked taste this is A GOOD BEER  hmm.. could maybe  been more body
Im pretty sure this beer would complement a nice plate of german sausage with kraut and spaetzel, however I experienced it during a night. I might have to sit at home one night to enjoy this one.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2004 Bottled: A rerate of this beer is long overdue. When I tried this the first time, my palate wasn't really ready for a beer like this. Has a dark ruby colour with a medium sized beige head. Aroma is full of smokenotes and roastyness. Quite pleasant. Flavour reminds me of a 10year old  Laphroigh (which I tried with the beer - nice pairing). Earthy, smoky, roasty on a nice maltbase. Is maybe a little thin bodied. All in all a good oneOriginal rating (1,7): This isn't my kind of beer. Had to try it, but the smoky flavour and aftertaste was to much. I kind of liked the aroma and the appearance, but as soon as i tasted it ......! It will take some time before I taste a smoked beer again.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2003 Lovely smokey aroma and poured deep reddish brown with a nice creamy head that pretty much disappeared immediately.  Yummy smokey and meaty flavor with a lingering aftertaste like you just ate a chunk of smoked gouda cheese, May not sound too appealing but it is indeed a very very good and enjoyable brew.  It would probably be great with grilled meat..

This was my first smoked beer and it was different. It had a pleasant smokey aroma and a dry smokey finish. The head disappeared immediately. I found it really interesting but I would not drink more than one. Not yet anyway.

Dark cola bourbon colour with dark beige short lasting head. My instant reaction to the aroma was smoked fish but there are faint hints of wood and malt lingering somewhere. Medium body with a mild bitter start and middle, a sweetish finish fading to a pleasant dry aftertaste. Difficult to rate as its my first smoked and the novelty factor is still high. Like porters I dont know how many I could drink in one sitting. Maybe one or too. Still nice though.
nice bacon aroma, reddish brown color, but very little flavor. This Marzen doesnt compare well w/ their Urbock. I wasnt too impressed.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2005 Another overdue rerate: I had this a few times this summer and know my original rating was way low. Clear burnt orange color with a tall lasting dry bone colored head. Smoked ham and cheese all over the aroma. Light sweetness up front, much akin to a glazed smoked ham. Enough malt in the front to ease the smoke in. Light dry finish with a mild linger of malt and coals. 
3 June 2002: (9,3,5,3,13 - 3.3) The aroma was fantastic, but I believe I got a bad bottle.  Way to many errant flavors.  Will rerate when I get a better sample.

These smoked beers are so highly rated and I was excited to find a couple bottles of the Marzen.  I poured it into my glass, put my nose to it and immediatly had visions of hamhocks, bacon and dried pork hanging from a big hook.  I would like all of those things with my beer, not IN it!!!  Maybe some smokiness, maybe a lot, but not all. I found it totally undrinkable. I found that there is a reason that I will buy more... Bratwurst soaked in this overnight makes a delicious dinner.
clear red-brown colour, few head, highly smoked bacon aroma and flavor, salami, full-bodied, malty, some sweetness followed by a strong bitterness and a long dry smokey finish - very good beer !

Wow! This is one of the most distinct beers I have ever tasted.  Its like tasting the inside of a smoke house!  Perhaps great with any type of meat.  Ive had some other smoked beers, but this one the flavor definitely stands out.  A nice dark color.  Every sip leaves me guessing.  I found this to be one of the most interesting beers in a long time.
I do like the heavier body of the Urbock slightly better.

I was certainly impressed by my first smoked beer.  Head diminishes quickly leaving behind some lace.  The first whiff is reminiscent of beef jerky or what you might scrape off the grill at the end of summer.  Flavor is ummmmm... well, smokey.  Definitely smokey.  Ill definitely be trying some more of these.

I tried this one and the Urbock for the first time the same day. My beer drinking partner and I both enjoyed it although agreed it would be a better cold month beer than early spring beer (like the day we tried it). Would love to get a bunch of it together to eat with some open fire cooked meat next winter. I had a slight preference for the Urbock over this one - I think.

This was my first smoked beer, and i totally enjoyed the experience.  The smokey smell and flavours were great.  Unfortunately i drank it whilst eating salad - I would have preferred some smoked German sausage to make for a great experience.  I got told that id either love it or hate it, and i definately really enjoyed it.  I couldnt say it was my favourite style ever, but it certainly is the most interesting and unique beer that Ive had.  Thanks Lea!

They say these Rauchbiers arent just for breakfast anymore, but I might prefer this smoked bacon brew with pancakes, maple syrup and sausage.  Theres depth to the smoke that isnt quite matched by the sweetness shining through its billowing clouds of burning grain. They do leave room to watch this, the beer is a bit wet. You can see the smoke balancing some solid hopping. Im excited to try the other two Schlenkerla (at the Toronado pronounced: shuh LENK er LAH).

Hickory smoked bacon beer?  Well, it’s not for everyone, certainly not appealing to my taste buds, but I had to try it, as it’s one of my friend’s favorite brews.  The head dissipates almost completely, the aroma instantly dominates your senses, overwhelming to the uninitiated, but there’s a nice, smooth texture, somewhat thin, but the flavor is just too gamy, like you drink this while eating grizzly bear.

after warming up this beer, really takes on a nice flavor.  hickory smoke aroma, and definately smoked flavor, but it is actually quite good.  Dont drink it too cold, I found it too be quite sharp, the first few tastes.

Wow.  Strong aroma of smoke, reminiscent of hickory smoked bacon. Absolutely wonderful in the flavour.  Nice bitter finish to take the edge off the smoke.  Long lasting finish, slightly salty.  Palate thin enough to keep it from being chewey.  Highly recomended experience.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2013 Dark amber with rich, stable head. Densely smokey aroma, quite reminiscent of smoked ham. Full bodied with big maltiness and nicely salty, very bitter finish. The intense woody smokiness is there all the way through. Simply a world class beer in its own style. When had from the wood at Schlenkerla it gains yet another dimension - combining intense flavours with Franconian drinkability and softness. If youve only had it from bottle or keg - you dont know what youre missing!
First rauchbier.  Great aroma, the smokiness grew on me as I drank on.  I am not usually a fan of smoked food, but I thoroughly enjoyed this beer.  A dry finish.  Very relaxing.

Apparently I didnt rate this when I had one in December. Well, heres memory... Amazing stuff; very smoky. Id say smoked mozzarella rather than ham or salmon, but its certainly like drinking a regular (but good) marzen while your house is burning down (just a conjecture, I dont think Id have a beer under those circumstances.) Worth looking for if you like smoked things.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2007 it tasts like smoked ham. You have to get used to it. On my visit to Bamberg I really tried. With every sip the beer tasted better and better. Re-rate: aroma and flavor of smoked ham. Smoky, yet malty flavor with some tropical fruitiness well hidden behind the smokiness. The tap version gets you by the throat, the bottled version has more finesse. The benchmark for smoked beers.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2009 After the initial shock of the smoked ham (!) taste this beer becomes very moreish.  Its one of my favourites and I recommend it to all open-minded beer drinkers.  Update - finally had this on cask and it was incredible.  Well worth my original 4.6.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2009 Color is n/a as it is being served in a stein.  Dense, sticky, foam cap.  Aroma of bacon and othe smoked meats, salt.  Flavor of smokey meats that gets more intense the more is consumed.  Campfire goodness.  The body is actually fairly light for a marzen.  This is the Quinessential rauchbier and is absolutely world class.  Others shall be judged in comparison.  I wish i could taste it fresh.

My first rauchbier.  I cant say if it is good or bad.  I can merely say that the first sip intimidated me slightly.  As I started drinking it though, I thought, Not that bad.  Definitely not a taste that Ive experienced before.  I can sum up by saying, I will try again.

A very strong smokey/campfire/ham flavor just like the urbock. This beer is a little thinner, but equally smooth and complex. I like the urbock better and this is still above average, but not world class.
Lets just say that I dont care much for heavy-smoked beers at this point.

The first time I tasted this VERY smoky beer I hated it. Acouple of years later I tasted it again and thought: Hmmm, it wasnt THAT bad. So I tasted it again and thought: HELLO this is GOOD!!. Now its one of my favourites. So folks, its never too late to learn to like something.
Smooth, smoky (bacon) taste. An absolute treat!
big smoky flavor with plenty of sweet malt. An interesting beer with a nice amount of complexity while maintaining drinkability.
Smelt like smoked bacon or salami (and campfire smoke), salami on the palate and slight bitterness towards the finish. Different, well-balanced and tasty.
Big smokey taste that is backed up with a big malt taste.  Some people may be put off by the smokiness of this, to them Id recommend drinking this beer with some smoked meat or bacon.
A very pleasant combination of smokiness and maltiness, excellent companion to red meat.
Smelled of definite smoke aroma. Different thats for sure. Big smoke on the palate with a slight bitterness. Well balanced.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2004 Wooden cask (gravity), at the Schlenkerla. Deep ruby red brown, excelent lasting creamy white head and gentle condition. Incredible sweet smokiness in the nose with some toffee sweetness to balance it out a little, sweet in the mouth but with a touch of woody dryness developing and again plenty of smokiness. Long lingering sweet malty smoke in the finish.
Also sampled at the Schlenkerla outlet in Nuremberg, from a keg. If anything the different serving method seemed to accentuate the aroma and flavour of smoke.
Lovely beer that has a malty tast, that makes the smokiness very mellow. It takes a pint to get used to, but then ....

At first it reminded me of camp fire smoke in your face, but after a few sips it more reminded me of smoked meat which was alot more satisfying.  A beer that you sit down and enjoy rather than gulp back.  Nice body, and an alright aftertaste.
Holy smoke! Not for everyone. Lots of taste - a little bit like smoked ham. Well rounded and pretty heavy.
Try with barbecue. One of my favorite memories is this beer with rib tips from Perry Fosters BBQ in Warrensburg, MO.
Mmmmm.  Thatss good, very smokey refreshing beer.  Instilled in me an overwhelming desire to have barbecue.

Smoked pork chops in the form of beer. Once you get over the shock, its actually pretty damn good. Tasted great with the asparagus chicken dish I was having at the same time. Smells like a barbecue with smoked ham, yummy.
One of my favorite beers.  This is the defining standard for all rauchbier.  Pronounced SCHLENK er la.  Most Americans dont like...leaves more for me!

Smells like an extinguished campfire, very much like peat and beef jerky.  Deep, dark cherry red, I was taken aback by the first sip, which left a lingering smoky aftertaste. As time passed, the smoky offensiveness did as well, leaving a tasty, smoked-ham beer with a creamy tan head.  The underlying sweetness never breaks through, surpressed throughout by the bullying burtness that gives this beer an identity unlike any other.
Excellent cherry red color. Smells like smoked meat. Tastes like Lebanon bologna. If can get past that it isnt bad. Very smokey. Try it as something different, not on my to try again list though.

My friends and I refer to this as 
das hambier.  The first sip is 
completely disgusting.  After about 3
or so, you get into it a bit more.  Would
go well with sausages and/or cheese.  Not 
my bag.  I like weird beer, but not this one.
Almost as good as the Urbock.  What a beer.  Take a sip and you feel like buying a plane ticket and flying to Germany.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2006 Deep red...ok head..smells of sweet,smokey bacon. The first sip is like inhaling a campfire...i didnt think i would like it...then as i have heard before on this beer...the smoke takes a back seat and becomes a compliment to the beer...which has a very decent malt palate and a smooth drinkability and finish...damn good beer!

As was mentioned previously, theres a definite sense of bacon going on here. Ive had this before with Scotch where it wasnt a bad thing, and it wasnt a bad thing here. The smokiness balances nicely with the malt flavor, and it leaves a very light, smooth aftertaste.

Aroma and flavor are wonderful, though I think a bit less complex than the Urbock.  More woody on the nose and hoppy on the tongue, a gorgeous deep red hue, and wonderfully smooth and silky going down.  This could be the best brewery in the world, folks.  Now for that Weiss . . .
1st one Ive tried and Ill have another. Very nice aroma. Makes me want to find a wooden barrell to make my next batch of homebrew.
A world classic smoked Marzen.  Gets better everytime you taste it. Remarkably complex, balanced, and delicious.
The queen of all smoked beers :-)

This beer (and its sisters) are lovingly made by the Trums of Bamberg. They even malt their own barley, and kiln it over a Bocha (beechwood) fire. If youre ever in Bamberg, be sure to visit the Schlenkerla Ausschank, where this is served from the Holzfaß (wooden keg). Much more aggressively smoked than their Weizenbier (which is destined to also be a world classic).
This is the only smoked beer ive tried and i liked it. goes down smooth
Definitely a tasty beer.  I wasnt sure about smoke beer, but this laid all fears to rest.  My favorite smoke beer of the 4 or 5 Ive tried thus far.

Wow. I have to agree with an earlier posting regarding this a liquid smoke in a bottle.  What a different experience this was.  So much so, that I had to go out and get another bottle of it!  Very good.  Drink this while eating something heavy, like a pot roast or venison.  Very good.

Zbrew said it: like liquid smoke in a bottle. I cooked with liquid smoke once and accidentally put too much on the meat - made me wanna puke. Thus, smoked beers always conjure up that memory - therefore they arent my favorite style. However, I can appreciate this beer for how well-made it is. I liked everything about it, except I thought the smoke flavor was too dominant and overpowering.

First I will assume that this is the Marzen that we are evaluating. The brewery also makes an smoked Ur Bock, a smoked Wheat, as well as an unsmoked helles.

With that said, this is the standard that all other Rauchbiers are judged against. It has a wonderful smoked flavor that grows on you with each glass. It is the perfect beer to complement any smoked meat. Freshness is always a concern, although I have found that this beer does not suffer from age as badly as most.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2009 There are few pleasures in this world like Schlenkerla Marzen from the wood.  Oh sure, Ill take the bottles, but lets not kid ourselves, those are only a 4.7 or 4.8.  When you go to the ausschank in the Bamberg Altstadt, its different.  The glass lands in front of you. The appearance of the beer is a unique reddish-brown, nice and dark with a thick but not overstated head.  The aroma is pure smoke goodness, nothing more nothing less.  The palate shows incredible balance.  Yes, the smoke is huge, but so are the chewy, earthy malts.  The wood finishes the beer, lending it impeccable balance and drinkability.  Theres no need for writing expansively about the nuances and the subtleties...this is simply the perfect beverage. Perfect looks, great aroma, great flavour, perfect balance...finishes brilliantly.  The most perfect beer on the planet, on gravity from the wood like real beer should be.
intense smokey flavor - like liquid smoke in a bottle. Excellent with bratwurst, but not for faint-taste buds

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2005 Rerate deleting my naive first rating and first experience with smoked beer.  Aroma milder than I remembered, campfire for sure, make some smoked sausage, or the clothes of someone who spent too much time near the fireplace.  Flavor less sweet than I expected for a marzen, smoked or not.  Actually the palate was somewhat light and only semi-sweet.  I would say smooth, not watery, though.  Smoke presence clearly predominates.  Attractive dark ruby almost purple color, firm creamy head.
